PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill I am introducing today is to consolidate and expand Australian laws which protect Australian trading interests and policies against the extra-territorial enforcement of foreign laws. I would like to outline, for the benefit of honourable members, the historical and policy context in which the Bill has been prepared and the principal provisions proposed. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable members for information.
Existing Commonwealth Legislation

In November 1976 the Parliament enacted the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act. The purpose of that Act was, briefly stated, to enable the Attorney-General to make orders, subject to parliamentary disallowance, to prohibit the production of documents located in Australia and, in certain circumstances, the giving of evidence in foreign proceedings. The Attorney- General could make orders where he was satisfied that the foreign court was exercising jurisdiction contrary to international law or comity or that the imposition of the restrictions specified in the order was desirable for protecting the national interest. In March 1979 the Parliament enacted the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act. That Act, which was confined to foreign anti-trust judgments, enabled the Attorney-General to prohibit the enforcement of such judgments on grounds which, whilst not identical, were broadly similar to those enabling the Attorney-General to prohibit the production of evidence under the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act. As in the case of that Act orders of the Attorney- General were subject to parliamentary disallowance. The Attorney-General could also permit the partial enforcement of foreign judgments for a reduced amount specified in the order.
The 1981 'Recovery Back' Bill

In June 1981 the former Government introduced the Foreign Antitrust Judgments ( Restriction of Enforcement) Amendment Bill 1981, which I shall hereafter refer to as the 'Recovery Back Bill'. The Recovery Back Bill would have enabled an Australian defendant to a foreign anti-trust judgment, where an order had been made under the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act, to recover back from the foreign plaintiff any amount which had been recovered under the prohibited judgment in an overseas country in excess of the amount specified. The former Government did not seek passage of the Recovery Back Bill following the signing of the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement between Australia and the United States on 29 June 1982.
The Antitrust Co-operation Agreement

The Commonwealth legislative measures that I have referred to were introduced against the backdrop of the troubled relations between Australia and the United States of America in relation to the extra-territorial enforcement of United States anti-trust laws. That legislation was directly occasioned by proceedings in the United States relating to trade in uranium and, more particularly, the Westinghouse suit for private treble damages. Without wishing to go over the entire Westinghouse saga, I would like to point out that the private suit by Westinghouse to recover treble damages from a number of Australian companies, which were among the list of defendants in the proceedings, related to conduct that, although in breach of United States anti-trust laws, took place outside the United States and in compliance with Australian Government policies for the marketing of uranium.

The deterioration in relations in this area between Australia and the United States had become so serious that the matter was raised in discussions between the President of the United States and the then Australian Prime Minister in June 1981. The outcome of these discussions was a renewed negotiating effort to reach agreement. These efforts were ultimately successful and on 29 June 1982 the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement was signed. The Agreement provides a framework for notification and consultation designed to resolve conflicts which might arise between Australian national interests and policies and the implementation of United States anti-trust laws.
The Present Position

When the Labor Government came into office in March last year, the general climate between Australia and the United States in relation to the extra- territorial enforcement of United States anti-trust laws had improved significantly.

The Labor Government has thus been able to formulate its policy on the protection of Australian trading interests and policies against the extra- territorial enforcement of foreign laws in the light of this much improved relationship between the two countries. In reaching its decision to introduce the Bill, the Government also had regard to the Attorney-General's discussions with Government representatives during his visit in June last year to the United Kingdom and the United States. As the Attorney-General then indicated to United States officials, it is better to introduce protective legislation now, during a period of improved relations, than to leave it until some crisis arrives, and so heighten what would be at that time a public perception of conflict between our two countries. The Attorney-General has indicated that, on the basis of the responses he received in Washington, the United States Government would understand the need expressed by Australia to have protective legislation.

The Government is pleased to note the report by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on 'Australian-United States' Relations : The Extraterritorial Application of United States' Laws', tabled on 1 December last year. The majority recommended the introduction of legislation to deal with problems arising from the extra-territorial application of foreign laws. The present Bill is consistent with that recommendation.

The essence of the Labor Government's policy in this area, which has been explained to the United Kingdom and United States governments, is as follows. First, in line with the conclusion of the Parliamentary Joint Committee that both countries should seek to implement both the letter and the spirit of the Agreement, the Government reaffirms Australia's commitment to the consultative approach of the Agreement. It is the Government's firm belief that jurisdictional conflicts between the laws and policies of sovereign governments should be resolved if at all possible by consultations and not by unilateral legal or executive action. The Government will advocate this approach vigorously in its dealings with individual foreign countries and in relevant international fora. I note that the Parliamentary Joint Committee recommended that Australia participate actively in international attempts, such as those within the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, to reach broadly acceptable arrangements to avoid or resolve conflicts in the application of national trading laws.

Secondly, notwithstanding the protection afforded by the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement, the Government cannot ignore the fact that the underlying jurisdictional threat to Australian sovereignty and to our export and other trading policies still remains. There has been no significant change in United States domestic anti-trust laws to take account of foreign government interests and no modification their wide jurisdictional claims. Article 4.2 of the Agreement recognises that if, after consultation, no means of avoiding conflict has been found, each party 'shall be free to protect its interests as it deems necessary'. While articles 4 and 6 of the Agreement also make some progressive steps forward in providing protection against private anti-trust proceedings, our central concern remains. That is, private plaintiffs, who account for about 95 per cent of United States anti-trust actions, are under no obligation to consider the national interests of other countries when they initiate their actions or in the conduct of the case. The United States Deputy Secretary of State, Mr Kenneth Dam, in a speech last year acknowledged that private treble damages actions are not within government control and as result are often referred to in this context as 'rogue elephants'. I note that the obligation in the Agreement on the United States authorities to intervene in private proceedings is at best a limited and indirect restraint on private plaintiffs and in any event the weight to be given to the United States Government's intervention is left to the court to decide.

Thirdly, since Australia first came up against the vexed issue of the extra- territorial enforcement of foreign laws, it has become apparent that the problem goes very much wider than the anti-trust field. The serious conflict between the United States and European countries within the Atlantic Alliance over the measures taken by the United States under the United States Export Administration Act with regard to the construction of the Soviet gas pipeline has focused attention on the wider implications of the problems of extra- territoriality. The problem can extend into many areas such as companies and securities regulation, banking, commodity futures market regulation, taxation, and laws related to enforcing national security or foreign policy controls over trade.

Accordingly, the Government believes that Australia should have available to it a comprehensive arsenal of defences which it could use as a last resort, should the resolution of conflict through the consultative approach fail. It is unacceptable to the Government that at the present time Australian businesses, unlike their counterparts in countries like the United Kingdom, have inadequate protection against the crippling damages and costs awards that are usually made in foreign anti-trust private treble damages suits. Nor have they means of protection against the extra-territorial effect of judicial and executive orders made under other foreign laws which may be inimical to Australia's national interests. I wish to emphasise, however, that in line with the Government's firm belief in the consultative approach in this area, the substantive provisions of the proposed legislation will only operate when activated by an order made by the Attorney-General.

When in Opposition, the present Government gave broad bipartisan support to the legislative measures that were introduced by the Fraser Government. The Government in a real sense is completing the task that was begun by the former Government. Indeed, when the former Attorney-General, Senator Durack, introduced the Recovery Back Bill he said:

It is also designed to underline the seriousness with which the Commonwealth Government and the Parliament continues to view this problem. For here, I believe that I express, in a complete sense, a national voice. The two previous Acts were enacted by the Parliament with bipartisan support and, whatever differences in nuance may emerge, the Opposition has been at one with the Government in its concern.
I would certainly hope, for the reasons I have outlined, that the present Bill will receive the support of this House.
Content of Bill
I will briefly mention the major provisions contained in the Bill.
Prohibition of the Giving of Evidence

Division 2 of Part II of the Bill replaces the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act 1976. The purpose of the provisions, like the earlier Act, is to enable the Attorney-General to make orders to prohibit the production of documents located in Australia and, in certain circumstances, the giving of evidence in foreign proceedings. The Attorney-General may make orders where he is satisfied that the making of the order would be desirable for the protection of the national interest. The Attorney-General may also make orders where he is satisfied that the assumption of jurisdiction by the foreign court or the action taken by the foreign authority is contrary to international law or is inconsistent with international comity or international practice.
Enforceability of Judgments Given in Foreign Anti-Trust Proceedings

Clause 9 of the Bill replaces the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act 1979. These provisions, like the earlier Act, which are confined to foreign anti-trust judgments, will enable the Attorney-General to make an order prohibiting the enforcement of such judgments in whole or in part. This gives the Australian Government the flexibility to respond to the foreign judgment according to the circumstances. The grounds upon which an order may be made are broadly similar to those enabling the Attorney-General to prohibit the production of evidence under Division 2 of Part II of the Bill.

The recovery-back provisions are contained in clause 10 of the Bill. This right of action, given to an Australian defendant to recover back damages enforced against that defendant, is given only where the Attorney-General has made an order that a foreign anti-trust judgment should not be enforceable in Australia in whole or in part. The right of recovery-back, which is given only to Australian defendants as set out in sub-clause 10 (4) of the Bill, is for any amount obtained by the foreign plaintiff from the Australian defendant in excess of the amount specified in the Attorney-General's order. The recovery-back provisions are based on the provisions contained in the 1981 recovery back Bill although they have been refined to avoid the complexity of the earlier Bill. A series of examples illustrating the operation of the recovery-back provisions is contained in the explanatory memorandum.

Clause 11 of the Bill gives a right to an Australian defendant, including an Australian statutory authority, to recover reasonable costs and expenses incurred by it in defending private anti-trust proceedings. This right of action is severely restricted:

(a) it is conditional upon an order being made by the Attorney-General either on national interest grounds or on the ground that the assumption of jurisdiction or the manner of exercise of jurisdiction by the foreign court or the exercise of power or the manner of exercise of power by the foreign court, was contrary to international law or inconsistent with international comity or international practice;

(b) it is confined to private proceedings for multiple damages where it is possible for the foreign court to assume jurisdiction simply upon there being an adverse effect on that country's trade or commerce; and
(c) it is further restricted to foreign proceedings where a successful defendant is not entitled to recover costs. This is peculiar to private anti- trust proceedings in the United States.

Clause 11 of the Bill can be justified on three grounds: An Australian defendant with no physical tie with the territorial jurisdiction of the United States can be put to considerable expense because section 12 of the United States Clayton Act-which provides for service on a corporation wherever found-enables a United States plaintiff to draw the Australian defendant into United States anti-trust litigation.

Again, United States anti-trust law does not allow a successful defendant his costs. This, when coupled with the widespread use of contingency fees, encourages United States plaintiffs to bring specious actions in the hope that the huge costs burden alone will compel the defendant to settle out of court.
Further, the costs burden in large United States anti-trust cases is of a magnitude unknown to our legal system and it is not uncommon for costs to amount to millions of dollars.

I should also mention that for both recovery-back and recovery of costs, orders would not in general be made where conduct, in respect of which a foreign judgment was given, took place entirely within a foreign country. We cannot discount, however, the possibility that situations may arise where it would be appropriate for an order to be made where conduct did take place entirely within a foreign country. An example would be where the costs or damages awarded in a private suit against an Australian defendant were considered to be so high as to be contrary to the national interest. For example, they might threaten the solvency of an Australian company, with consequences for the enterprise in which it was engaged and for the employment of Australian workers.

Clause 12 of the Bill provides for the enforcement of a 'recovery-back' judgment on a reciprocal basis after agreement with countries that have ' recovery-back' provisions that correspond with those in the Bill. The United Kingdom has shown considerable interest in developing the concept of reciprocal enforcement with Australia and has made provision for such a system in section 7 of its Protection of Trading Interests Act 1980. The Parliamentary Joint Committee recommended that consideration be given to reciprocal enforcement of recovery-back judgments only if Australian interests are further threatened or damaged by foreign laws. The Government considers it prudent, however, to deal comprehensively with the problem of extraterritoriality, rather than to introduce additional legislative proposals at a later stage if Australian interests should come under active threat from foreign laws. In this way, we avoid heightening what I said earlier would be a public perception of conflict between Australia and the foreign country.
Actions and Decisions of Foreign Governments Affecting Australia

The purpose of clause 13 of the Bill is to counteract the problem created by foreign laws relating to trade or commerce that would enable foreign governments or their agencies to impose obligations upon persons or corporations in Australia. Clause 13 of the Bill will enable the Attorney-General to make an order prohibiting the performance of the obligation where he is satisfied that the act or decision of the foreign government or agency would or might adversely affect the national interest. The topical example of such a foreign law is the United States Export Administration Act. A provision similar to this clause- Section 1 of the United Kingdom Protection of Trading Interests Act 1980-enabled the United Kingdom Government to counter United States executive orders which were directed at United Kingdom companies with the purpose of blocking the construction of the Siberian gas pipeline, contrary to the national interests of the United Kingdom and the other European States.
Prohibition on Giving Effect to Certain Foreign Judgments

The purpose of clause 14 of the Bill is to enable the Attorney-General to block judgments or injunctions of a foreign court-but not money judgments-where the object of the judgment is to require the doing of an act or thing in Australia, or to prohibit the doing of such an act or thing, or to require a person to refrain from conduct in Australia. The Attorney-General may make an order based on national interest grounds similar to those in clause 13 of the Bill. Possible instances where this clause could be called into operation could include divestiture orders and 'cease and desist' orders made under United States anti- trust laws.
Miscellaneous

Part V of the Bill contains general provisions relating to parliamentary disallowance of orders and intruments made under the Act, jurisdiction of the Federal Court, service of notice of orders, offences and regulations.
Financial Impact Statement

The Bill will not necessitate any increase in the existing staff establishment of the Attorney-General's Department and will have no impact on Government revenues. The Government commends the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Spender) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 7 December 1983, on motion by Mr John Brown:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill 1983, as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering both measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill 1983 relate to the administration of dumping within the Australian economy and the effect that it has on certain areas of trade. The Opposition will not oppose either of the Bills but in the Senate will propose an amendment to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill in the area relating to the issue of warrants, which I will canvass later.

SPEECH.PARA: Dumping is a factor which occurs far more frequently in times of economic stress and comes to the fore in Australia, as a major trading nation, because of the vulnerability of the small Australian market to import penetration. There is no doubt that this has occurred in a number of industries and the procedures brought forward by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) certainly meet many of the problems that have been experienced in the last couple of years. The proposals which were amended in 1981 and brought forward today go a long way towards meeting some of the complaints from industry. I note from the papers and from other advice that industry as a whole has welcomed these changes and has been well pleased with and well serviced by the new administrative arrangements which allow for a 45-day period to settle the matters and for 120 days to investigate the complete project.

There are many forms of dumping that come under consideration. There is price dumping, tariff dumping and the switching of products from country to country. All of these take a degree of administrative skill to trace because the people who exercise these activities are not above using false invoices or making certain statements which are totally incorrect. Because of that, some of the sweeping powers that are in the Customs Act are used with discretion. In some areas I can see the problems that might arise and I understand the enormous administrative problems associated with them. However, there are two areas that require further consideration.

One is the area of freight dumping. I know the Minister has addressed himself to this but, as I read it, the matter has not been resolved. There are some difficulties with it. The most recent case was that of Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd which lodged a complaint against the freight component of imports from North America. The administration in these areas necessarily would find it hard to measure the degree of dumping involved. To do this one has to know what normal rates are, what the published rates were and try to read into that any attempt at freight dumping or taking advantage in that area, particularly when one thinks of the freights that can be offered by certain shipping lines in relation to back traffic and back loading.

The second area is a very old one with which we have had some experience in the past. That involves a product brought in from one country where injury was affecting the local industry and a complaint was raised and the product was then switched to another country. Under those circumstances the same procedure would occur.

The particular product I have in mind came initially from Iron Curtain countries and switched to a European Economic Community country. The maintenance of surveillance and checking up on such activities is an extraordinarily difficult task, especially when the Australian Customs Service is too short on manpower to be able to cover those areas. I understand the problems involved because when in government we attempted to apply voluntary restraints which were accepted by communist governments through their trading companies and by some Western companies. In return for guaranteed access to the market, they agreed not to extend their penetration. However, this generally means that the injury was done before it is caught up with. As a consequence, the problems of country- hopping are still with us and probably will be with us in the future.

One or two other areas are worth drawing to the attention of the House. There is the matter of the processor. In Australia we have a number of processing firms which are dependent on rural supplies, generally fruit and vegetables, sometimes meat. These processing companies take local products. They would not be injured if they were supplied by other countries with a similar raw product at a lower world price. A few years ago there was a case involving tomatoes, strawberries or perhaps even sweet corn. These products were brought in from another country and used by the processor, thus severely affecting the local producers. The local producers had no comeback against that import because the processor would not join the action.

I understand the difficulties of determining the national price of a commodity such as strawberries. By the time they are flown into Australia and processed the injury to the local farmer has occurred. The local producer will no doubt leave them on the plants. Thus to ascertain a real market price would be extraordinarily difficult. I draw this to the attention of the House because I know that large numbers of people in the rural sector feel that they do not get a fair go from the processing industry, particularly if the processor will not join with them in an action available to them under the dumping procedures.

There are two other matters worth pointing out. The first is that there appears to be no appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. One of the stumbling blocks in the past was that when an action for dumping was taken the person in receipt of that action normally rushed the decision to the AAT and thereby stalled the action. The injury therefore continued within the industry. The procedures within this legislation limit that possibility so that the direct impact will be immediately felt.

I find some difficulties with another area, that of search warrants. Two types of warrants are used by the Customs Service. Much to the surprise of the House, I guess, under schedule 5 the open search warrant can be issued only by the Comptroller-General or his designated officer. It can be used in a general sense to search and take whatever documents or property they deem necessary. The Opposition will move an amendment in the Senate to require a judicial warrant for that activity. It seems a little harsh to think that it is possible for an officer at any time to enter and seize any property without a judicial warrant.

However, there is a second warrant, the section 4 warrant, which is known in the trade as the 214 warrant. It is issued by the collectors in various States. This is made out to a particular person, and can be issued only by the collector directly to that person, and only after that person has declined to co-operate with Customs in relation to an investigation. That seems to me to be the proper procedure. The Customs people have a difficult time trying to find out the real truth in regard to many dumping matters. They have an extraordinarily difficult task, and I commend them for it. Trying to keep up with the range of marketing activities from country to country is in itself a technique, but when collusion occurs here as well, the Customs officials must be able to get access, and I certainly support the continued use of the 214 search warrant. I draw the attention of honourable members to the other circumstances in regard to which we will be moving an amendment in the Senate. Overall, the proposals which have been put forward have our support, and I look forward to the continued healthy administration of the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate in Australia in recent years regarding protection and dumping and a range of other industry measures has become very confused. I think the actions of the Government in this regard early last year on achieving office were very pertinent. A number of actions were initiated, the review of the dumping procedures being one of the key actions. Honourable members will also recall that in the steel plan a new phrase was coined-'fast anti-track dumping procedures'. That that phrase was even needed was indicative of the problems which were occurring within Australian industry as a result of the existing anti-dumping and countervailing measures.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government believes that Australian industry protection procedures should be restructured, that we should become more competitive and that we should be able to compete more adequately in international markets. But the same time, we must recognise that restructuring must be done on a fair and equitable basis. The changes in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill are based on a sense of fairness and fair competition.

When one looks at what has been happening in Australia in recent years, the contracting market place and the world's economic recession have meant that economies like Australia's have become much more vulnerable than they were in previous decades, so much so that a number of industries, I believe, have been seriously threatened by unfair competition. The dangers that presented to our country as a whole and certainly to Government actions became of paramount importance.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) referred to the difficulties experienced by the Australian Customs Service in terms of staffing and the complications involved in checking and assessing dumping procedures and dumping actions. In the last three years or so these weaknesses have become much more pertinent as the volume of imports of a potentially dumped nature increased.

That we have had those problems at the same time as we have had the problems of high interest rates, high inflation, developing country preferences, and a whole range of other industry problems has meant that as a nation we have become increasingly confused in terms of our understanding of industry protection. I have heard it said by many people that the anti-dumping measures are anti-free enterprise, anti-competition, when in fact that is quite clearly not the case. So much jargon has been coined and there has been so much emotive language regarding all areas of anti-dumping that I suspect that the public is totally confused, as are many industries, as to what should be the clear policies of and the clear guidance from the Government. It was therefore not surprising that last year when the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) issued a discussion paper he received 150 submissions, and some of those were very detailed and complex. I believe that that was still, to some degree, the tip of the iceberg. However, those submissions covered virtually all of the major problems.

These amendments go some way towards addressing those problems. Honourable members may recall a speech that I made in this House last year regarding country switching and a few other aspects that I am pleased to see are now being picked up. However there is an underlying problem. It is that the European Economic Community operates as an economic community and Australia operates as an economic community but the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade relates to individual countries not economic communities. I suspect that Australia will have to look much more closely at its agreements in terms of GATT and begin to say: 'If you six, eight or 10 countries want to form an economic union you must let us treat you as one rather than expect to have the benefit of that economic union and also of being treated as separate countries'. That would have a significant effect on country switching because the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, COMECON, and the EEC are clearly single economic communities. They operate as one. Their industries are interwoven across national boundaries and it seems quite inappropriate that we in Australia should be forced to compete with them on world markets, given their economic strength as members of a union, and at the same time be forced to deal with them as separate countries when it comes to fair trade in respect of our own industries.

The aspects that have been picked up in the amendment are particularly pertinent. I have been aware of a number of dumping actions that have been in progress in the last year and certainly the time delays have been fairly cataclysmic. What tended to occur was that while the case was being examined the volumes of imports tended to increase. This has a stockpiling effect. In one case that I am aware of, in which anti-dumping action eventually was successful, the actual lead time became some nine months from the making of the decision. It was nine months before the product was phased into the market at the increased price. Importing and stockpiling prior to the making of the decision had meant that the affected company in Australia suffered some one and a half to two years of unfair competition. While the 45-day and 120-day periods will be very pertinent, the volume of imports attained prior to that will be a matter that the Government may well have to address in the times ahead.

The other aspect of the amendment with which we will have to grapple in the months ahead concerns the situation in which a company takes a profit. It will be quite appropriate, when the Bill becomes law, to establish a price-an aspect that we have had difficulty with in the past-but where companies are interwoven in both Australia and the exporting country it is quite reasonable to assume, as with transfer pricing, that the organisation may take its profit in the parent company and therefore export to Australia at what seems to be a fairly reasonable market price. But when the product is retailed in Australia, if the wholesaler's profit is removed and the profit available in the parent country is accepted, unfair competition may well still result. When international companies look at their global accounts it is quite reasonable for them to assess that they will use Australia for turnover and the parent country for profit. Therefore, we may well still have some flow-ons in regard to companies ignoring a normal wholesale profit margin in Australia. I believe that that has been happening, certainly in regard to some companies I have been watching in recent times. Even though some countervailing duties have been imposed, the product is still retailed in Australian stores at a price vastly below what would be the normal retail marketing price.

In considering dumping procedures we are looking at the import price, the price for the product landed in Australia, not the price in Australian retail establishments, so there is a secondary stage which seems to be of importance. We must, then, take into account the profitability within the product as well. Although the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) indicated in the second reading speech that profit margin was not a major factor in manufacturing costs, very often it is a major factor in terms of total sales value, and that will vary from product to product. The capacity to ignore a profit margin in a product is an aspect that will not go away as a result of these amendments; in fact, it will be resurrected. I believe that the fierceness of competition and the difficulties being faced by other economic communities, such as those of Europe and certainly America, will ensure that companies with capacity to export to Australia will do so under whatever terms and measures they can. I do not doubt that this legislation in its amended form will be stressed and strained quite heavily by those who seek ways of maintaining production levels in their own country.

I was also pleased to see in the second reading speech that the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Government will be looking very closely at Government tenders and procedures to ensure that the Government itself will not be a party to purchasing dumped products. That has been a source of embarrassment in regard to one product in particular. I refer to fluorescent tubes and light globes. It is quite clear that State and Federal Government departments have, if anything, been major purchasers of dumped products. It was subsequently proved and accepted that the products in question were dumped. If it had not been for the governments' purchase volumes it is likely that the product would not have had such an impact on the Australian market. It is bewildering to find that government departments, which in theory apply the spirit of the legislation, in these connotations have been totally ignoring it. There was quite significant capacity on the part of those departments to say: ' Technically we cannot take action under the existing legislation but in practice we can ignore those products; we do not have to buy them if we believe that they have a dumping component'. To some degree it has been that blindness which to my mind has, in certain areas, made government itself, and government departments, seem very suspect in the view of many manufacturers. On the one hand they see the legislation, weak and imperfect as it may be, and on the other they see governments of the day at Federal and State levels exploiting all of its loopholes. That is part of the reason there has been a tendency in the industrial community to question the sincerity of governments.

The other aspect that I would like to raise in this context is that in regard to Australian industrial policy-anti-dumping procedures, developing country preferences, bounties versus tariffs and so on-it is important that we first separate this legislation and these amendments from other industrial policy matters. In a way, what this is all about is establishing a platform of fairness and equity for Australian industry whereby it can see that if it behaves and acts in a responsible way it will be fair and reasonable to expect that other industries and countries will do the same.

On the other hand, as I mentioned earlier, there is a tendency in the public mind to mix up dumping, developing country preferences, tariffs and bounties in one big bunch. They are handled eventually by the same departments or Minister anyhow and there has been a tendency to suggest that governments and industries, in attempting to use anti-dumping procedures, gain leverage and, if you like a competitive edge. That clearly is not the case, because in virtually every instance I have observed the Australian company has had to more than prove its case and duties, when imposed, normally have been slightly below what was seen to be, to my mind, fair. That is because of our responsibility to other nations and our involvement in GATT. We have to be seen to be acting totally fairly. If we as a country discriminate against the products of other countries in a way that breaches such agreements our international trading reputation will become very shaky. I think it must be made very clear that the anti-dumping procedures, rather than giving our companies a competitive edge, even if completely complied with and accepted, have tended to mean that those companies are still slightly behind the eight ball.

Looking at the other side of the coin in terms of Australian protection systems , the anti-dumping legislation in effect imposes a responsibility on importers to account for the veracity of their imports. In the same way the attitude that has become prevalent-certainly the Government has brought it forward in things such as the steel plan-is that we should ensure that Australian industries are in fact accountable for the assistance they are given. I think that is where major changes start to occur. To my mind the steel plan, for the first time in Australia's history, has in it a mechanism to ensure that the protection offered to Australian industries becomes an accountable protection which is audited by a third party. Therefore, I think we must clearly distinguish in the public's mind between the anti-dumping procedures, and other tariff and industry assistance mechanisms. We should ensure that goods are being imported on a fair and competitive basis and that in fact the costs of manufacture in the parent company are not being subsidised or disguised, so that Australian industries are competing in a genuine, non-Rafferty's rules situation. The third part of the government reviews that are taking place obviously must deal with the subject of special country relationships and, again, anti-dumping legislation becomes relevant there.

I am delighted that within the first 12 months of government the Minister has been able to bring this legislation forward. I trust it will be given a speedy passage through both Houses because industry badly needs to have these amendments adopted and endorsed. I think it is a significant contribution to the industrial manufacturing systems in Australia that the Government has recognised the need for this overhaul so early in its term. Mind you, I expect that a much more profound overhaul will be needed in the next few years as well. I think what the Government has done here has been to react to a situation that existed at the start of last year-certainly in March of last year. It has reacted in a very speedy and responsive way. I do not think we should assume that we have in fact finished with the problem. I think more cases will come forward and new loopholes will be explored. I am sure that as each one is closed off two more will open up. I do not think the pressure on Australian industry will go away because of these amendments. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When one talks about dumping it is very difficult, of course, to ignore the wider subject of the tariff and what it means to the Australian economy. Although I have some very specific issues that I wish to raise on the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1984 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill 1983 and the direction in which this legislation should go, I think it is reasonable that in the first instance I should make a few comments on the broader issue of the tariff in Australia. I have been wondering what the policy of this Government is in that regard since our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is somewhat naive in business matters, got himself into the situation overseas of saying all things to all people and expounding, amongst other things, a major policy on the restructuring of Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that we must now wonder what it is because, of course, once he discovered what the opinions of many of his colleagues were on this subject he decided he needed to get us into other areas of great interest, such as steel in China, so that he could start to muddy the waters of that statement. In fact, he terrified his colleagues and he terrified his supporters in the trade union movement. However, we do not have to worry about that. I would have supported entirely the Prime Minister's statements in Japan. Let me be quite honest and say that I would have supported entirely the statements that my Prime Minister made overseas when we were in government. But let us get back to the truth and reality of what they both said once they got back to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get back to the Bill, too.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I was making a point about tariffs in particular and dumping is an integral part of the tariff business. The point I want to make is that, since the Prime Minister returned, he has completely muddied the waters by making to the trade unions in a major speech in New South Wales a promise which indicates to me-probably to the gratitude of most honourable members on the other side of the House-that he will probably be well and truly defeated, retired or possibly dead and buried before any major restructuring of the type he referred to in Japan occurs. All we need to know is whether there is a policy at all available to the Australian public on the tariff business.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to bring to your attention, Madam Deputy Speaker, and to the attention of this House some of the thoughts which I believe are essential in this regard. One of these, of course, must be the consideration by any government of what I refer to as the neutral tariff. If anyone consults the last Budget Papers they will see that the estimate of tariff collections is $2.123 billion. On the other hand, the estimate of bounties that might be paid by the Government to encourage industry to compete is $0.329 billion. This leaves a profit, if one likes, to government-a positive revenue differential-of $1.794 billion. Irrespective of the interest of the Prime Minister and his Ministers in the business of restructuring Australian industry, I just wonder whether we will ever get an enlightened Minister for Commerce, or whatever he will be labelled at the time, who will go into Cabinet and say: 'Fellows, I have worked it all out. From here on in there is no need for us to apply tariffs to protect Australian industry. Industry can stand on its own two feet. I have worked it all out'. The first person to jump to his feet after that statement would be the Treasurer to inquire about where the revenue of roughly $2 billion would come from.

This is not a problem just of this Government; it has been around for a long time. That revenue component will obviously withstand at all times the real efforts of sensible Ministers to overcome the distortions in this particular matter. Quite clearly, therefore, the tariffs that are collected should not be used for Consolidated Revenue. They should be used to provide bounties in other areas of protection. So, the revenue component of our protection should be neutral. That, of course, could be achieved and, quite clearly, those parts of the system that were supported by way of bounty should be inputs into manufacture. In particular, they should be the inputs necessary for the protection of primary production, which is so essential in the Australian economy. Quite clearly those goods which attract the tariff would be those that could be considered more as luxury items. Maybe, unfortunately, that would include motor cars.

TALK.START.PARA: —You forgot to look at the latest figures.

—I do not know what the honourable member means by 'the latest figures '. I am telling her that there is a massive revenue differential in favour of the collection of tariffs. If she can show me in the Budget Papers that this is not the case I will not buy her a new set of glasses. The fact is that the Government recently fell foul of this situation, admittedly with the aid of the Industries Assistance Commission, when it imposed a 15 per cent duty on a major input into the primary industry sector, the sector that is currently allowing it to strut the stage and claim what a good economic manager it is. Primary industry has had the benefit of some rain and the primary sector has got the Australian economy out of trouble again. However, instead of looking at the grand contribution that that industry makes to Australia and saying that it proposes to protect certain manufacturers within Australia-and I am not saying that I totally oppose that proposition-and consequently pay to those manufacturers a bounty from some of that massive revenue, the Government again took the revenue option and applied a 15 per cent tariff which meant a $14m bill to primary industry-a $14m bill to some people who are making no income at all because they are still in the grip of drought and are faced with other problems. In that regard I must raise the other great concern of the primary industry sector; that is, the fact that the Government now perceives that the tractor manufacturing industry would be much better served by a tariff than a bounty. I sincerely hope that that is not what is going to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: I am now only too pleased to refer to matters relating to dumping. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) clearly defined dumping when he said:

Dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value. Normal value is defined as the price of like goods sold in the ordinary course of trade for consumption in the country of export. Dumping is condemned internationally as unfair trading if it causes, or threatens, material injury to the industry producing like goods in the importing country and a dumping duty, equal to the difference between the export price and the normal value, may be levied on dumped imports.

That is a very clear and concise definition. I do not think many people in Australia or in the international community would support dumping by anybody. It is a distortion. Even some of the more ardent free traders would say that dumping is not a proper practice in the international trading community. I am prepared to support the Minister in his efforts to achieve this, although, like my colleague the honourable member for Moore (Mr Ryan), who has just spoken, I wonder whether human rights are being sufficiently protected when members of the Australian Customs Service are to be given powers that no policeman holds in the pursuit of a criminal. Other than that I believe that the Bill generally does things which are necessary to overcome the problems that presently exist.

However, in my view, additional amendments are needed to address other problems in this area. There have been examples in recent times where what I choose to term the second level of persons affected, very significant sectors of the Australian economy, have had no place in anti-dumping procedures. In his second reading speech, the Minister said:

It is proposed, therefore, to require the Department of Industry and Commerce, in other than exceptional cases, to arrive at a preliminary finding on whether there is a case of injurious dumping or subsidisation within 45 days of accepting a complaint.
Then comes the important part-
The suppliers of the imported goods and the importers as well as the complainants will be given an opportunity to provide information relevant to the complaint within a specified period . . .

All those people are directly affected. The persons not named are people such as farmers who are particularly affected by the results of any anti-dumping decision. In this regard, I would like to give two examples on both sides of the coin. During the time of the Fraser Government a case was put and a complaint lodged by manufacturers of fertiliser in Australia that the fertiliser was being dumped in Australia from the United States of America. The history of this situation was that, irrespective of whether it was being dumped, a number of manufacturers, people with the capacity to manufacture that product in Australia , were not doing so because they found they could import that product from America cheaper and on-sell it to their traditional customers. That is what they were doing. Of course, other people who were not manufacturers of that fertiliser suddenly discovered that they, too, could import that product and started to undercut the manufacturers. Immediately the manufacturers felt that the product was being dumped and lodged the complaint.

The complaint was found to be true although many people, particularly farmer representatives and organisations such as the National Farmers Federation, were producing substantial amounts of evidence to the effect that the product was not being dumped. They were confronted, if I recollect correctly, with an increase in price of that fertiliser of $40 a tonne, but I will stand corrected by the Minister; it is some time since I checked that price. They had a very real interest when one thinks that thousands of tonnes of this fertiliser were being put on farming country every year.

The only people, as the Minister still says, who had a direct role in consultations or in appealing against the decision of the Department of Industry and Commerce were the people to whom I have just referred, the farmers who had to put their hands in their pockets and pull out the money to pay for this situation that, in reality, was a non-entity under the legislation. The situation was that the farmer would be heard but he would not be directly involved in the original discussions and there was no provision in the Act to give him that right. Of course, he was not able to take a proper legal position when an appeal against the Department's decision was made. That is one side of the coin.

Strangely enough, on the other side of the coin, and in somewhat similar circumstances, we find that cheese manufacturers-this relates a lot to the policies of the European Economic Community and its subsidisation of agriculture which I condemn-are able to purchase dumped cheeses and bring them into Australia, slap their labels on them and sell them. This is occurring. Of course , the losers again are the primary producers because the milk which they produce which would normally be used in the manufacture of that cheese is not required. While the manufacturer is profiting from that import, why should he complain about the fact that it is being dumped in Australia. Until he receives competition from an outside source, and in this field that is not so easy because of the brand-name situation and because of the grip that this market has , the loser is the Australian dairy producer. Again, he is not entitled, under the current legislation or under these amendments, to take anti-dumping action. Only the person affected is allowed to do that. The person who is likely to suffer injury under all this legislation is the manufacturer of the product.

Of course everybody overlooks the fact that the actual manufacturing activity, compared with all the input of the original milk produce, is probably the smaller part. The big loser in the Australian economy is the producer of the whole milk who would have it turned into cheese by that manufacturer. That situation is quite wrong and can be quite simply addressed, even at this time, by this Government. Quite clearly a simple amendment is needed that increases the list of those people -the suppliers, the importers and the complainants- mentioned in the Minister's speech. Why cannot we include in the list of complainants and in the list of defendants in the two cases I have given at least primary producers when, as I said earlier today, it is quite clear that those people are again lifting the Australian economy and allowing the Prime Minister and his Ministers to strut the stage of Australia telling the people how this Government's economic policy is working.

There is another reality that I should mention. We have just commenced the era of Hawke-Keating economics. There would not be one economist in the world or even one Government member who would claim that an economy can be turned around in a few months. Gains to date have been principally because of Fraser economics , whether we liked them or not. Anybody who denies that has very little economic sense. That is a reality of national economics. Whatever one does, one cannot turn an Australian economy around in a few months. In fact, no government ever has. I call on the Minister to consider seriously my suggestions. I am sure he would get the support of the Opposition for such an amendment. In fact, the Opposition would congratulate the Government for an additional amendment.

We have already indicated that we support his legislation, with that one exception of his attack on human rights. I hope a speaker on the Government side concerned with that might add weight to the Opposition's concern in that area. We do recognise the problems that the Customs people face in this area; on the other hand, what price are we prepared to pay for an intrusion of that nature? If that intrusion will be only in the area of customs and tariffs-an area where even the benefit to Australia is of great debate-I just do not think it is worth it.

In this area I would much prefer to give that role of entry without warrant to a policeman tracing a drug runner or tracing some of the people we read about who seem to operate in New South Wales in particular. I certainly would not wish to give that power to Customs because it is a peculiarity of many of the policies and laws brought down in Australia that we have some peculiar views of villains. If we look at the mandatory fines imposed on people who operate gambling businesses in competition with government-established gambling businesses, such as totalizator agency boards, we find that the minimum fines involved are much higher that those that apply for some criminal offences, including breaking and entering. I have always doubted the wisdom of that but have accepted the reality of it. In an industry such as starting price betting, for instance, if the penalties are not sufficient operators will pay the money and keep on conducting the business.

Nevertheless, in this case of the Customs Bill we should not extend to the Customs investigator, in his rather commercial role, a right that is denied our police. I trust the Minister will take into consideration the points I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to congratulate you on your election to the position of Deputy Speaker. I also add my support to the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the complementary Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill. The Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, announced on 10 April last year that he had directed the Department of Industry and Commerce urgently to review the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Act and procedures for dealing with the dumping of goods on Australia's domestic marker. This direction was in accordance with the previously announced Government policy. The review has culminated in the introduction of legislation to amend the existing customs tariff anti-dumping legislation we are now discussing.

SPEECH.PARA: The review was very wide ranging, giving the opportunity for many and varied points of view to be put. Those involved included manufacturing and importing industry groups, trade unions and other interested parties. My colleague the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) has already mentioned that 150 submissions were received which canvassed diverse views and proposals. That followed a discussion paper issued by Senator Button's Department of Industry and Commerce. It became obvious that the legislation needed strengthening in order to provide greater protection for Australian industry against dumping, which was becoming more prevalent.

In adding my support to these anti-dumping amendment Bills, I am supporting the commitment of the Government's election platform to strengthen anti-dumping procedures to ensure that goods are not landed in Australia at unrealistically low prices. Our ability to gain increasing benefits from international trade markets is closely aligned with the degree to which the products of Australia's trading partners may compete in the Australian market with the Australian products. There are, all the same, circumstances in which it is necessary to provide appropriate assistance to Australian producers outside normal tariff measures to counter unfair competition. In the sensible parts of the speech of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) he reminded us of the definition of dumping and dumping duty. I was also interested in his suggestion that the consumer should be represented at hearings; for example, the farmer with his fertiliser. I am sure the Minister would be most interested in that proposal, and I hope the honourable member makes it to the Minister.

The countervailing duties imposed to offset the injurious effects of any subsidy, bounty, remission or redirection of freight or other financial assistance which applies to the production, export or carriage of goods imported into Australia are very important, because goods come into Australia which are heavily subsidised by the government of the country of origin, in various ways, so competing with goods that we manufacture which do not receive such assistance from within the country. Those countervailing duties, equal to the amount of subsidy or other assistance received, can be levied and are very important protection for our own production against subsidised goods from other countries.

These measures are taken to ensure that the Government's decisions on the appropriate levels of assistance for Australian industry are not eroded by the unfair pricing practices of exporters of goods to Australia. That these practices are not new is shown by the fact that Australia's anti-dumping legislation dates back to the beginning of this century. In 1906, anti-dumping measures in Australia were originally incorporated in the Australian Industries Preservation Act. Some time later, anti-dumping and countervailing measures were included in the Customs Tariff Act 1921, the Customs Tariff (Dumping and Subsidies) Act 1961 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Act 1975. I remind honourable members of that fact because there is a tendency to imagine that dumping largely has something to do with the increase in trade from our Pacific neighbours instead of being historically something about which we have always had to be concerned. Our international rights and obligations in respect of anti -dumping and countervailing action are governed by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the relevant agreements negotiated in 1979. In recent years anti-dumping complaints have risen considerably and it has been claimed by various sectors of Australian industry that the current law does not provide effective control against dumped imports.

Central to the thrust of these amendments is the welfare of Australian industry . For too long dumping has been allowed to escalate at a rapid rate, which has to be seen as a trend causing undue harm to Australian industry. Justice is being brought to bear on importers and, unlike the previous Government which muddled on for many years with the old system, this Government is attempting through this legislation to protect manufacturers from the most unfair effects of dumped goods on the local market. I know it is of great concern to a number of manufacturers in my electorate that they have in the past suffered this unfair competition from dumped goods. Whilst I am appreciative of the efforts of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) to increase interest in small business, I suggest that protection of our industry against unfair trade practices is infinitely more useful to small business than the naming of a year of small business, which is probably typical of what went on before this Government came to power. Then one could give things a label and say something had been done.

Looking back to the 1960s and 1970s, the dumping of goods on the local market was not as great a problem as it is today. World trade was expanding and the tendency to dump was not an issue for Australian industry to have to cope with, as it is today. Dumping tends to occur more readily during times of international recession and due to this fact has become a pressing issue during the 1980s. In 1981 the incidence of dumping rose considerably and the problem is clearly reflected in the number of dumping complaints put forward during that period.

The Government realises that speed is of the essence to effective anti-dumping and countervailing action. Complaints have to be dealt with in a quick, efficient and accurate manner because industry may be damaged if the process is convoluted and lengthy. For example, in 1982 it took up to one year to deal with a dumping complaint. We know that small businesses can go to the wall in that time if they have to wait for some correction to be made to unfair practices which threaten them. That has produced the result whereby in some cases the fear of delay in dealing with hearings of dumping complaints actually can prevent a company from manufacturing a new item because it fears that the item will have to compete with a similar, dumped item, and it will be in diabolical trouble before it can get any reasonable action.

Because of that the Government believes that by streamlining procedures the new administrative processes for dealing with complaints will be of great benefit to our local manufacturing industry. The Department of Industry and Commerce will be asked in cases, other than exceptional cases, to produce within 45 days a preliminary finding as to whether a case of injurious dumping or subsidisation stands. I think we would all agree that 45 days is a deal better than 365 days. All parties concerned-the suppliers of the imported goods, the importers as well as the complainants, the manufacturers that is-will be given a chance to provide information within a specified period of approximately 30 days. To simplify the whole process, questionnaires will be allocated to all interested groups.

If, after these preliminary inquiries, a case of injurious dumping or subsidisation is determined, the Department of Industry and Commerce will be required to further investigate the complaint and to complete this inquiry within 120 days, this being the normal period of validity of provisional security action. It should be understood that the time limits mentioned above apply to normal complaints and remain flexible to deal with cases which require speedier preliminary findings or a more complicated case which may enforce a more lengthy investigation.

The effect of these administrative changes will be to put more pressure on Australian manufacturers to substantiate complaints and to give importers earlier access to the full nature of the allegations. The Department of Industry and Commerce is also seeking to increase the size of the dumping division and to appoint an extra senior officer. This will enable one assistant secretary to concentrate on day to day affairs and another to work on the more long term perspective. Stress on visibility is reflected in the new administrative changes , especially in reference to the preliminary finding of the Department of Industry and Commerce.

It is the Government's belief that these administrative initiatives will strengthen significantly the procedures for dealing with complaints of dumping and subsidisation while at the same time ensuring that suppliers and importers from overseas are given every opportunity to provide information and submit counter arguments against any allegations of unfair trading practices. These initiatives are based on the principle of a fair and equitable input from all parties concerned in a particular complaint.

The Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides some clarification of the status of the various people concerned and definition of some relevant matters. Clause 3 proposes to align the definition of the business association in section 4 of the principal Act with that of related persons in section 154 of the Customs Act 1901. I think that is an important definition. Clause 4 amends section 4A of the principal Act to enable the Minister to deal with sales dumping arrangements, that is, hidden dumping, irrespective of whether the parties are associates. The invoiced export price between associates may be acceptable to the Minister if the prices are in relation to purchases in arm's length transactions. I could go on to discuss a number of these clauses in some detail, but I believe we will have an opportunity to deal with them in some detail at the Committee stage.

The anti-dumping legislation provides an opportunity for the Industries Assistance Commission to review dumping and countervailing decisions. The Government is of the view that such reviews should be confined to the facts of the particular case and that, as the question in issue is one relating to unfair trading practices and is not an industry assistance matter, the policy guidelines of the AIC will not apply as they are not relevant. It is with a feeling of real concern for Australia's industry that I support the initiatives contained in this anti-dumping legislative package. Australia's industry should not have to cope with unfair trade practices. It is the intention of this Labor Government that every assistance be extended to our domestic industry, including that of the customs tariff anti-dumping legislation. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to draw the attention of the House to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill which are currently before the House and to endorse the sentiments expressed by my colleagues the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). May I say how much I agree with the desire implicit in the legislation to prevent unnecessary dumping and how much I regret that non- tariff barriers are growing throughout the world. In the time available I want to reflect on the impact on farming and fruit growing areas of dumping allegedly taking place in Australia at present. I want to focus my observations not only on what is happening in the United Kingdom and the European Economic Community but also on the impact of subsidised production from Brazil and South Africa on the products that particularly affect the seat of Wakefield.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1970s the Common Agricultural Policy, which was endorsed by the EEC and embraced by the United Kingdom, reduced the export of Australian products, particularly canned fruit, apples and pears, into the United Kingdom. That Common Agricultural Policy made it more difficult for primary producers in Australia to export into Third World nations, but primary producers seemed to be able to cope with these dilemmas. When we found that the CAP and other policies across the world were involving the dumping of agricultural produce in Australia , it was time to call a halt and look again at our anti-dumping procedures. While we have butter mountains and wine lakes posing a real threat to our horticultural produce, we have to acknowledge that it is not only horticultural products but also dairy products, beef and lamb that are directly affected by the present accessibility of the Australian market to subsidised overseas competition.

In making these remarks to the House I am not supporting inefficient Australian producers. The producers I purport to represent in these remarks are producers of products with a high labour content, producers involved in intensive agriculture and producers more accutely affected by Australia's labour costs than many other primary producers. What is exclusive and unique about horticultural and intensive agricultural industries is that some years pass between planting and production. There are long lead times. The grower, in putting produce into the ground, has to anticipate markets that might well be a decade away.

In the light of that sort of investment by individual growers, we on this side of the House welcome the purpose of this legislation which is to accelerate anti -dumping procedures and provide a more rapid track technique for growers and primary producers who believe their produce is being affected by dumped subsidised produce from overseas. As the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) has pointed out, the legislation will require the Department of Industry and Commerce to hand down a preliminary finding on a dumping allegation within 45 days and complete the investigation within 120 days.

Because of the impact of subsidised EEC production, horticultural exports into the United Kingdom all but ceased during the 1970s. In fact, the export of canned peaches into the United Kingdom fell from 90,000 tonnes to 27,000 tonnes. The export of canned apricots from Australia to the United Kingdom fell from 8, 000 tonnes to 1,000 tonnes. The export of apples into the United Kingdom fell from 126,000 tonnes to 42,000 tonnes.

The thrust of the legislation is not only to deal with the dilemma that the EEC has posed to Australian producers in falling exports but also to protect Australian producers from the dumping of subsidised products that principally have come out of the EEC. One classic example of the dumping of subsidised EEC production in Australia that has just been brought to mind-it is coincidental to the emergence of this legislation in the House-is the dumping of French brandy. Australian Customs Notice No. 84/37, which was handed down on 23 February, agreed that a prima facie case has been brought by the chief executive of the consolidated co-operative producers in the Riverland area of South Australia on behalf of the Australian brandy distillers group against French brandy being dumped into Australia. As a result of that case the importers are now required to lodge a security of 16.33 French francs for every litre of alcohol in brandy dumped in Australia. This figure effectively converts to 90c a bottle, or approximately $2 in Australian terms per litre of alcohol. It is very timely that these Bills should come before the House just as this decision has been made in favour of the consolidated co-operative group.

This legislation will require the Department of Industry and Commerce to hand down a decision on this issue within 120 days. This may well be a very optimistic note for what has been, for at least 12 months-as honourable members would know-a very pessimistic industry. I wish to incorporate in Hansard a table which indicates the fall in brandy production in Australia as a result of the import of whiskies.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — As the paper you wish to put in Hansard comes within the guidelines set down by Mr Speaker, leave is granted.
