TALK.START.PARA: —A glance at that table will show that in the nine years from 1974-75 to 1982-83 whisky imports increased from 54.45 per cent to 70.71 per cent, up by 16.25 per cent. Australian brandy's share of the market decreased from 29.23 per cent to 19.95 per cent, down 9.28 per cent, and that of Australian whisky decreased from 9.31 per cent to 2.52 per cent, down 6.79 per cent. Since 1978-79 brandy imports increased from 2.68 per cent to 6.82 per cent, up 4.14 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to believe that this can be done in a price market when the EEC spirits have to be carted half way around the world. When we consider that the French cost of production is very much like the Australian cost of production we can understand why the industry in Australia was very suspicious that dumping was occurring and just how timely this anti-dumping legislation is. The table also refers to whisky production in Australia and, because of the impact on whisky and brandy production, I have this day written to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) requesting that he extend the Customs inquiry into the dumping of French brandy to include concurrently an inquiry into the dumping of EEC whisky.

It is not just the brandy industry or the wine industry in the electorate of Wakefield that I seek to represent in these comments before the House. The dried vine fruits industry, which is currently in production in the electorate of Wakefield-and the producers will be working for less than the basic wage-faces a real threat from EEC Greek and Spanish production. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is well aware, the dried tree fruit industry faces a similar threat from the importation of South African fruit into Australia. So this Bill facilitates the opportunities that both industries will have to bring the unfair trading practice to the attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

In my concluding remarks I would like to bring to the notice of the Minister one or two other matters that I think might be amended as the Bill proceeds through the House. I ask the Minister to consider a couple of matters. Firstly, if the goods on which the anti-dumping tariff is being paid are re-exportable from Australia, will the Government rebate the duty paid to the exporter? Secondly-this point has largely been taken up by the honourable member for O' Connor (Mr Tuckey)-does the Government agree that the anti-dumping tariff, I emphasise the word 'tariff', mean that the importer will raise his selling price by the amount of the duty and will no longer be accused of dumping? Of course there will not then be any revenue to the Government and as a result the consumer will be required to pay more. Might he not then, in the sentiments expressed by the honourable member for O'Connor, give due regard to a bounty rather than a tariff, as applied in the steel industry? The third point, which has also been touched on by the honourable member for O'Connor, is the need to expand the area of appeal to include not only processors but also producers. Madam Deputy Speaker, I thank you for your consideration in allowing me to address the House on these points. If the Minister is prepared to consider these constructive additions I would be happy to commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, allow me first to congratulate you on your elevation to the high office of Chairman of Committees and thank you for giving me the call to address the House on this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill is a timely piece of legislation which reflects the Government's commitment to the electorate to strengthen anti-dumping measures, thus defending our manufacturing industry. The legislation before us has the effect of improving anti-dumping and countervailing procedures. I for one welcome, and believe that the Australian manufacturing industry also welcomes, the provisions of this Bill, although I would have preferred much more stringent and comprehensive measures to protect our manufacturing industry and through that to save the jobs of many Australians .

The anti-dumping Bill is especially welcome as it has been introduced at a time when Australia is fast becoming the dumping ground of cheaply produced goods by transitional capital. The speaker before me, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), mentioned the importation of agricultural products into this country. I congratulate him on opposing it in the interest of his electors. However, at the same time many honourable members opposite are propagating the unlimited importation of manufactured goods, which will harm our manufacturing industry-an industry that employs hundreds of thousands of Australians.

For instance, if I needed an ordinary fan-belt for my car today and I went to a garage to buy it, it would sell me one that is made in Korea. If I needed an air -conditioning belt I would be sold one made in the United States of America or Canada, as though this country is unable to produce something as simple as a fan -belt or an air-conditioning belt. The production of the new $1 coins overseas is another story and to some extent it made a farce of our Government's 'Buy Australian-made' publicity program.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you will remember last year's Australia Day celebration when the country was flooded with Australian flags made in Taiwan. I am glad to report that this year Carroll and Richardson Pty Ltd of Blackburn, manufacturers of Australian flags and such produce, produced an Australian flag which is much better in quality and which was widely used. I display one proudly on my desk, not only because it is the Australian flag but also because it is one that is produced in this country.

I have a circular issued by a company in Taiwan offering steel-wire and tubing products. It is signed by the manager, Rocky Chou. Among the illustrated items is a garden chair made from steel tubing and flat wires. It is offered f.o.b. Taiwan for $US5.30. A local manufacturer brought one of the chairs to me to show me. He told me that to produce the same chair here would cost him $15. But, of course, by the time a firm can prove the dumping Rocky Chou has made a handsome profit, the importer has made a handsome profit and the manufacturer in my electorate is forced to reduce his work force because his product is forced out of demand.

Only recently I wrote to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button ) requesting temporary assistance for a company named Pyrox Pty Ltd, our main domestic manufacturer of space heaters, which is being squeezed out of the market by imports from Japan. I pointed out that some of the gas heaters imported from Japan sell here cheaper than in Tokyo. I have visted Pyrox and spoken to the workers there as well as the manager. I found that the workers, many of whom have been employed there for a number of years, are dedicated to the company. Pyrox, which is Australian-owned, is doing everything to produce both cheaply and efficiently. However, no matter how good and diligent the Australian workers are, no matter how good the Australian management is, they cannot compete with dumping and unfair practices.

I have just one more illustration of the penetration of foreign made goods. My biro, which was sent by Sir Billy Snedden to members of the House of Representatives, was made in Italy. They are still being sent to us, I regret to say, by the current Speaker. Evidently Sir Billy must have purchased a great quantity of Italian made biros to present to the members of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought he gave them to us out of his own pocket.
—I do not know whether he paid for them. If it was from his pocket, he probably got some cheap dumped products.
—Do we make biros?
—If we continue to import foreign goods, we will lose our ability to manufacture anything, including brandy.
—I just asked: Do we make biros in Australia?

—We did make biros but our manufacturers were forced out of the market by the importation of foreign goods. We used to make thongs in Western Australia . The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) ought to know; he comes from that part of the country. The manufacturer who made ordinary thongs was forced out of the market because of cheap imports from Taiwan. That is what I am talking about. Opposition members have no concern for the workers who lost their jobs because of the imports freely allowed into this country. I assure the House that the biro concerned is somewhat inferior to biros made here, at least to the extent that we cannot get a refill for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the pessimism that was just displayed by the honourable member for O 'Connor, this non-belief in the ability of the Australian worker to produce goods for our own needs, is fostered by the conservatives, not by accident but by design. They have set out to denigrate our industry and shake our belief in ourselves. They advocate reliance on imports. This advocacy is dangerous because it turns Australia into an international dumping ground for products manufactured by transnational companies which results in millions of dollars of profits to foreign manufacturers. However, at the same time this advocacy of reliance on foreign goods ensures continuous unemployment of hundreds of thousands of Australian workers.

This advocacy of our own impotence is dangerous because it supplements the strategy of the new corporate world economic order according to which Australia has a role of supplier of raw materials and agricultural produce. There is no place for Australian manufacturing industry in the global economic strategy plan of the transnationals.

The dismantling of the Australian manufacturing industry has already begun and it has a traumatic effect on our employment at present, as well as employment opportunities in the future. The de-industrialisation of Australia that ensures millions of extra profits to international capital is promoted by the traditional free trade lobby of importers and exporters and the big rural interests. Lately, they have been joined by the mining interests, largely foreign owned.

The promoters of free trade, the strategists of the world interdependence, the fetishists of free market forces, are becoming more and more numerous. With the zeal of religious converts they are advocating the dismantling of some sections of our manufacturing industries and the restructuring of others to serve the interests of international capital. They are following in the footsteps of Henry Kissinger, former United States of America Secretary of State who has now become an adviser to transnational corporations. He visited Australia late last year and delivered a strong attack on policies which would protect national industries against the inroads of trans- national corporations.

One of the latest outbursts came from Hugh Matheson Morgan, Executive Director of Western Mining Corporation Ltd, a director of Alcoa of Australia Ltd and the Australian Industries Development Association who, according to the Melbourne Age of 19 January 1983, warned a business audience at the Savoy Hotel in London that 'high Keynesians' were waiting to incite rebellion in the Hawke Government. Mr Morgan identified these Keynesians as including senior and junior Federal Ministers, the Victorian Government and the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research at Melbourne University. He attacked all and sundry from the socialist Left to the cost of living adjustment and preached in general the old saga of tight monetary control and free trade. Mr Morgan's advocacy of tight monetary policies, low government spending and low wages will not resolve our problems. We have seen seven years of Fraserism and all that it resulted in was more and more Australians out of work.

Mr Morgan, the Executive Director of Sir Arvi Parbo's outfit and a director of Alcoa, represents well the exporting interests of mining companies but he certainly does not represent the interests of Australian wage and salary earners , many of whom would join the reserve army of unemployed if Mr Morgan's advice were accepted. He chose London, thousands of miles from our shores, to attack those who identify with the aspirations and interests of ordinary working Australians. Such an outburst and attack against economic nationalism was to be expected as a new ideology to justify export oriented global production strategies, created to serve the increasing transnationalisation of production. Trade barriers and restrictions on the movement of capital and goods interfere with the global plans of transnationals and they want to stop them.

A whole new school of free trade economists is being employed to preach the interests of multinational capital. These economists invent various glasshouse models to explain the past and to forecast the future. But while they play with their Orani models, they forget about the human element. They forget about this nation which the economy should serve. They talk about rationalisation of our industry which means that, if an industry cannot compete with cheap off-shore industrial products produced and imported by multinationals, such industries should go to the wall. From such advocacy it is obvious that the expansion of the capitalist world economy in the second half of this century has managed without the actual involvement of the domestic bourgeoisie, or at least without its capital. They, like many conservative gentlemen opposite, are only the compradors, the domestic agents for the transnational interests, and so is Mr Morgan, who is telling us from London what we should do.

Considering all this, the Bill before us today-a Bill which will offer a much better measure of protection to our industries against dumping and unfair trade practices-seems to be only a small and somewhat less important measure, especially if we take into account the problems besetting our domestic manufacturing industry which is under attack by powerful foreign controlled transnational corporations.

The international restructuring of production undertaken by the transnationals is particularly harmful to Australian manufacturing industry. The de- industrialisation of Australia is proceeding according to their plans. This de- industrialisation process is taking place partly through the movement of Australian based companies off-shore to cheap wage countries. Such a process is dictated by the logic of forces of competition advocated by the free traders. It is obvious that companies producing in Australia, paying Australian award wages which are 10 times higher than the subsidiaries of some companies are paying in, say, the Philippines or Malaysia, cannot compete with overseas production. Such companies, unless they are given increased protection and assistance, cannot survive and they will be forced to close their operations here in Australia and to re-open somewhere in Taiwan or the Philippines, employing cheap labour. Such are the effects of so-called free trade whereby transitionals are given the freedom to disregard our national interests and bankrupt our domestic industries by flooding our markets with foreign products.

The latest of such moves to replace domestic production with imports is in the field of electronics, or what remains of it. The proposed reduction of tariffs on large screen colour televisions and the discontinuation of voluntary export restraint in the report of the Industries Assistance Commission will certainly have the effect of dismantling our television industry and component manufacturing industry. The production of small television sets stopped long ago as imports forced our manufacturers out of the market.

The IAC proposals, if accepted by the Government, will force the manufacturers of large colour televisions, 20 inches and over, to sack their work force and stop the production and assembling of such sets in Australia. One of the manufacturers, Philips Industries Holdings Ltd, is in my electorate. I fear what will happen to the hundreds of workers who might lose their jobs because of the pressure put on the Government by the free traders. According to the proponents of free trade, if protection is lifted, capital will leave the inefficient, non- profitable industries and be reinvested in so-called sunrise industries which are more profitable. Alternatively, those industries can pull up their socks, invest more and become more efficient. That could be so in some airy-fairy free market world or in the woolly heads of some economists.

What is in fact happening in my electorate is that once a factory is closed and capital moves out, the workers are sacked and no other factory opens up. If a manufacturer is forced out of business he does not necessarily invest in something more profitable such as high technology industries. Most manufacturers have told me that they will be forced to turn into importers, importing goods from offshore countries. For example, Philips will not go out of business. It will reduce its work force, use its warehouses and retail outlets to sell imported products from its parent factory in Singapore where it can produce the goods more cheaply. Alternatively, it can move into another country where mass production techniques can also produce goods more cheaply. The result of freely allowing foreign goods to be dumpted on us will be that our work force will remain unemployed for a long time.

Even more highly trained people, for example, engineers and technicians, will be forced out of the industry. Not only will they be unable to find employment in this country, they will have to go overseas if they want to practice their professions. There is not much remaining of our electronic industries; there will be less if this television industry is forced to go to the wall and import the sets. In the future we will lose our ability not only to produce a biro, which we may have lost already, but also to put a television set together. I wonder how that will affect our ability to defend ourselves and this continent in the future should the need arise.

Time will not allow me to bring up more matters regarding these Bills and the protection of and assistance to our industries in general. I represent an electorate with over 2,000 industrial undertakings, mainly small businesses. These businesses, if not in every case, are very often Australian-owned and work with Australian capital. I am concerned about what will happen to thousands of Australian workers if we do not stop the dumping of imported goods into this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anti-dumping legislation is necessary for any country in order to ensure and protect fair trading. It is part of any country's protection policy. I will not make general reference to the customs tariff anti- dumping legislation; I want to highlight several specific problems. The weaknesses that I have highlighted before in this Parliament, I believe, still continue with this legislation. The legislation concerning dumping does not allow, require or enforce fair trading in certain situations. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) raised part of the problem when he mentioned dairy farmers and dumped cheese. I will be very pleased if the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown) can tell me that this legislation actually corrects the position.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem, as I understand it, is that the definition of the industry or the injured party which is allowed to lodge the formal complaint upon which the Department of Industry and Commerce makes its initial inquiries to see whether the potential for dumping exists is too narrow. As I said, I have raised the problem before in the Parliament with the previous Government. At that stage I was told that when amendments to the customs tariff anti-dumping legislation were being considered this problem would be taken into account. If my understanding that it has not been considered or included in this legislation is correct, I am disappointed. I say sincerely to the Minister that I hope he will consider including provision for the problem in the legislation before it goes to the Senate. It is a sincere complaint, one I had raised with the previous Government. I will be complimenting the Government for some legislation it will bring on later in the next week or two. In that instance it has listened to people in the pear industry who for years have been asking for a differential levy in relation to pears for distillation. I will commend the Government for listening on that occasion to something that I have been saying was not right for some time.

The examples I will use relate to agriculture, as it affects my electorate and I understand it better. However, my comments could also be applied to manufactured products. The producer of the product, whether a dairy farmer, a grower of tomatoes, a vegetable or fruit producer, or a grape grower-in other words, the producer of the unprocessed product or commodity-is not classed as the industry when it comes to dumped imports. It has to be the cheese manufacturer, the tomato canner, the vegetable canner or the wine producer. The honourable member for O'Connor gave the example of the dairy farmers as represented by the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation not being able to make complaints on imported cheese from Europe. The cheese manufacturers had to make the complaint, even though the Dairy Farmers Federation did most of the work for the cheese manufacturers when they finally made the complaint.

The honourable member for O'Connor also mentioned the case of some companies in Australia which were also represented in the European Economic Community. It suited them nicely to import goods rather than to manufacture them here. There was the case of a company established in, I think, Tasmania which was to produce certain types of cheese in Australia but which found it was more profitable to import the dumped product from its parent company in France.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I welcome the comment that that was correct. There was also the case of an Australian company that used to make blue vein cheese. This point relates to material injury. The industry as a whole, rather than a small component of it , has to be shown to be materially injured in some way by the dumped imported product. This particular manufacturer, the only manufacturer of blue vein cheese at that time in Australia, finally stopped production of blue vein cheech because of dumped product. But when it tried to compain it was told: 'You can't really complain because you are no longer manufacturing a product. How can that be of material injury to the industry generally? Your total production, even if you were in full production, would be so small for the total industry that it can't be considered by itself'. However, I commend the Department for the action that has been taken against dumped imported cheese from the EEC because the present arrangement is far more satisfactory than before. There is a better understanding between the industry and the Department as to how to proceed in the future. I certainly commend the action that has been taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Another example is that of tomatoes. Some of the canners, including co- operative companies to my disappointment, both import and produce canned tomatoes in various forms in this country. Under the EEC's common agricultural policy, tomato product from Mediterranean countries has been brought into Australia. In my view, by definition, it has been clearly dumped. They have been frustrated in that. There was the additional complication-I may have it the wrong way round-that if it was tomato pulp the growers were considered to be close enough to the pulp to be considered the industry; if it was paste it was considered that the growers were further down the line in the manufacturing process and could not be considered. It seems to me a rather absurd definition if the people who actually produce the product, those who are affected by the dumped imported product, are not able to appear as the formal complainants.

We have a problem with canned vegetables as a result of the closer economic relations policy with New Zealand. Generally, as a result of various takeovers which have taken place, basically the same companies operate in both New Zealand and Australia. Because of special financial assistance provided by the New Zealand Government for exports, it generally suits companies to can products in New Zealand and act as importers in Australia. Therefore the canners will not lodge a complaint in Australia because they are doing very nicely as a result of the joint ownership arrangements in New Zealand. One case a few years ago involved an Australian canner of a vegetable product who was threatened by the supermarket chains which were importing this product from New Zealand. He was told that if he were to lodge a formal complaint they would not give him any shelf space for his product in their supermarkets. That is the sort of problem that arises. I put sincerely to the Minister and the Government that if the right to lodge a formal complaint has not been covered in the amendments the Bills should be looked at again before they go to the Senate.

Another point I wish to make indicates the delicate balance that has to be maintained by governments and departments in legislating and applying regulations for fair trade and reasonable protection. I refer to the question of by-law admission for a new product whereby a person may lodge a complaint against a product being admitted without duty on the grounds that that product is being made in Australia or, more particularly, could be made in Australia and that it is the intention of a manufacturer to make it. Some protection should exist to stop a predatory operator overseas killing any hope of production in Australia.

I will cite two examples of events which occurred in the area I represent and the industries I have represented. One case related to liquid nitrogen containers for the artificial animal breeding industry. The more recent case, the example I wish to concentrate on, involved agricultural lasers. Agricultural laser technique is revolutionising land layout in irrigation areas in Australia and the reclamation of badly drained and salt affected irrigation areas. I believe that agricultural land lasering, with the necessary government tax incentives to encourage farmers to utilise it, will do more than any other government program or expenditure to solve the problems of irrigation drainage and salinity along the Murray Valley and elsewhere in Australia.

When it came to the point of importing agricultural lasers from overseas, one company in Australia said it intended to produce them. It was already producing building lasers, and producing them very well. Because that company kept saying it intended to produce agricultural lasers, by-law admission was not granted. It was my view and the view of those who were importing, using and anxious to use the lasers in primary industry in Australia that that company was not genuine; that it did not intend to produce them. I wish to commend the previous Minister, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who listened to those arguments but gave by-law admission for the importation of agricultural lasers for a limited period. He recognised that the argument of intention to manufacture can be used by some to frustrate the importation of a product which should be imported rather than be used to protect someone who is trying to establish a market for that product in Australia against predatory imports. When the Minister speaks in reply, I do not expect any response about the by-law arrangement. I merely meant to comment on it. In regard to the definition of 'industry affected', I know that the honourable member for O'Connor and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and I would all be interested if that point could be explained to us .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an old Chinese proverb which says: 'Fuel is not sold in the forest nor fish in the lake'. That is no longer true. European cheese is sold in the quality dairy producing Bega Valley and foreign fish has been sold in Eden, both at prices cheaper than the farmer is paid for the raw material in the country of origin. The Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr John Brown), in his second reading speech on the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill, reminded the House that the Government's election platform included a commitment to strengthen anti-dumping procedures to ensure that goods are not landed in Australia at unrealistically low prices. A wide-ranging review of the legislation was announced on 10 April 1983. I hope that the provisions in this legislation embrace cheese and fish. If it does not, I certainly support a call for an inclusion of those items.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that the code to which we are a signatory relates to people who pack cans of products in Australia. Apparently they can object to the importation of similar products, but the producer cannot. Therefore there is some complications if a producer wishes to object to the importation of cheese and fish. I believe that the Government needs to look at that problem. Many materials other than cheese and fish have been dumped on the Australian market. Honourable members who have spoken in this debate have mentioned strawberries, eggs, light globes, brandy, whisky, Australian flags, fan belts and biros. Sometimes there are instances of actual dumping. Other cases, I would imagine, could be regarded as approximations to dumping.

The honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) has pointed out the increasing incidence of dumping since the 1960s and 1970s. As the honourable member for O' Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the Minister have said, dumping occurs when the products of one country are exported to another country at less than their normal value. 'Normal value' means the price of like goods sold in the ordinary course of trade for consumption in the country of origin. To date, successive governments in Australia have had about as much effect on the European Economic Community's dumping programs as the chook which said to the horse: 'Let's agree not to step on each other's feet'. This Government does not accept the continuation of that relationship. Within 45 days-not a year, as often happened before-of accepting a complaint of dumping the Department of Industry and Commerce will now be required to arrive at a preliminary finding as to whether there is a case of injurious dumping, and an investigation will follow. The Government also proposes to discourage hidden dumping. When it comes to trade, even our friends have to be treated as strangers. When parties agree to an export price above the normal value and then share the profit on the export sale, that is agreeing to hidden dumping. The Minister will now be able to determine the export price.

Under another provision the Minister may determine the amount of duty on goods which have been dumped to be a sum sufficient to prevent injury to the relevant industry. Another example is freight dumping-a reduction in freight costs to allow a lower price in Australia. Again, action can be taken against any activity which threatens an Australian industry in this way. The associated Bill , the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Miscellaneous Amendments Bill, allows investigation of practices such as secret rebates and package deals which are part of hidden dumping schemes between parties to import transactions.

Few people will envy governments of countries like France, which has militant farmers not prepared to lose their position in the economy and who determine that where there are inefficiencies their market will still be maintained, using the useful shield of the European Economic Community. Therefore the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is to be congratulated on his recent discussions with European countries. The agreements reached should reduce some dumping, without the need for the sort of legal confrontation which we are talking about now. The Departments of Primary Industry and Industry and Commerce have also reached a better understanding with the primary and manufacturing industries of Australia.

Many people on both sides have made a useful contribution to the tariff debate. On the side against tariffs we have had contributions from such people as Bert Kelly, who formerly represented the electorate of Wakefield. There is much merit in their argument that protection is of no real value to a country or the world, but that is if the world itself is a free market world. But when it comes to dumping there is no alternative to the taking of protective measures in the form of the Government's anti-dumping amendments. If the world market were free we could indulge in the luxury of having no protection. It is not a free market while other governments sell their products overseas below cost because their farming or other industries are inefficient. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

I would like to comment on some of the contributions to the debate that have been made by honourable members. I suggest that this legislation is long overdue . The previous Government had been fiddling with it for a long time and had been unable to bring it to a conclusion. The Bill was introduced in the last session and has laid on the table for a long time. Industry has not responded to any great extent to its provisions, which rather satisfies the Government that it has covered most of the contingencies that need attention. Certainly, prior to the introduction of this legislation we had problems with dumping. This has been one of the best debates I have heard for a long time. Honourable members have offered reasoned, intelligent and constructive contributions. I note that as a very pleasant change because I have been discouraged that Bills of this type, of great importance to Australian industry, have been largely ignored on both sides . Often in the last Parliament, when I was Opposition spokesman on the subject, I would find myself the only Opposition speaker and the responsible Minister the only Government speaker. I am pleased that all members of the Parliament are taking a more active interest in the protection of Australian industry and, as well, our obligations under international codes.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who is the Opposition spokeman for Industry and Commerce in this House and formerly held that portfolio, raised a couple of subjects on which I would like to comment. The first concerned freight dumping. He mentioned the very real difficulties faced in considering the problem of freight dumping, whereby goods are landed in Australia at a freight rate which appears, superficially, to be well below the proper rate. The honourable gentleman asked exactly what the Government proposed to do to counter freight dumping. The existing legislation enables countervailing duty to be imposed in cases of reductions or remissions of freight-for instance, when goods exported are shipped freight free, or the amount paid is less than what is essentially recognised as the ruling rate.

The Government, during its review of this legislation, examined a request that the anti-dumping legislation be amended so as to enable the application of dumping duties in cases where the freight charged was less than, for example, for the liner trade, the published scheduled rates, discounted to the extent freely available or, in respect of the charter trade, the rate that would recover all costs including leasing charges plus a reasonable profit for the charterer. The Government does not consider that anti-dumping action should apply where those cheaper freight rates are available in an open, competitive market. The fact is that at the moment shipping rates in the market vary considerably. Where cheap freight rates are generally available across a whole spectrum of opportunities it would be not only impossible but also unwise for the Government to apply dumping duties if someone took advantage of those rates. The Government believes that the existing countervailing provisions are sufficient. In fact, it has decided to make no alteration in this area.

The normal avenue of seeking assistance through a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission or the Temporary Assistance Authority would be open to an industry which faced difficulties due to low freight cost imports, where such freights were in fact not subsidised. Where it was quite evident that the government of another country was subsidising freight rates a countervailing duty should be applied, but that is not the case in every situation and it would be unwise of us to make sweeping legislative changes that would reduce the possibility of industries taking advantage of cheap freight rates that could be available.

The honourable member for Ryan also made reference to the lack of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and an amendment that the Opposition intends to move in the other place relating to what it believes to be a diminution of civil liberties in the case of the powers for Customs officers, especially where searches are made for documents in offices in cases where a warrant has been issued. Dumping is a complicated matter. In order to establish a dumping case a lot of interlocking decisions have to me made. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) will be asking the Attorney-General to refer to the Administrative Review Council the matter of appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, so that matter is in hand.

The use of judicial warrants to seek information about a dumping complaint, either directly from a person or from records, is not appropriate in pursuing the investigation of a customs offence. The Government believes that judicial warrants are neither applicable, justifiable nor appropriate in an anti-dumping case. The Customs authorisations to be issued under new section 214B of the Customs Act for the investigation of dumping relate to very necessary inquiry as to whether in fact the prices of an export have been artificially reduced. The Government believes that, having in mind the damage that can be done to Australian industry, open access should be available to a Customs officer to enter premises and obtain records without the need for judicial warrant to be issued. This is done in trade practices cases and we cannot see that it is any different to provide the same power of investigation to Customs officers concerning something that could be very injurious to Australian industry. When the Opposition's amendment is lodged in the Senate the Government will be able to answer fully any fears that the Opposition might have that civil liberties are being impinged upon.

My colleague the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) made a very valuable contribution to the debate. It is very obvious that he has a good knowledge of this whole area of tariffs, duties and dumping complaints. He pointed up the responsibility that Australia has international agreements to observe the full spirit of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade without necessarily reducing its responsibility to protect its own industries. The honourable member made a very good point when he mentioned that now that the steel plan is in operation there is a public perception that the protection afforded Australian industry is open to audit by the Government. So it should be , because I do not think that anyone on either side of the House would suggest that inefficient industries should be afforded protection in an unfettered, unaudited fashion. Rather, protection provided by government should always be open to public inspection. I thank the honourable member for his contribution.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) brought up a number of interesting points. I must point out one thing to him. I do not think he quite understands-if he did, he certainly did not espouse it-that tariffs are not imposed for the collection of revenue but for the protection of Australian industries. As long as that is done in a calculated and sensible fashion that is open to public inspection, I do not think anyone should suggest that the tariff barriers that we have in place in Australia should be completely dismantled. I am sure that is not what he meant but it was one of the impressions I gained.

The honourable member mentioned that the Government was moving to remove the bounties from the production of Australian tractors and moving towards a tariff situation. I can tell him that that decision has not been made as yet. I do not know whether it is going to be made. A preliminary report from the Industries Assistance Commission that was handed to the Government some time back in fact suggested that line of activity. But the Minister for Industry and Commerce has not yet made a decision on that matter. I am in no position to anticipate what decision he will make. Maybe the honourable member for O'Connor is prescient; maybe he is not. Time will tell.

I was surprised to find that the honourable member for O'Connor raised the subject of cheese because I thought we had answered this question quite competently in terms of the decision that was made about the imports of cheese. I am sure he appreciates that the Government acted very promptly in that area. I know that the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) made reference to that fact. I thank the honourable member for O'Connor for his usual challenging contribution. I am sure that some of the points he made will be taken into account by the Department of Industry and Commerce in the administration of this legislation.

The honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) made some references to the attempt by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) to have 1984 declared the year of small business. She pointed out that perhaps the dumping legislation that is now before the House will do more to assist small business in Australia than the implementation of slogans and gimmicks will ever do. I think that is exactly correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you got on your tie?

—No, it is not a koala. It is some kind of little animal. Given the onslaught on small business that was made by the previous Government of which the honourable member for Higgins was a member, when precious little was done to assist small business in terms of finance or protection and in view of the extraordinary number of bankruptcies that occurred in that area in the last year, I think it is true to say that if the previous Government had been in power for much longer we would not be discussing small business; we would be discussing minuscule business. Therefore I support the honourable member for Chisholm's view that the dumping legislation that is now before the House will do more to help the competitiveness and the profitability of Australian industry than any attempt to introduce gimmicks or names.

SPEECH.PARA: The next contribution to which I would like to refer is that of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) who raised some interesting points which I would like to answer. First of all he spoke about imports of brandy from France. I am pleased to be able to inform him, if he did not quite understand the position, that on 23 February the Department issued an Australian Customs Notice advising an affirmative preliminary finding on the subsidisation of brandy from France. Provisional measures in the form of cash or documentary securities have been imposed on the import of brandy from France entered for home consumption from 24 February. The investigation of the complaint will now proceed to reach a final decision within the timeframes announced in this legislation-that is, within 120 days. Within 45 days there needs to be a preliminary finding; within 120 days a decision has to be made. I hope that the brandy producers in his electorate will be happy that that action has been taken, and taken very promptly and very properly because the brandy industry is a very important industry not just in the electorate of Wakefield but also to the Australian agricultural area generally. I am pleased to note that that action has been taken.

The honourable member also asked a couple of other questions which I would like to answer. He asked whether the anti-dumping duty will be refunded on goods that are exported. Of course, it is. In normal circumstances, particularly where the drawback of duty has been applied, those duties, including dumping duties, will be refunded if those goods are in fact exported. He also asked whether dumping duties would be still payable if an exporter increased the price. The answer is yes. However, if the price has been increased to accord with normal values there will be no question of dumping and no dumping duty will be applied.

The honourable member also asked whether there could be an expansion of the area of appeal on dumping cases to producers as well as processors. I will perhaps answer this question when I get to the complaint raised by the honourable member for Murray. Certainly producers may join or support a complaint that has been made by the processing industry.

I should answer one other question that was asked by the honourable member for Chisholm. The honourable member asked whether users of products could be represented at meetings at which a preliminary complaint is being made. I am pleased to tell her that the Department will organise meetings of interested parties in accordance with the procedures for dealing with complaints. The users of products as well as importers and processors may all attend those meetings and give submissions. All of these submissions will be taken into account when the Minister is making a decision on the dumping complaint.

The honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) mentioned the specific matter of Pyrox gas heaters which are manufactured in his electorate. This complaint has been registered. In the first instance, further information was required to meet the prima facie case standard. However, this information was received and accepted on 21 December and this matter will be processed in accordance with the revised procedures. Therefore, the honourable member for Hotham might be heartened by the fact that his complaint is being recognised and that the company that was under threat in his electorate might find new life.

The honourable member for Murray asked about the definition of 'industry' when a complaint has been made particularly in the primary industry area. I should like to read to him the definition of 'industry' that applies not only to the processor but also to the primary producer. The GATT anti-dumping code to which Australia is a signatory provides, inter alia, that in determining injury the term 'domestic industry' shall be interpreted as referring to the domestic producers of like products as a whole proportion of the total production of those products. The term 'like product' is defined in the code to mean a product which is identical-that is, alike in all respects to the product under consideration or, in the absence of such a product, another product which, although not alike in all respects, has characteristics closely resembling those of the product under consideration. So, in the case of imported processed primary products the Government's policy is to allow primary producers to support a complaint being made by the local processing industry when the imported product competes directly in the local market with both the processed and the unprocessed product. The existing legislation is, in fact, adequate for this purpose.

I would like both the honourable member for Murray and the honourable member for O'Connor to be satisfied that the definition of 'industry' is flexible and can include not just the processor but also the primary producer who has an input into a like product. So if a complaint by a processor is being dealt with, the primary producer has in fact an opportunity to join in that complaint. I would not like any primary producer to think he was being denied that opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can they initiate a complaint?

—I will have to check this matter. However, as I understand it, primary producers have equal rights with the processor in initiating a complaint if they think damage is being done to their industry. However, I will check further on this matter and report back to the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: The last speaker, the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), made a very interesting contribution to the debate about the fishing industry in his electorate. I will take that complaint to the Minister and see that specific information is provided to the honourable member.

In summary, I am pleased that the House has launched a very comprehensive and constructive debate on this matter. When the subject comes up for discussion in the other House, the Opposition will introduce its amendment to cover the subject of what they believe to be an imposition on civil liberties. I am sure that the Minister, in responding to that, will be able to allay those fears. In view of this Bill's very important impact on Australian industry, first of all in terms of protection from dumped imports and secondly in terms of our necessity to comply with international agreements to which we are a signatory, I hope that it will get a speedy passage through the other House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: The Economy-Tertiary Education-Australian Labor Party-Northern Territory Government-Primary Industry Research-Education-Penalty Rates: Youth Unemployment -Tourist Industry-Duty Free Shopping-Travel Industry-Building Industry-First Home Owners Scheme

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during his recent sojourn in Singapore said at a business council breakfast that last year Australian workers received a wage increase of 4.3 per cent and that this year the increases are not likely to be significantly higher. The fact of the matter is that average weekly earnings rose by about 7 per cent during 1983. Why did the Prime Minister seek to mislead Asian businessmen on such a vital issue? Why is he incapable of telling the truth? I raise this issue of the rate of wages growth because it is fundamental to our future economic well-being. The Prime Minister's statement in Singapore highlights his failure to face up to the real problems confronting the economy. He is leading us into higher inflation, higher unemployment, higher interest rates, and generally putting economic recovery at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me be the first to admit that there has been a substantial lift in the economy over the last year, but it is important to recognise the significant factors which have contributed to that recovery. They have been the ending of the drought, the wages pause implementation by the Fraser Government, and world economic recovery. Those three factors have one thing in common, that is, the Prime Minister had nothing to do with them. What then has been the Government's contribution to economic recovery? Firstly, we had the National Economic Summit. At that Summit the Prime Minister gave away all the benefits which were accruing from the wages pause. The wages pause was implemented at a time of high real wages growth. It was not easy to get the wages pause in place but it was working , inflation was coming down, and the job scene was improving. The pause would have continued to work had the Prime Minister not generously given all to the big unions. The unions, of course, were pressing for a renewal and backdating of full wage indexation. The Prime Minister was determined to pay off the union bosses. The only man who was right at the Summit was Joh Bjelke-Petersen. The Prime Minister sacrificed the wages pause, economic growth and jobs for his own short term political gain.

After the Economic Summit we had the August Budget, with a deficit of around $8 billion. That is double the biggest deficit ever recorded by a coalition government. The results of this Government's economic policies are now beginning to show up. Unemployment is rising; the rate of inflation is rising; interest rates are rising. The previous Government had recognised that our inflation rate was of major concern and took steps through the Budget and through the wages pause to contain the increases in our inflation rate. From September 1982 the quarterly consumer price index increases fell every quarter until a year later, September 1983. Then the influence of the Labor Party's Budget deficit, together with the ending of the wages pause and wage indexation, started to have their effect on the CPI. The December quarter CPI was higher than that for September, indicating quite clearly that our rate of inflation is now starting to grow again. This is a disastrous situation, especially for exporters such as our farmers and our miners. They are confronted with costs rising in Australia at a much greater rate than in those countries with which we trade.

Our competitive position is being seriously eroded. Our inflation rate for the year to December 1983 was 8.6 per cent. Let us compare that with some overseas countries. In the United States the inflation rate was 3.8 per cent; in Japan 1. 8 per cent; in West Germany 1.9 per cent; in the United Kingdom 5.3 per cent. In fact, the average inflation rate for Australia's major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development trading partners was 3.6 per cent, compared with our rate of 8.6 per cent. These figures indicate our growing competitive disadvantage. Worse still, the inflation rate of our overseas trading partners continues to fall while ours is going up. The result will be the loss of export markets, a fall in our standard of living, and the further erosion of the incomes of our exporters, in particular farmers and miners. The gloomy prospects for further economic recovery in this country were highlighted again this week with the release of the Australian Bureau of Statistics forecast for capital spending. We need a lift in capital spending to ensure that the flagging recovery has a chance of surviving. However, the forecast indicates that business expects an 11 per cent real fall in capital spending in 1984-85. The industry most seriously affected is mining, with a real fall of over 20 per cent . This continuing downturn in forecasted capital expenditure will result in a further real cut in spending on new buildings and structures of about 20 per cent, more than halving the real spending levels of 1982-83.

If this Government is to address the economic problems confronting this nation then hard decisions have to be made, hard decisions to curb inflation, to curb wage growth, and to restore our international competitive position. The Prime Minister's record clearly indicates that he is not capable of making the hard decisions necessary. He always chooses the course of least resistance through the factions in his party. Hard options will have to be adopted if he is to contain wages growth, reduce the Budget deficit and give the promised tax cuts. I do not believe he will deliver the goods.

Certainly the Prime Minister has been adept at getting to the right sporting functions. However, he has not been adept at making the right economic decisions . The Prime Minister has avoided the hard decisions. He has always gone for the soft option. At the Economic Summit he gave away the hard-earned gains of the wages pause by conceding automatic indexation. Another classic case of a hard decision not faced by this Prime Minister was the uranium decision. That was not a decision at all. The issue was fudged. We had a decision neither for mining nor against mining. We had a decision for a little bit of uranium mining.

The confused, indecisive, muddle-headed decision making of this Government has meant that we now have 1,400 assets test wallopers with nothing to do. There are 1,400 public servants sitting in rented offices, with nothing to do. The cost to the Australian taxpayer of these people and their offices is around $20m a year. The Prime Minister has no excuse for such an enormous waste of taxpayers' funds, other than, of course, his own Administration's incompetence.

This Government is lurching from crisis to crisis. Continued economic recovery is in the balance. Hard decisions are needed to ensure economic growth, and this Prime Minister has shown he is incapable of making such hard decisions. Compromise is fine, but Prime Minister Hawke's actions have compromised future economic growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your elevation to the Chair. I want to address my comments today to a matter of great concern to very many country parents and country students, and that is the problem many young people are having gaining tertiary education. This Government has professed a sincere belief in the goal of increasing the opportunities for young people to pursue their education to tertiary level. The Australian Labor Party policy was to reverse the thrust of the previous Government and to increase the number of student places in tertiary education by 25,000 over a number of years. As honourable members might know, the cost of this proposal is great, and it must be phased in if it is not to affect seriously other very important Government programs. Because of the unexpected increase in applications for places in tertiary institutions this year, the Government, on top of the increase of 3,000 places announced in the Budget, has recently decided to allocate funds to enable an extra 3,000 students to enrol. This readiness to respond to an obvious need is to be commended. The 1983-84 Budget also included an 8.8 per cent increase in funding for universities and an 8.7 per cent increase for colleges of advanced education, an increase in real terms of one per cent over the previous year. This was done in spite of the inept handling of the economy by the previous Government which resulted in the massive increase in deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Government is to be commended for its concern for tertiary education generally, there is one area of concern that must be addressed. For years it has been recognised that, in general terms, access to a wide range of tertiary studies has been more difficult for non-metropolitan students than for those living in metropolitan areas. I recognise that certain groups living in metropolitan areas have been under-represented. Socio-economic factors and parent occupation have been important influences on children's academic and occupational opportunities. However, country students face particular problems that do not necessarily face those from cities with universities. Even those students who live in provincial cities with colleges of advanced education are not free from these problems if the CAE courses available are not those of their choice. They will still be required to leave home if they wish to study at a university or if their local CAE does not provide courses that suit them.

It is a pity that the Government should have chosen to reduce by 25 per cent the operating subsidy for collegiate residents before the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission reviewed the arrangements for support for student accommodation. From my experience, this will mean that a considerable number of students aiming at CAE courses will not be able to commence courses and a number of students will be unable to continue their studies. In a recent study undertaken by Mr Robert Pledger, a student services officer of Victoria College, the number of rural students, both male and female, who declined their offers of places in tertiary institutions in the metropolitan areas was markedly more significant than was the case with metropolitan-based students. According to this study, the major reasons why non-metropolitan students were deterred were twofold. Firstly, students, and I suggest parents, are deterred by the perceived financial cost and the lack of perceived benefits of tertiary education. Secondly, and closely allied to the first reason, is the social risk factor of undertaking tertiary education that necessarily involves a geographic removal of the students from their accustomed social environment.

With respect to the issue of financial cost, I sympathise with the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), who I know would have wished the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance to have been given a significant boost in the last Budget. The Minister is still hoping for an increase as she would like to have the allowance moved to equal the adult unemployment benefit. However, I guess that is a goal to be reached through a number of Budgets. Given that the value of TEAS was reduced significantly in real terms under the previous Government, which was determined to restore tertiary education to be the preserve of the privileged in our society, the present Government has considerable leeway to make up. As I indicated, the recent decision of Cabinet to approve an allocation of an extra $10.47m in order to give 3,000 extra students the opportunity to enrol in tertiary institutions is evidence of the Government's true commitment in this regard. Some 74 per cent of the $10.47m will go to colleges of advanced education, many of which are in non-metropolitan centres. I commend the Government for that step, especially as there is an emphasis on encouraging disadvantaged groups to enrol. However, there is still this one disadvantaged group that is not adequately recognised, and I emphasise that that is the country and other non-metropolitan students.

I indicated that a number of deterrents to participation in tertiary education face the country student. The TEAS allowance for those eligible for maximum payment is $2,110 per year for a student living at home. For those students living away from home the allowance is $3,255 per year, a difference of $1,145, or $22.08 per week. On one estimate, the cost of educating a student living away from home is around $6,400 per year. That figure might be somewhat inflated, but the question of an exact figure would be academic for most rural and provincial parents on moderate incomes. They would just not be able to afford to send their children to either the provincial cities or the metropolitan area for tertiary education. This situation effectively places such students in the category of disadvantaged as much as if they were living in the outer or the less privileged suburbs of the metropolitan area. It is far more difficult for young people from the country to establish work contacts in the city to enable them to meet some of their costs. The fact that they do not have part time jobs before they commence their studies can be crucial in their decision to turn away from tertiary studies. They are aware of the fact that in many cases they will be heavily dependent upon their parents for the necessary finances, and if the parents cannot meet the costs the students cannot enrol. I repeat that those eligible for a full TEAS allowance get only $1,145 more if they are living away from home.

It was sad to see the Victorian Government place the erstwhile teachers college hostels in that State up for sale. For years these hostels have provided country students with the opportunity to find their feet in the city, especially when attending colleges of advanced education. They have provided the low cost subsidised accommodation so necessary as students adjust to the often traumatic experience of leaving home and settling into a new social environment geographically distant from home. The hostels have also been an important factor in influencing parents to agree to their children's acceptance of places in tertiary education institutions. I could understand that eventually the Victorian Government would seek to have the Federal Government assume responsibility for the hostels. After all, tertiary education is the responsibility of the Federal Government and the State Government has its own priorities to meet. What is upsetting for so many students in Victoria is that there is now a major obstacle in their way that was not there previously. It certainly did not help to have the hostel accommodation allocation to colleges of advanced education reduced by 25 per cent in the same year.

I exhort the Minister and the Government to assume a much greater responsibility for assisting rural students by providing subsidised accommodation for country students. As many of these students would wish to seek private accommodation in the later years of study and many would gain access to part time jobs as they became accustomed to city living, the necessity for students to remain in subsidised accommodation for the entirety of their courses would not be critical. As well as a more realistic TEAS allowance, one that is more closely related to costs, it would be of great benefit to country students if subsidised accommodation were more readily available for more students, and I hope the Government will act to rectify the situation as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, the grievance I wish to present to this House today can be built around a single word, the word ' hypocrisy'. In this case, I direct that word to the many actions I have perceived in the Government ranks in recent times and in the last couple of days in particular. To take myself as the first example, it is almost a daily occurrence that members of the Government, and one in particular, remind me of a problem that occurred to me in 1967. It is a matter of record, and one which I have never denied, that I was convicted of assault, and assault against a black Australian. When those outraged people rise to their feet to do this, they take no notice whatsoever of the fact that within their own ranks is a person much more recently convicted of assaulting an Australian person, in this case a woman , and in the case a non-black woman. That is okay for them; they associate with and support that person. I hope that I will never have to raise that matter again in this place, but I promise them that, if they continue those attacks on me time and time again I will respond by drawing their attention to the situation in their own ranks.

SPEECH.PARA: They put themselves forward, although now to a much more limited degree, as the keepers of the public revenue. They stand up and advise the world of their great purity in the area of taxation collection from Australians for Australians. Yet the reality is that they all came into this House and stood behind one of their own Ministers, a proven tax avoider and a proven tax evader. They stood up for him and they voted down a motion of no confidence in that man by their solidarity behind him. They are guilty by association, and they have no right whatsoever at any time, on any occasion, while that man remains either a Minister or a member of their Party, to claim that they have some special role in this area. It is a disgraceful situation and one about which this Parliament has yet to receive the proper answers or to see even a reasonable investigation of the very concise documentation brought before it.

While I am talking about this situation and while I am thinking about the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), it is of interest to me that during the recess a very small country newspaper in my electorate bothered to raise the issue of my service to the electorate and gave me some credits. The following week the newspaper received a letter to the editor, under the letterhead of the Minister for Finance literally accusing them of biased reporting. What a childish thing for a Minister to do!

Let us get down to more serious matters. Let us look at yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald-a big and well-circulated newspaper. The first three pages are almost entirely devoted to matters relating to the activities of the Labor Party and the Labor Government in New South Wales. What are some of the headlines? Firstly and most importantly is the one that states: 'The Log of Corruption Claims'. Down a full three-inch wide column we get a list of the circumstances and activities of that Government and that political party. The first item on the list states:
Four Corners alleged in April 1983 that--
a particular judge is referred to-
at the request or direction of Mr Wran, influenced the outcome of committal proceedings against the football official . . .

The articles goes on to tell us what the result of all that was, and we know it anyway. We know that grave accusations have been proved and others are still pending. We know also that the Premier was exonerated. As in so many of these cases, of course, his tracks were well and truly covered. Further on the article continues:
In September/October 1983 the NSW Opposition Leader, Mr Greiner, alleged that prisoners bribed Corrective Services officials to gain early release.
What do they say was the outcome of that? The article goes on:
The Minister for Corrective Services, Mr Rex Jackson . . . resigned . . . for misleading Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am led to believe that the proceedings the honourable member for O'Connor is mentioning are the subject of a judicial inquiry which is at present proceeding in New South Wales. I believe that there must be a fair hearing of this matter, and if the honourable member proceeds along the course he is taking that will be prejudiced and there will be no fair hearing.
—The point of order is upheld.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I am referring to a newspaper article that was published in the public Press yesterday. Quite clearly, if the prejudice has occurred it has occurred.
—Order! If the matter the honourable member is referring to comes directly from a newspaper the point of order is not upheld.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I come to the hypocrisy of the situation and further guilty associations. When the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) raised matters relating to that very situation, what happened? They had two weeks to take action on this matter. They did nothing in that time officially, but unofficially there was a lot of talk and a lot of effort to muddy the waters, to cover the tracks. To my great disappointment, the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), a young man whom I admire and who I believe has a great future in the Parliament, stood before us with his honest face and told us that everything was all right, everything had been done properly. Quite clearly, that was not so. As in all of these New South Wales Watergate matters-it is interesting that the Premier of New South Wales has never learnt the lessons of Richard Nixon-they continue to deny and to try to cover up. The newspaper refers to 'New South Wales, the Allegation State'. Let me say of that that where there is smoke there has to be fire.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we see further on this page? There is a huge photograph of a huge man. 'I never belt a lady', said Mr Domican. Mr Domican has stated himself that he was employed by friends of the Labor Party at $20,000 per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been denied.

—It has been denied, but I will take Mr Domican's word for it, thank you very much. I bet that if any action is taken in any court none is taken against Mr Domican. There would be two good reasons for that. The first is that that statement is true, and the second is that not one honourable member opposite would be game to deal with a gentleman like this. He is quoted as being Senator Richardson's enforcer, and it is interesting to note that he claims that he recruited members. I love that word 'recruited'. When he knocked on somebody' s door that person would accept recruitment with great alacrity. He is a bash artist, and he has been a close associate of members of the New South Wales Labor Party. Peter Baldwin is not here now, but Peter Baldwin probably recognised his features through his black eyes. We know how the New South Wales Labor Party operates, and it is a shame to see the Federal Government, in trying to protect its political mates, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in trying to protect his political power base, entering into guilt by association with what has been proved time and time again to be a shameful organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: On the front page of the newspaper we see the headline: 'Judge should be more careful'. He certainly should, but it is a pity that someone like the present Prime Minister did not give him that advice years ago. 'Judge should be more careful'. He should be a better person! We then have the Attorney-General ( Senator Evans), after this horrible event, saying:

No one will ever be able to blow off steam with loved ones or trusted intimates ; no one will be able to gossip, or brag, or exaggerate, or fib in the way that every one of us has done from time to time in circumstances which he would be appalled to ever find made public.

That is what he is suggesting about the day to day activities of one of our most senior judges. It was disgraceful to suggest it. Quite clearly we expect a judge , whether he is on the telephone, in his court, or speaking at some luncheon, to have the propriety and the decency of mind not to behave in that fashion. If that is the only charge against him he is condemned on that, but I suspect there is a lot more of it. The Sydney Morning Herald is full of it-Trimbole, Allan--

TALK.START.PARA: —If you read what Wran says you will agree with it.

—If the honourable member is worried about it, he can get up and speak next on this matter. He can associate himself with the tragedy that is New South Wales politics. It is a disgrace. There is a log of corruption claims.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well nigh time that some of the myths developed by the Northern Territory Government's propaganda machine were exploded. Propaganda is used widely by the Northern Territory Government to cover up its incompetence in most areas of its Administration. That Government clearly subscribes to the Hitler principle that the great mass of people will more easily fall victim to a great lie than a small one. Many great untruths have been told by the Northern Territory Government and many people have fallen victim to them. Many gullible members of the Australian media can count themselves among those victims. Not the least are the so-called political journalists of the Northern Territory News who, it seems, have swallowed the Country Liberal Party line in the Northern Territory, hook and sinker included. I have no doubt that the Northern Territory News and its CLP masters will attack me for making these comments. They will say, among other things, that I am attacking the Northern Territory and its people. I am not. The fact is that the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory people are not, fortunately, synonymous. Most of the advances made in the Northern Territory in recent years have occurred in spite of the bungling and incompetence of the Northern Territory Government. These advances have been made as a result of the hard work and dedicated spirit of the Territory people. They are the people who are responsible for the advances made. They are the people who should feel proud . They are the people who should be given the credit, not the Northern Territory Government, which spends most of its time claiming the credit.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the bungling and incompetence of this Government and the untruths it keeps telling. We should keep in mind that the Northern Territory Government has served only three months of its current four-term term, and this is what has happened in that short period. Firstly, the Territory Insurance Office annual report was tabled yesterday in the Legislative Assembly in Darwin. The report discloses that the Office lost $5m and it suggests that former members of the Office's staff will be prosecuted. Over the past four or five months, numerous Government Ministers have consistently denied that the Office was in any trouble. More untruths. Secondly, in January the Northern Territory Government closed the Darwin primary school and arrogantly gave next to no notice to parents and students that they would have to go to some other school. It is widely rumoured that the school land has been marked for property development. That has been denied by the Northern Territory Ministers concerned, but who would believe them? Many members of Darwin's Chinese community attended that school in the early days of Darwin and it has a very special place in their hearts. That did not make the slightest bit of difference to the Northern Territory Government in its arrogant decision to close the school.

Thirdly, the Northern Territory Government had recently helped out one of its land developer mates by purchasing 16 units in the Marraki unit development. That is unusual enough when we consider that Housing Commission money was used to purchase these units. Some of the units cost up to $200,000, and they are to be leased to public servants in the Northern Territory at a rent of $90 per week . In the meantime, thousands of Territorians wait up to 18 months in Housing Commission queues for a humble house. I ask: What sort of fair allocation of Housing Commission money is that?

Fourthly, earlier this week the Secretary of the Department of Primary Production resigned. He is the fourth person to resign from that position in as many years. All have resigned without adequate explanation. The Secretary of that Department joins a long queue of talented senior public servants who have resigned in similar circumstances. The departments concerned include the Department of Community Development, the Department of Mines and Energy, the Department of Education and many more. The resignations raise serious questions about the relationship between the Northern Territory Government and its senior public servants. It is indicative of more administrative bungling.

Fifthly, last month the Australian National Line operated its last east coast shipping service to Darwin. The Northern Territory Government had been given almost four years notice that it would have to replace the service when the Australian Government subsidy ran out. It ignored these notices. The notices were given, I might add, by both this Government and the former Liberal Government-the Northern Territory Government's colleagues.
