At present Darwin has no east coast shipping service, and it is certain-in fact this has been admitted by wholesalers and retailers-that the price of beer, building materials and some foodstuffs is certain to rise. Why? Because the Northern Territory Government bungled it yet again. It is only now that the service has been stopped that it has really got serious about finding an alternative service.

Sixthly, and this is probably the most serious matter, by loose talk, the Northern Territory Government and its Chief Minister have put at risk the funds for the accelerated upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin. Last year, during the debate over the Alice Springs to Darwin railway, the Chief Minister said, among other things, that the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin was adequate and did not need upgrading. The report of the Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, the Hill report, which was tabled yesterday, concludes that the case for the accelerated upgrading is not strong. Those two statements, taken together, have put the accelerated upgrading of the Stuart Highway between Alice Springs and Darwin under a very big cloud. I have had discussions with the Minister for Transport (Mr Morris) and I am sorry to have to say that that cloud puts the funds for the accelerated upgrading at considerable risk. I am trying now to fight a rearguard action to salvage those funds for the Northern Territory people to ensure that the Northern Territory Government's bungling does not result in the only transport link between the Northern Territory and the rest of Australia being left in a totally inadequate condition.

The seventh matter relates to the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign. This week the Minister for Primary Production in the Territory suspended compensation payments under the BTEC scheme, saying that the Budget had been overspent. There are very strong rumours circulating, in the Northern Territory and elsewhere, which raise some very serious allegations about the Northern Territory Government's administration of that scheme. Those rumours include the administration being totally inadequate, government funds, and in this case the Australian Government contributes a large part towards those funds , being misused, insufficient control or supervision of the scheme, and collusion being involved. I am sure more will be said about this issue in coming weeks and months. Again, we see incompetence and bungling from the Northern Territory Government.

I have not mentioned a number of other incidents that have occured in the last three months, including the 6 per cent increase in electricity charges, the $2. 25m that Territory Ministers are spending on their travel and entertainment, the Chief Minister's destructive politicking over the Kakadu tourist plan, the closure of the second ward at the Gove hospital, the 30 per cent per annum turnover rate among Territory public servants, the broken election promise to introduce a foreign ownership registry and the money being wasted in continuing to employ Canberra lobbyist David Combe. The bungling goes on and on and all of it has occurred in the last three months.

I come back to the question of propaganda. With the use of propaganda and an unquestioning Press, the Northern Territory Government is drawing attention away from its incompetent bungling by continuing its negative, destructive, whingeing , whining, Canberra-bashing campaign. The Northern Territory Government continues its conflict politics in this area. While its administration of the Territory is in chaos, it tries to draw the fire by concenrating on national issues it has no control over, very little interest in and very little responsibility for. I refer to issues such as communications, which falls within the realm of the Federal Minister and Telecom; the free trade zone, which is a matter for national trade; tariff policy, which is again a matter for national trade; and uranium mining, which is a matter to be decided by this national Government. At the same time, the Northern Territory Government continues a scare campaign on the future of Australian Government funding by untruthfully claiming that the Australian Government will not continue to fund the Territory. The irresponsible Northern Territory Government is eroding confidence in the Territory's economy by continuing to make these statements.

The track record of the Hawke Labor Government speaks for itself on this matter . In the 1983-84 Budget, we increased funding for the Territory by $124m, which is the largest dollar increase ever. So the combination of incompetent bungling, the scare-based Canberra-bashing campaign, and a leader pre-occupied with using Territory taxpayers' money to run a Federal campaign, has given the Northern Territory and its people a bigger handicap than Phar Lap's. I hope that the handicapper, namely, the Northern Territory Government, will start to act a little responsibly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Deputy Speaker, today I speak on behalf of Australia's 120,000 sheep and cattle producers, who are being badly hurt by yet another broken promise of the Hawke Labor Government. Honourable members will recall that before the last election Labor made a firm promise to increase government involvement in research for primary industry. It was quite specific about this when it told graziers how much better off they would be under a Hawke Labor government. Words, as always, are rather cheap. Not only has the Hawke Labor Government failed to speed up research which would benefit primary industry, but also livestock producers are today suffering from long delays and seemingly endless red tape when it comes to getting new and improved veterinary products approved and on to the market. For this deplorable state of affairs our farmers and graziers can thank both the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). The Minister for Primary Industry certainly has not flexed his axeman's muscles. Maybe he is not even aware of the example I am about to raise, but surely he would have done something about it if he was on top of his job, carrying out his election promises, and even remotely interested in the welfare of farmers and graziers, their wives and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian livestock producers have been waiting for 12 months for the Hawke Labor Government to approve a new veterinary wonder drug, Ivermectin, which is helping to wipe out internal and external livestock parasites in more than 30 other countries. Despite the fact that the drug has been approved by primary industries authorities in the United States, New Zealand, South Africa and South America, Ivermectin has still not been approved by Australia's own National Health and Medical Research Council. We live in a world trading environment where we are largely price takers, and Australia's farmers are very adaptable and very cost efficient. However, if they are to be subjected to competition from other countries which have access to veterinary products which significantly reduce costs obviously they are at a disadvantage. Furthermore, there appears to be no prospect of Ivermectin being approved in the foreseeable future.

Ivermectin works in a completely new and different way. It paralyses and ultimately kills parasites through a unique action on their nervous system. Some of the world's foremost veterinary authorities are describing this drug for sheep and cattle as the greatest breakthrough since the discovery of penicillin. Even in the United States of America, a nation which is universally known for its strict agricultural regulations and its acute concern about chemical residue dangerous to humans, Ivermectin-related products are approved not just for sheep and cattle but also for horses. The problem in Australia is that instead of learning and benefiting from all this overseas research about the drug, the National Health and Medical Research Council is imposing testing requirements which have not been insisted upon anywhere else in the world. If the Labor Party was genuine about practical research and its professed desire to assist primary producers, it would accept that not only has this drug been well and truly tested overseas and found to be safe, but its potential for better parasite control among livestock in Australia is enormous. If the Labor Party was genuine about primary producers, it would also realise the potential damage this excessive and unwarranted red tape is doing to Australia's meat export trade.

Ivermectin is widely used throughout the world already, but it is proving of particular benefit to New Zealand, which competes directly with Australia on world beef and sheep meat markets. Our neighbours across the Tasman have found this wonder veterinary chemical a formidable productivity tool. They have found that it safely and effectively controls all internal parasites and resistant strains which affect sheep, along with lung-worm, nasal bot and itch mite. In point of fact, lice are the only major sheep parasite for which control with this drug is not claimed at present. There is no excuse for the Minister for Primary Industry or the Minister for Health either not knowing about the drug or , if they do know about it, not acting on this problem. It is a problem with the potential to cost Australia millions of dollars in lost exports and a problem which has resulted from just another broken promise of the Hawke Labor Government. I suggest that if the Ministers require any further information they consult their own departments or purchase a copy of this week's Queensland Country Life, which has an excellent article setting out the concern of graziers .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, with this opportunity today to comment about general problems in our electorates or in the nation at large, I thought I would speak again about an important issue in my electorate of Lowe, the issue of education. I notice that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his talk to the National Press Club dealt with education and the quality of education in our nation, but because of other matters he touched on education got very little mention in the national Press. The Prime Minister reiterated and reinforced his Government's commitment to improving the quality of education in Australia, and in relation to financial assistance he stressed that the Labor Party is committed to 'diversity of educational opportunity'. The Prime Minister continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Such assistance to schools is provided with due regard both to the principle of equality of educational opportunity, and the principle of need as defined in close consultation with interested parties.

As I go around my electorate visiting primary schools and secondary schools, both state and new state, I really believe that in many of the schools our young Australians have little hope of equality of educational opportunity. Many of the schools are old, some buildings were constructed as long ago as the 1850s, and many of the playgrounds are inadequate. In some suburbs the school population is largely from families in which English is a second language, so that the families do not have English language books or even, in some cases, English language newspapers. The parents, if they are born overseas, are not familiar with joining parents and citizens or parents and friends groups, and in some cases, the schools have no active parent support. Now this makes for great difficulty in trying to ensure equality of educational opportunity.

I know that the Government has been very generous with the non-government schools and with the government schools, but as I go around the electorate I must confess to a sense of hopelessness in relation to the schools I see. The primary and secondary schools will need an enormous injection of capital funding to do anything about inadequate playgrounds, old buildings, lack of resources. The principle of need, which was the second part of the Prime Minister's comment , was well thrashed out last year. Towards the end of 1983 there was almost a sense of hysteria about the Labor Party's 'needs' policy. There were meetings in Sydney, meetings in Melbourne, meetings around the country. There were advertising campaigns by the Parents Council and other groups. I believe that now the school authorities and the parent groups that opposed the Labor Party see that the ALP is here to stay. Labor has a big majority. The swing to the Labor Party in the Richmond by-election will only confound those who feel that Labor is not entrenched and will not be in government for a long time. In fact, the total exodus of members from the Opposition benches certainly would support an argument that Labor is here to stay.

I thought I would raise today the matter of the expectation being built up in the Press, in the media and in the public at large that the Government must make large tax reductions. If our nation is to do anything about the future of young Australians and the schools and institutes and technical colleges in which they are educated, then I do not see how such a policy, such a commitment, can be compatible with enormous tax cuts. I believe that we will sell short the future of Australian children and Australian youth if we give substantial cuts in taxation at the expense of adequately funding the schools and technical colleges . I have discussed this at some length with non-educationalists, people in the Catholic Education Office and the State Government offices, and they tell me that schools are even worse off in the country. In particular, the parish schools in small country towns are unbelievable. I have seen only one of these and that was at Bourke, where I have a cousin who is a nun at the convent school . A large number of the children are Aboriginal, and they pay no fees at all. I was staggered at how bad this parish school at Bourke was. It was lacking in basic facilities, and it is in a very hot and arid part of our nation. If many schools in other country towns are in as bad a way then our nation should be ashamed. We cannot hold our heads high at the international conferences on education matters which our public servants attend at great expense.

The issue was thrashed out at great length last year, but I have raised the matter today because I believe that there is now a calmer atmosphere, with perhaps less hysteria, in which people can look at eduation in our nation and see where we are going. I have always believed that had we a continuation of the previous Government's political philosophy of a basic grant to all non- government schools, by which the wealthy schools got wealthier and the poorer schools got poorer, then the Australian people would have turned against all aid to non-government schools, and that would have been a tragedy. The whole concept of aid to non-government schools would have been at risk had the previous Government remained in office. What concerns me is that the previous Government' s funding of non-government schools set government schools against non- government schools. If there is to be funding of education, as there must be in our nation, there has to be a united approach to the government schools that need aid and the non-government schools that need aid. Funding of one is not and must not be at the expense of the other.

The children of our nation deserve a decent acceptable standard of education, and in many of the schools in my electorate they would be very lucky to get that . If the child is bright, he will survive. If the child is not bright, if he has English language difficulties, if he has reading difficulties, then the schools that I see as I go around my electorate and to other parts of the country are very deficient in resources and facilities for that child. In the small playgrounds I see in schools in my area the ethnic kiddies need more room to run around. The schools have not got facilities. Many families who do not speak English are very protective of their children. They are not allowed to take part in weekend sporting activities. If they cannot get their sporting facilities at school then they do not get any involvement with other kiddies because the families are very home conscious and keep the children at home.

I have raised before the matter of inadequate playgrounds. I have raised the matter of inadequate buildings and lack of resources. What I really want to emphasise today is this whole concept of tax cuts vis-a-vis education funding. The amount of money needed to improve the schools in our nation to any extent is enormous. I am sure that one could sink $50m into the electorate I represent and perhaps see a lot for it, but that is just one electorate out of 126 in our nation. If the country schools, the isolated schools and all the others are so bad, then our nation will use up a lot of funds. Already the Federal education bill is mounting at an enormous rate. I congratulate the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, who is proving particularly competent and very sensitive to the needs of schools and has introduced many innovative programs that have done a lot not only to keep young people at school but also to improve the quality of education. Once again I stress this problem of the expectation of tax cuts while at the same time taking positive steps to improve both the government schools and the non-government schools in our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the House today on the question of penalty rates and the effect of penalty rates on youth unemployment. I consider that penalty rates are the major inhibiting factor on small business in Australia employing school leavers this year, 1984. I say this because I have recently conducted an Australia-wide survey of small business. The results show that 20 per cent of businesses surveyed stated that the major reason for not taking on school leavers this year was penalty rates. This is an alarming and a concerning result, and I consider that the Government should take note of it. It is frightening that jobs in Australia are being lost because of the lack of capacity of small business to pay penalty rates. Whilst my survey concentrated on school leavers it logically follows, I believe, that penalty rates inhibit small business across the nation from taking on employees of all ages.

SPEECH.PARA: The survey that was conducted from my office contacted a variety of small businesses across Australia, including nurseries, newsagents, chemists, service stations, hairdressers and small manufacturers. It uncovered a number of disturbing facts. It showed that last year 60 per cent of firms took on school leavers, but this year only 26 per cent will be employing school leavers and another 10 per cent have yet to make up their minds. So even if the undecided group actually employ young people, the figure would still be well below last year's figure. Considering that an estimated 80 per cent of new jobs in the Australian economy will have to come from the small business sector, this is a most frightening and alarming statistic and paints a grim picture for school leavers in Australia.

My survey was necessarily limited but was randomly carried out and honestly done, and I think it is a most reasonable guide to trends. It was a telephone survey, and initial contact was made with over 100 organisations picked from the yellow pages. Reasons given for not employing school leavers were penalty rates, 20 per cent; business being down, 15 per cent; workers compensation and other imposts on small business, 12 per cent; youth wages being too high, 10 per cent; industry award anomalies, 10 per cent; payroll tax, 5 per cent; and 28 per cent other. Let me quote what some small business respondents said during the survey. From a chemist in Queensland:
If there were no penalty rates I would definitely employ more people.
A newsagent in Queensland said:
Penalty rates are the most ridiculous thing I've heard of.
From a newsagent in Tasmania:
I employ less staff out of business hours than I actually need because of penalty rates. I believe the alternative to penalty rates should be an overall increase in wages . . .
Another quote from a chemist in Western Australia:
Percentage of wages to turnover have crept up dramatically in the last two years.

What is the Government doing about penalty rates? I believe that the Government should live up to its promises in this area, and its activity has been nil. Let us look at what the Government has said. On the 22 February 1983, before the election, the now Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) said that a Labor government would seek a reduction in the outrageous penalty rates for workers in the tourist industry. He has backed off from that statement , under the thumb of the union movement, but has at least admitted in the House that in certain isolated areas of the tourist industry they have a horrendous effect. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is reported as saying on 24 February last year, before the election, that a Labor government would call discussions between all parties in the industry to agree on new penalty rates. Senator Button, since he has been the Minister for Industry and Commerce, has raised the issue and canvassed the question of penalty rates and has said that they might be reviewed or abandoned. On 18 April, the Prime Minister said that he would be prepared to review penalty rates in some areas if jobs could be created.

Now the Government has gone silent; it has gone quiet. The Prime Minister has said nothing further, the Tourism Minister has gone quiet. There is a silence. What has happened to the conference that the Tourism Minister said was going to be called between industry, Government and employee representatives to look at penalty rates in the tourist industry? Why has the Government gone silent? Why has the Prime Minister gone silent? Why has the Minister gone silent? They have gone silent because Labor is frozen in to the institutionalised framework and structure of the union movement. I repeat today, as I have said before in this place, that the parliamentary Labor Party is the captive of the union movement and is the formal representative in Parliament of the union movement. That is why the Labor Party was formed. The Minister and the Prime Minister have developed feet of clay on this issue of penalty rates. Labor talks of jobs, Labor talks of growth, but it is only rhetoric. The reality is that the Prime Minister, the Tourism Minister and the Labor Party are frozen stiff in the vested interests of the union movement, who want no change. The union movement is thinking only of itself and is not concerned about growth, profit, investment or the creation of wealth in our society. The union movement fails to realise that the creation of a bigger wealth cake through profits in fact benefits employer and employee alike.

I am not alone in my concern. In a gallup poll last year, 54 per cent of Australians said that they wanted wage penalty rates reduced and 60 per cent of Australians said that they would like penalty rates reduced or eliminated as part of a special program to increase youth employment in service industries such as the tourist and travel industries. What is required in Australia today is for the Government and the union movement to understand that working patterns are changing, that the traditional concept of the five-day, Monday to Friday working week is no longer regarded as sacrosanct, that many people would be happy working a regular working week on any given five days of a week. There is a community-wide shift towards a greater flexibility of working hours. The union movement and the Government must appreciate that penalty rates do inhibit growth , do inhibit expanding opportunities for Australians. Penalty rates stop Australians, young and old, getting jobs. Labor talks rhetoric, but the reality is that it will do nothing about penalty rates. Labor should be facing this question. The Government should be honouring its commitments to hold an inquiry. I think the Prime Minister indicated that there would be one, and the Tourism Minister said that he would call a conference. We should be creating jobs in society today, creating wealth, encouraging profit, and encouraging investment, but the Government is doing none of this, none of this at all.

Can I look, in the time available, at the tourist industry? Recently there was a 5.7 per cent consumer price increase in the cost of domestic holiday travel and accommodation. This makes it imperative and urgent to tackle the problem of penalty rates, particularly in the tourism and hospitality industries. The abolition of penalty rates would reduce costs and create thousands of jobs in these industries because penalty rates, by their very nature act as a barrier to employment. The Australian Tourist Commission currently has a task force investigating the effects of penalty rates on the tourism and hospitality industries. It must have wider terms of reference than a recent Monash University penalty rates study, which in fact was interpreted very selectively by the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, who said that the abolition of penalty rates would not have significant impact on prospects for economic growth. Mr Cain is absolutely wrong, and I am saying to the Australian Tourist Commission that I hope that in its study it will take into account those matters in the Monash study that were ignored by the Victorian Government. That includes statements that the Victorian hotel, restaurant and boarding house wages bill would decrease by over 25 per cent if penalty rates were abolished and that the average hospitality industry wage bill would be reduced by 19 per cent if penalty rates were abolished. The Australian Tourist Commission should also take into account matters such as the effect of the additional add-on costs of penalty rates on workers compensation and payroll tax payments. It should concentrate on the new employment opportunities that are lost because of penalty rates. I call on the Australian Tourist Commission, in its study, to look at all the inhibiting effects of penalty rates on the potential growth of the tourist industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Deputy Speaker, since you were elected to your position this is the first time I have been on my feet, so might I take the opportunity to congratulate you. We in this place are very pleased about having you as Deputy Speaker and I know that the community in Australia, especially many women, are very proud that you are there. They feel that you have shown great courage and great perseverance and that you really deserve the position.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is appropriate that the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) spoke about the travel industry. I should like to speak initially very briefly about the travel industry today and then go on to speak about some problems involving the housing industry. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Higgins, mentioned the question of penalty rates. One of the issues his Party never did address when it was in government, and I think it is rather unfortunate, is the question of the duty free shopping in Australia. People in the community would be aware that currently it is possible to buy duty free goods in Australia, but unfortunately one has to carry those out of the country and bring them back into the country to comply with the requirements of the Customs Regulations. Obviously that is a very inconvenient way to handle shopping, and so the practice is that, despite the fact that we do have duty free businesses in Australia, many people do their duty free shopping in places such as Singapore and Hong Kong.

I would suggest to the relevant Minister and to the Government that it would really make sense if we were able to buy our duty free goods when we return to the country. Perhaps we could buy them and put them in a bonded warehouse so that we could collect them when we returned to the country. The implication is very clear. If we did that we would keep money in Australia and we would help some Australian businesses. I share the concern of the honourable member for Higgins about the need to have good Australian business and I believe that this would do something substantial to improve Australian business. Obviously this is not directed against shopkeepers in Singapore and Hong Kong, but I feel that our primary obligation is to the businesses of Australians and the travelling public of Australia.

My suggestion to the Government is that we look seriously at developing inbound duty free or bonded warehouses. According to the research I have done, not only would that keep money in Australia but Qantas estimates that it could save some $6m per annum in fuel because of the extra freight that people currently carry out of the country and bring back into the country. There is also the safety factor, of course. If everyone on board a 747 has a one litre bottle of spirit, as they are allowed to, that is very dangerous. We might have 400 bottles, 400 litres, on board a 747, and if there was a fire it would cause serious problems. There is also the fact that it we buy duty free goods in Australia we can go to the shop from which we bought them and follow up guarantees. Most goods carry no international guarantees but we would certainly have guarantees within Australia . So, my suggestion is that the Government look seriously at this idea. I believe it would help the Australian travelling public and it would certainly help businesses in Australia, and I believe that both sides of the House have a commitment to doing that.

Along with that, I believe we have an urgent priority to look at the question of licensing and registration of travel agents. Currently, of course, there is an International Air Transport Association arrangement whereby people can get IATA recognition as travel agents. However, governments have not done anything to license travel agents. What has happened, very clearly, is that the travelling public are at risk because from time to time companies default on their commitments to their customers. We ought to have a licensing arrangement whereby everyone who wanted to join the travel industry as a travel agent would either have to have a certain amount of paid-up capital or lodge a sum of money as a bond. In the event of people becoming stranded in places such as Singapore or Hong Kong, and we know that that happens frequently, that money could be drawn upon to ensure that the travellers were able to return to Australia. I believe that as a matter of priority this Government and State governments ought to look at the question of licensing and registration of travel agents. It would do a great deal for consumer protection.

The second industry I wish to talk about is the building industry. In a speech on the adjournment last night, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) raised some concerns about processing of applications for the Government's first home owners scheme. He went to some lengths to criticise this Government for the way it was processing those applications. I find that rather strange because, in terms of overall performance, this Government is looking at something like 130, 000 new housing commencements in the financial year July on June 1983-84, whereas for the previous financial year, when the former Government had the say in housing, commencements were only 105,000. So we will be adding at least 25, 000 houses to the private sector of building because of our housing policy. I do not believe it is good enough to come into this place, as the honourable member for O'Connor did, and say that we are not doing the right thing.

Let me deal with a couple of points about the reality of processing first home owners' applications. We accept that there have been some delays, but that is because there was an enormous flood of applications when we commenced our scheme . In Western Australia in particular, where the scheme has been very successful, we have had great co-operation from the building industry, from the finance companies, certainly from the State Minister for Housing, and from the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford). I can understand why the honourable member for O'Connor feels that it is a sore point. The success of the scheme shows him up and his Government as being lamentable failures with respect to housing. We cannot afford to fool around about that. There are many areas where our Government is performing well and housing is one of those.

The clear situation I want to convey to the public, because I understand that the honourable member for O'Connor was trying to scare members of the public, is that if a person has lodged a first home owner's application for a grant of money, if he has indicated that he has a particular settlement date he has to reach then the housing assistance scheme will be able to ensure that his grant of money is made available for that settlement date. A lot of people out there in the community at the moment must be very uneasy because of those words last night, but I would like to reassure them that if they do indicate a settlement date on the application form and if the application is completed properly and fully, the grant will be made available by the settlement date. I think it is important that we take some care in handling these grants.

The honourable member for O'Connor may have been a little slipshod in his comments and he may be slipshod in his own financial practices, but this Government is not about to start being cavalier with public money. We are handling public money with care and due regard. This is not Carnarvon Shire Council, this is the Federal Government of Australia. We are handling money with due care and consideration. We are processing the money appropriately, and if members of the public wish to have their first home owner applications processed and they do have a settlement date, then we can meet that settlement date. I think it is important to convey that message here today.

The other important thing to indicate is that in terms of the overall performance of the first home owners scheme, it is meeting the goals of the Government. I should point out that the previous Government did have a home savings grant scheme. The honourable member for O'Connor said: 'You are not getting your applications processed inside of six weeks'. Under the previous Government's scheme people were given only a month in which to lodge applications, and if they did not succeed in that time then they did not qualify . So on 2 July 1982 if people had not indicated that they wanted to lodge home savings grant applications or their application were not in, then they simply did not qualify. The current Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) is still getting letters from the community about problems the previous Government so cavalierly ignored by giving people only four weeks in which to lodge their applications.

In relation to the overall approach to handling first home owner applications, we are doing what we can in terms of staffing. We are retraining people and we are looking at reallocating people from other departments. We believe that the industry can assist us a great deal by conveying the sort of message that I am conveying today. The reality is that if people wish to have a first home owner scheme grant processed, if they indicate to the office on their application what their settlement date is and they fill out that application clearly, then we will process it. In fact, 80 per cent of applications do fit that criteria. The message for the people in Western Australia particularly and in my Federal electorate of Stirling is very clear. We can process the home owners grant applications effectively. We can do it if people indicate their settlement date. We have a responsible scheme. It is a scheme that can meet the demands of the community. All we ask of the community is that a clear indication is given to the housing office. We can do indicative assessments to advise people whether or not they are entitled to that grant and we can process it with due expedition.

To refute the statements of the honourable member for O'Connor, this Government has a responsible housing policy. It has an excellent Housing Minister. It is getting good co-operation from the industry and from the State governments. I do not believe it is the business of Federal parliamentarians to come into this place and use scare tactics around the community. We have a responsible policy. We aim to see that that policy will succeed, and I believe that in terms of the direction and thrust of the policy so far there is every reason why this scheme will continue successfully in the future. In conclusion, I say to the community of Australia that we as a Government intend to continue this good housing scheme . It does show up the inadequacies of the past. The honourable member for O' Connor cannot talk about the housing policies of the past. We have a good scheme to pursue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Does he agree with the statement this week by his Minister for Social Security that the assets test will go ahead?

—I repeat that this Government has not retracted from the principle involved in the legislation introduced into this place. That remains clear. I will be in a position later today or tomorrow to announce the composition of a broadly-based representative committee which will assist the Government in an advisory capacity as to how we can give effect to that principle, taking account of the fact that, as I have readily acknowledged, there is some degree of misunderstanding and uncertainty in the community and perhaps some anomalies in the nature of the proposals we put forward.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PAPUA NEW GUINEA: POSSIBLE VOLCANIC ERUPTION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What steps has the Government taken to respond to a request from the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Somare, for assistance in the event of a volcanic eruption at Rabaul?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for St George for his question. The Government has been in touch with the Government of Papua New Guinea for some time and has arranged for a speedy and co-ordinated Australian response to requests from Papua New Guinea for assistance in respect of the threatened volcanic eruption at Rabaul. The Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Somare, rang me on 17 February requesting assistance with pre-disaster preparations. Naturally I assured him of Australia's willingness to help with relief assistance in whatever way possible. I asked him then on the phone to provide me in writing with details of what he had in mind. He wrote to me on 23 February and today I wrote to him informing him of the Government's response. We have agreed to provide an emergency broadcasting system. The Government will help with temporary shelter for people not already provided for under the local evacuation plan. Also, two Australian experts requested by Mr Somare flew to Papua New Guinea on 29 February to carry out key tasks, advising our two governments on evacuation planning and material requirements. Those two experts are Captain Doyne Hunt, Royal Australian Navy, retired, who is the former head of plans and operations and is attached to the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, and Dr Hugh Davies of the Bureau of Mineral Resources, who will help to establish a volcanological information service.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that two earlier requests by Papua New Guinea for assistance, which Prime Minister Somare mentioned in his Press conference of 23 February- that is, for airfield and water supply construction-have been deferred but our officials will keep in close contact about progress on these requirements. Finally-I am sure I speak for the whole House and all Australians-we are monitoring the situation closely in order to ensure that Australia is ready to respond to any further requests from the Government of Papua New Guinea as the situation evolves.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. I refer the Minister to newspaper reports today which indicate that the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence has asked Victorian police for photographs of two journalists who have written articles on the New South Wales corruption tapes. Did the Minister originate this request? If so, what is the purpose of his request? If not, who did make the request and for what purpose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the honourable member for Boothby for his question. I am advised that photographs of the persons were sought by the ABCI because the Bureau believed it was necessary as a safeguard for the security of their information against the background that the reporters concerned were known to be investigating matters related to current police inquiries involving persons not connected with the Age tapes articles they had written. It is my view that this action was an error of judgment by the Bureau and I wish to make it clear that I and the Government do not approve of any police surveillance of journalists legitimately conducting inquiries.

ANSWER.PARA: I should point out that the ABCI is not a federal crime intelligence agency, as reported, but an inter-governmental body responsible to all Australian governments through the Australian Police Ministers Council. I have today spoken to the current Chairman of the Police Ministers' Council, Mr Mathews, the Victorian Minister for Police and Emergency Services, with a view to having the matter of proper procedures for the accreditation of journalists to the ABCI placed on the agenda of the next Council meeting in May. I have also been briefed on the background to the request for photgraphs by the Director of the Bureau, Mr Anderson, and have discussed the matter with the current Chairman of the ABCI management committee, the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police .

I have indicated to them that while I accept the need for the Bureau to take appropriate measures to safeguard the security of its information holdings, it must do this in a way which is consistent with the civil liberties of law- abiding Australian citizens.

The Editor of the Age newspaper, Mr Burns, when he contacted my office last night, asked a series of questions about photographs and files in relation to the Bureau's activities. I want to make it clear that only files and photographs kept by the ABCI related to persons known or suspected to be involved in criminal activity of a kind covered by its charter. Therefore, I can assure the honourable member and the Australian public that any citizens who do not fit this criterion are not the subject of the ABCI's records. Of course this policy has been transgressed in this instance and the Government apologises to the two journalists concerned for that transgression. The Director has expressed his regret and assured me that there will be no recurrence of this incident. I should also make it quite clear that the request for the photographs was in no way connected with the fact that the reporters concerned had written articles published in the Age on police telephone taps. The ABCI is not and has not been involved in the inquiries now being conducted by Special Prosecutor Temby.

As indicated, I am seeking to discuss the matter of accreditation procedures for journalists to the ABCI at the next Police Ministers meeting. Under the inter-governmental agreement establishing the Bureau-which, I add, was a very sensible step by the previous Government in an attempt to get some co-ordination between the various police forces-ultimate responsibility for the ABCI in matters of policy rests with the Australian Police Ministers Council, although the agreement also provides that the Bureau shall be independent of any one participating government and administratively accountable through a management committee of all Australian police commissioners, who report annually to the Council. I have approved the tabling in this Parliament of an annual report on national common police services under the auspices of the Australian Police Ministers Council, including the activities of the ABCI. The report is currently being printed and will be tabled in the current sittings of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Why was the time of 1 p.m. on 24 June 1982 selected for the operation of clause 8 of the Income Tax Assessment Bill (No. 5), which disallows taxation deductions attributable to ownership of property which is used, among other things, in tax exempt activities? Will this apply in future to joint venture developments similar to the Eraring power station and the Maritime Services Board coal loader in Newcastle despite the fact that the end user, at least in part, is engaged in tax exempt activities but the owner/user is producing taxable income?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One o'clock on 24 June 1982 was the date and time announced by the former Treasurer when giving notice of the fact that transactions or arrangements similar to those entered into by certain parties in the New South Wales Government, I think in respect of the Eraring power station, had prompted him to make that announcement. In that respect the Government has achieved continuity by making the legislation retrospective to that time. I understand that the Eraring project and the Newcastle coal loader project will not be affected by the provisions as they are based on contracts entered into, I think, before 24 June 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: I am unable to give any other precise details of which other companies or consortiums are likely to be affected, because that information is contained in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation and, under the secrecy provisions, is not available to me. The purpose of the measure is to ensure that tax exempt bodies do not obtain tax benefits such as the investment allowance through the device of leverage leasing which was used at that time and which, I am certain, would have been used on a much wider scale had the measure not been proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence: What are the technical and safety factors and the strategic and operational circumstances which would determine his acceptance of requests by allied and friendly nuclear nations for their warships to be dry-docked in Australia? Would his new policy permit the dry- docking of HMS Invincible at some future date in the same circumstances as led the Government to refuse to allow it to be dry-docked before this new policy was announced? If so, has the Minister apologised to the Government of the United Kingdom because HMS Invincible was not dry-docked? If not, can he assure the House that, as a result, the ANZUS arrangements for the United States are not now prejudiced?

—Firstly, the question contains a considerable amount of hypothetical matter and an allegation which is untrue. I repeat, the allegation that the Australian Government refused to allow the Invincible to dry-dock is untrue. The fact is that the statement I announced on Sunday is a statement which was agreed between the governments of the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Australia. It is a statement with which we will comply. It indicates, quite clearly, that matters relating to any circumstance of a request will be assessed at the time and on the basis of the circumstances at that time.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Does the Government regard it as a matter of concern that apprentice intakes have fallen dramatically since 1981? If so, what action does the Government intend to take to reverse this trend?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the honourable member that the Government does view with great concern the fact that there has been a very substantial decline in the intake of apprentices. In 1982-83 there was a fall of 15,000, or 32 per cent, which is the worst fall ever recorded. In 1983-84, unless other action is taken, we are likely to see some slight increase, but not a substantial increase, in that number. That has significant implications for the economy and, indeed, for youth unemployment in this country. Obviously such a decline deprives 15,000 young people of the opportunity to become apprentices. It has impacts also on the availablity of skilled workers. A recent study by the Federal and State departments of labour in this country showed that we need an intake of 37,000 to 44,000 a year just to replace wastage from the current trades labour force of around half a million.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is very concerned about this matter. It is also concerned in this context about the fact that outside the trade of hairdressing only 2 per cent of all apprentices are female. Since we are committed to increasing opportunities for females in the labour market, we are very concerned about that . The Government has taken a number of responses so far-they are of a relatively minor nature so I will not detain the House with them at the moment-to try to make some impact on the apprenticeship intake situation. It is now clear that, unless something more substantial is done, this year we will have an intake increase of only 2,000 over the 34,000 of last year. To meet that situation the Government has decided to introduce a four point proposal which will cost around $19m over three years.

Specifically, the measures which we will introduce are: Firstly, a special additional employment incentive of a $1,500 tax exempt payment for each additional apprentice in training on 30 June this year compared with the level of training of apprentices for each employer last year. So for each additional apprentice in training there will be a $1,500 payment in addition to the normal Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full-time training. Secondly, there will be a $750 tax exempt payment for each additional female in apprenticeship training over the same period in all trades other than hairdressing. That will be payable in addition to the $1,500 where that is applicable. Thirdly, there will be a $ 750 tax exempt lump sum payment for each graduate of a pre-apprenticeship course taken on by an employer after 1 January this year. That will replace the existing premium on ordinary CRAFT rebates and is designed to encourage employers to take on young people who have been through these pre-apprenticeship courses for which we have provided for an extra 3,000 in the course of this year . Fourthly, we increased all CRAFT rebates by 4.3 per cent from 1 January this year to strengthen the assistance to all employers who are providing apprenticeship training.

Those measures represent a substantial package of incentives to employers in private industry to take on apprentices. I very much hope that employers, when they become aware of these measures and when they receive a letter from the Prime Minister, will take full note of what the Government is doing, recognise their responsibilities and greatly increase their apprenticeship intake. Certainly, the Government hopes strongly that they will see the importance of taking that step. In addition, the Government is investigating the level of apprenticeship training in its own establishments to ensure that its training effort is maximised. I hope to announce in the near future some steps to increase our own apprenticeship intake.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence a question which is supplementary to the one I asked earlier. I presume that the circumstances at the time to which the honourable gentleman referred are the strategic and operational circumstances referred to specifically in his statement. What are those circumstances? If he is not prepared to advise this House, does he accept that as a result our ANZUS allies must have the same uncertainty as that with which we are left and that our ANZUS arrangements are weakened?

—Our allies are satisfied with the terms of the statement. It is only the Opposition, which sees an opportunity to cause disunity and disruption by creating doubt, that is dissatisfied with the statement. I have nothing to add to the statement. It was agreed to by our allies. I would have thought that it would have the support of the Opposition, but cheap politics obviously have much more to do with it in its case than national interest.

—Is the Minister for Health aware that a significant number of doctors in Western Australia are choosing to present age pensioners with accounts rather than bulk bill them? Can the Minister say whether this draconian practice is widespread? Is there anything the Government can do to prevent doctors causing this distress to the elderly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the problem that has been raised by the honourable member for Canning. I understand that in her electorate at least two group practices-I think one in Kwinana Medina and another in Kelmscott-have publicly advertised that they will provide no bulk billing services. It is clearly the Government's preference that doctors should bulk bill. Firstly, this produces a major reduction in the community's health bill. To doctors and Medicare it brings administrative advantages. For doctors it removes the problem of bad debts. For patients it means that they do not have the worry of going and collecting a refund from the Medicare office. However, we have always accepted that some doctors have reasons, their own preferences, for not bulk billing all patients. The Government has always said that it would respect that right. But what we do regard as quite unacceptable is that doctors in their ideological opposition to Medicare should now refuse to bulk bill pensioners and the disadvantaged, whom for years they have bulk billed. That is the traditional practice, but for ideological reasons they are now punishing the old and the disadvantaged.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me give honourable members one example in relation to the honourable member 's constituency. The result of this activity in, I think, the Kelmscott service was that an aged pensioner of 89, on a day when the temperature was 42 degrees, was forced to collect a refund from the Medicare office because the doctor refused to bulk bill.

I believe that honourable members on both sides of this House will regard that kind of opposition to Medicare as wrong and unreasonable. They recognise that this Government does not, and its predecessors did not, have the power to compel doctors to bulk bill the disadvantaged and the pensioners. But let me say that this Government and the Health Ministers of at least every Labor State will take every opportunity to publicise these kinds of practices. While we recognise that there are reasonable objections which doctors can make, these kinds of practices are simply intolerable and will be presented to the public as so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In addition to the band-aid measures which he has just announced, is he prepared to negotiate with the States and the Australian Council of Trade Unions to change the apprenticeship system so that the inequity under that system whereby before people can get training they must have a job will be removed so they can get vocational training without first having to get the job? Is the Government prepared to reimburse employers by paying, on their behalf, the payroll tax for the people additionally employed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the honourable member's description of these measures as a band-aid. They are a considerable advance on the measures introduced by the previous Government when it was concerned about a drop in the intake in about 1979-80. Far from being a band-aid I believe they will be a considerable incentive to employers to take on apprentices.

ANSWER.PARA: As regards the other measures which he has mentioned, it is our intention to ensure that there is a complete review of the assistance which is provided to employers and of the encouragement they are given to take on apprentices. Of course we have established a review of all of our labour market programs headed by Mr Kirby, the Director of the technical and further education colleges in Victoria. That committee will be reporting to the Government by the end of this year. If the honourable member has any bright ideas which he would like that committee to consider I invite him to make a submission to it. I am sure it will be very interested to consider any intelligent suggestions which he makes to it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPAIR OF ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY SHIPS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Defence been drawn to Press reports appearing in today's Brisbane Courier-Mail in which union officials call on the Federal Government to have Royal Australian Navy ships based in Brisbane repaired in Cairncross Dockyard? Can the Minister inform the House why Australian naval ships are not repaired at the Cairncross Dockyard? Will any ships be repaired there in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the newspaper article, both by the honourable member for Griffith and by Senator Jones. The article is basically correct; naval ships are repaired at yards in Ballina and Bundaberg, which are period contractors for the Royal Australian Navy. Cairncross is not a period contractor. The Queensland Government owns the facility and is prepared to accept work only when the dry dock is involved. If any other work is required, it is necessary for the Navy to engage a second contractor.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government of Queensland does not allow the yard to enter into Commonwealth contracts, for reasons that we do not know. Period contractors do exist in the Brisbane area, but Cairncross is not one of them. It is anticipated that when HMAS Tobruk undergoes a refit the work will be done in Brisbane by one of the period contractors.

It is also alleged in the article that the Commonwealth Government has poured money into the Ballina yard. I am unable to find any record of defence investment in that shipyard, and I am informed the the Department of Transport is also unable to find any record of such investment. If Cairncross is being disdavantaged by the present situation I suggest that those employed there take the matter up with the Queensland Government, and perhaps the practices of the management of that yard can be changed so that it can compete for Commonwealth work. I should also indicate that Ballina and Bundaberg are successful in obtaining work over Brisbane because there is a significant cost penalty in getting work done in Brisbane compared with the costs involved in the other yards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer him to the dry docking of allied ships. In view of his answer to previous questions, that each case would be treated on its merits, I ask him: What would happen if HMS Invincible were to return in the same condition as it was when it was here last? Would that ship be dry docked in Australia?

—The question by the honourable member for McPherson is a hypothetical one. Should HMS Invincible return under exactly the same circumstances, negotiations would be resumed where they were broken off.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Is it a fact, as reported in this morning's Launceston Examiner, that the Minister has not been invited jointly to open the international rowing course at Lake Barrington this Saturday? Did the Commonwealth make funds available for the establishment of this course? When projects are jointly funded with States what is the normal arrangement about the performance of official opening ceremonies? Has the Minister been given any undertaking by the Tasmanian Government that the Commonwealth contribution to this project is to be acknowledged on Saturday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unhappily, it is a fact that I was told by the Tasmanian Minister that I was not allowed to speak at the opening of this rowing course in Tasmania on Saturday despite the fact that it has been jointly funded by the State and Commonwealth Governments. It is also a fact that this course, among a whole series of projects of a sporting nature in Tasmania, was funded conjointly. We in fact contributed $0.7m to the building of this international rowing course at Lake Barrington. I must observe that this is occurring with quite regular frequency in non-Labor States. It recently occurred in the Northern Territory when I was not invited to participate in the opening of an athletics stadium that was built, also jointly by the State and the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.PARA: In contrast, I recall an instance in New South Wales when the State Minister, Mr Cleary, and I jointly laid the foundation stone for an indoor sports stadium in that State, built jointly by the Commonwealth and the State. It seems to be a very childish attitude on the part of the Tasmanian Government because, very clearly, this Australian Government, the Hawke Government, has been the greatest benefactor to sport of any government that has existed in Australia since Federation. I know quite openly that the rowing authorities are very concerned about the snub by the Tasmanian--

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't get an invitation.

—Well, the honourable member is a typical Tasmanian. The public will not be fooled by this snub, by this crude attempt by the Tasmanian Government to grab the kudos for the building of this project. The Tasmanian people know where the funds came from, particularly if they read the Launceston Examiner this morning. Quite clearly, this tactic is part of Mr Gray's continuing tactic towards an early election. He is continually belabouring this Labor Government and claiming that Tasmania is being discriminated against in terms of Commonwealth funding to the States. This is clearly not the case.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course that argument would fall very clearly to the ground if there was to be a joint opening of this facility; people would know where the funds came from . It is about time that the Tasmanian Government started to tell the truth about the facts of life. Certainly its attitude will make no difference to us. We will continue to fund in a very even handed fashion sporting facilities around this country in every State in order that Australian youth will have an opportunity to compete on equal terms with their opposites in other countries. I can assure honourable members that we will do that however petty and however grubby the attitude of State governments like the Tasmanian Government is to these policies .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Defence. It follows the answer that he just gave. In his earlier advice to the House that there was no approach or request by the British to dry dock the Invincible, how can he now refer, as he just did, to negotations being broken off? Who was negotiating, at what stage were the negotiations broken off and for what reason and, therefore, in which answer has he misled the House?
—Discussions took place, as I think the honourable member knows as well as I do, between the Royal Australian Navy and the British Royal Navy.
—But you said there was no request.

—We talk about things quite often without having someone request something from us. The British Government ultimately advised that it did not wish to use facilities in Australia, for operational reasons. The facts are as they were stated previously. They have not changed. The statement which has been issued by me, after agreement with our allies, is a statement which will ensure that the problems of no policy being in existence, as was the case when we came to office following the previous Government, do not occur again.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware of an ongoing dispute between the Tasmanian Aboriginal community and the Liberal Government of that State relating to the disposal of human remains currently being held by the Tasmanian Museum?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the problem to which the honourable member referred. A collection of human bones is currently held by the Tasmanian Museum. It has become known as the Crowther collection but should be more correctly entitled the Oyster Cove collection. While I was in Tasmania last week I had the opportunity to meet with representatives of several Aboriginal groups at Oyster Cove. I considered it important to meet with these people because Tasmania remains somewhat of an outpost with respect to the status given to Aboriginal people and their rights. The issue was one of several that were raised with me by the Aboriginal community last week. It is important that honourable members should be informed of the background of this dispute.
—Oh!
—Well, it is important to those people. It is important that honourable members should be informed. From a period from about October 1847 to 1876 a number of Aboriginal people were buried--
—You are giving us a history lesson.

—I propose to. They were buried in a cemetery at Oyster Cove and in 1908 Professor Berry, an anatomist, asked William Crowther, then a medical student, if he could obtain skeletons of Tasmanian Aborigines for him.

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. There is a responsibility on Ministers at Question Time to answer questions concisely. I do not think there is any need whatsoever to enter into a discussion of history at this time when the Minister has an opportunity to make a statement.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—If the honourable member for O'Connor was buried, he could be certain that the Leader of the Opposition would not dig him up.
—I point out to honourable members that if they interrupt answers, they are only lessening their opportunity to ask questions and receive answers.
—Crowther went to the Oyster Cove Cemetery in 1909 with three of his colleagues. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I led a team to rob the graveyard here. We met at the churchyard and we started to dig. We exhumed about, there must have been nearly a dozen of the poor creatures.

Crowther donated the remains to the Tasmanian Museum in January 1963. It is not clear exactly what was originally excavated but it is clear that some of the material was lost at various times before 1963. What is present now in the Museum from Crowther's excavations at Oyster Cove are seven skulls and two boxes of post-cranial bones. In addition, there are two skulls from two others who were at Oyster Cove, known as Augustus and Caroline. There is also the skull of Waubedaba, who was not at Oyster Cove, but is a known individual. These three skulls should be considered as part of the collection with which the negotiations are concerned.

Around the turn of the century there was in fact a brisk trade in Aboriginal skeletons. The last person, William Laney, not only had his head, hands and ears cut off before his body was cold, all in the name of science, but also his skin used to make a tobacco pouch. It is under these circumstances that Aboriginal people in Tasmania feel with some sensitivity that the remains of people who are their ancestors ought to be respectfully and decently interred in accordance with their wishes.

I have had discussions with the Attorney-General in Tasmania. I have expressed the view that I do not believe that this is an area that ought to be the subject of confrontation either between the Commonwealth or the State. It is something which, if handled with some sensitivity and having regard to the needs and wishes of Aboriginal people, could be fixed up quickly. We have had positive discussions and I am hopeful that the Tasmanian Government will act quickly in respect of this matter and in a way which will make it unnecessary for any further Commonwealth intervention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the next question, I observe that at times the Chair does not have any power over the length of answers. While the Minister's answer was completely relevant, I hope Ministers will co-operate with me in trying to have brevity of answers.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Has any change been made to the policy of issuing free copies of the Queen's photograph to community groups? Are copies of the Queen's photograph readily available? If the Queen's photograph is available, why are copies of the coat of arms now being substituted for the photograph of the Queen in the items issued with the Australian flag?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no change in the policy. If community groups request a portrait of Her Majesty it shall be supplied.

—My question is directed to the excellent Minister for Transport. Given the vital importance of railways to my electorate of Grey, particularly to the railway workers at Port Pirie, Peterborough and Port Augusta, can the Minister confirm that an examination is currently being made of the standardisation of the Melbourne to Adelaide line?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his very important question. Railway efficiency and financial performance are critical to the economy of South Australia and particularly to the electorate of Grey. I am able to confirm that an investigation is currently under way by the Australian National Railways Commission and the State Transport Authority of Victoria into the standardisation of the rail link between Melbourne and Adelaide. My understanding is that such a project would comprise a new standard gauge line from Melbourne to Geelong and a third rail being laid on the existing line between Geelong and Tailem Bend in South Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that there would be significant advantages in such a project. For instance, it would reduce the rail freight time between Melbourne and the west of the continent by some 24 hours. It would complete the inter-capital standard gauge rail link and it certainly would result in considerably reduced operational costs for both VicRail and Australian National Railways. It would improve the efficiency and quality of service of the inter-system network around the continent. The matter is still under investigation and, as with all projects or this importance and with these financial implications, it is essential that there be a comprehensive financial analysis of the costs and benefits. My understanding is that the report of that analysis should be available in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Primary Industry by drawing his attention to the fact that the present formula for setting dairy underwriting levels was due to be revised at the end of the 1982-83 financial year. Does he regard the formula as being outdated and seriously disadvantaging dairy farmers? If so, will he undertake to draft a new formula which will increase underwriting levels for the financial year 1984-85?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see no change in the basing components of the underwriting formula. There is a set formula. A review of the general industry organisation arrangements will take place during the review now under way following receipt of the Industries Assistance Commission report. We have a working party of the Standing Committee on Agriculture following a meeting of the Agricultural Council in Perth. It will look at all matters, including price setting mechanisms, the organisation of the Australian Dairy Corporation and any system of arriving at underwriting levels.

ANSWER.PARA: The other formula or arrangement that the honourable member could be reflecting on is the arrangement between the Commonwealth and the Australian Dairy Corporation with respect to the setting of the domestic wholesale price of milk for levy purposes. There are 10 criteria, of which one is not entirely agreed upon by the Commonwealth, the ADC and the dairy industry. By and large there is not much conflict among the parties concerned. That tenth criteria on which there is some debate is mainly about the international price of milk and how much that should influence the price we set for wholesale price determinations. All I can honestly say to the honourable member is that all this is now under intensive scrutiny on three levels, the Standing Committee working party, the Commonwealth Government's committee that is looking at a formal response to the IAC report, and also the committee comprising the Department, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Australian Dairy Corporation and the dairy industry itself. All matters will be looked at.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Special Minister of State. In view of the large disparities between the net voter enrolments of Federal electorates and the recently announced redistribution of electoral boundaries involving the creation of 23 new electorates, can he advise when the redistribution will be completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that honourable members have a certain interest in this question . I suspect that already a fair bit of homework has been done on boundaries. The likely timetable of the Electoral Commission is that the redistribution will be under way almost immediately. The appointees to the various State Electoral Offices will be announced very shortly. The committees will also be announced and the redistribution will be under way. The timetable will be such that redistribution in the smaller States will probably be completed after the first maps are produced and the objections received. The Commission then makes its final declaration. Even the larger States, which will take a little longer, should have their redistributions completed by September of 1983.

—I might have made a mistake with the year, but Malcolm wishes I was right. For the benefit of honourable members who, I know, have only a slight interest in the subject, the submissions will be called almost immediately. The first reports will be out by mid-year. The objections will be received and the final reports of the Commission, which, as honourable members well realise, are not subject to parliament, will be out of the way in all States by September this year.
