DEBATE.TITLE: ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON REPATRIATION LEGISLATION REVIEW

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the report of the Advisory Committee on Repatriation Legislation Review, together with the text of a statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs relating to the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs presented its report , 'Strategies to help overcome the problems of aboriginal town camps', in October 1982. It was presented by the then Chairman of the Standing Committee, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), and the Government would like to record its appreciation of the conscientious work done by the Standing Committee , and particularly by the honourable member for Dundas. The Committee provided a working definition of 'town campers' as:

SPEECH.PARA: Any group of Aboriginals living at identified camp sites near or within towns or cities which form part of the socio-cultural structure of the towns and cities, but which have a lifestyle that does not conform to that of the majority of non-Aboriginal residents and are not provided with essential services and housing on a basis comparable to the rest of the community.
The foreword of the report says:

Aboriginals are generally acknowledged to be the most disadvantaged group in Australian society. The fringe-dwellers or town campers as they are referred to in the report, are the most disadvantaged section within the Aboriginal group. It was glaringly apparent to the Committee that the deplorable conditions in which town campers live, not only in a physical sense but also in social and economic senses, are of urgent concern to all Australians.
While small in numbers (less than 20,000), they are the real losers of today.

To be the most deprived members of Australia's most disadvantaged minority-the Aboriginal people-is to know true deprivation. Name a disadvantage or a social problem and the town campers suffer it: Offensive unsanitary conditions; abominable housing-if the pitiful shelters can be called that in many cases; virtually no employment prospects; inadequate education; and all the physical and mental health problems including alcohol abuse, social tension and frequent violence that accompany despair, anguish and hopelessness.

The Standing Committee's report and recommendations provide a most valuable starting point for the development of the integrated and co-ordinated program of assistance that is needed if we are to succeed in removing these disadvantages.
The Past and the Present

The root causes of the town camp problem lie in the past. Town camps, in many areas, were the last remaining refuge for a proud and dignified people who were forced to move from their traditional lands, to pastoral stations, to government settlements, to missions, and then on again from these impermanent places. The growing populations in towns naturally meant further encroachments on Aboriginal traditional land, resulting in Aboriginals being pushed out to the fringes. The quite appalling economic and social results of the dispersal and dispossession which have led to the town camper situation have been fully documented by the Committee. It makes grim reading.

After the 1967 referendum, and a general acceptance of Aboriginal rights in the seventies, some improvements took place in town camps-housing was provided in town for some who wanted to make the move. As well, some housing and facilities were upgraded in town camps and reserves, and land tenure by way of leases was provided in some cases. In addition the outstation movement has provided an outlet for some, particularly in the Northern Territory. However, for the great majority of town camps nothing much has changed, and cannot change unless the problems are dealt with as a whole.
The Future

The Committee made recommendations which covered the complexities of the problems. In response to these recommendations and the Committee's overall report, the Government has decided to adopt a multi-faceted, co-ordinated and integrated program to be known as the town campers assistance program. This program will reflect the complexities inherent in these situations by involving myself, my State and Territory counterparts, their colleagues responsible for local government and lands, local government authorities, Commonwealth Government Departments and Authorities, national and local Aboriginal organisations, general community groups and, most importantly, the people who are most affected by the problems-the Aboriginal town campers themselves. These organisations and individuals will be involved in the town campers assistance program to varying degrees but the contribution of all to the program will be guided by the principles of consultation, Aboriginal self-determination and the need to develop flexible responses to the individual needs of each community rather than meeting any one particular need on a national basis. To achieve this , a local consultation process involving officers within the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, including the National Aboriginal Conference, will be further developed. The consultation process will then allow the community to identify its needs and relay them to the Government and other authorities which can then help develop and implement effective, localised programs. The consultation arrangements will ensure that Aboriginal women are directly consulted and involved in the decision making process. Town camper communities will therefore be involved in determining the form of consultation, their priorities and the appropriate agencies to meet their needs. The willingness of the appropriate agencies to meet the needs of the town campers is crucial to the success of the town campers assistance program. Of particular importance is the support and co- operation of State and local government authorities. It is relevant to mention here that State and Territory Ministers entered into a commitment at the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council meeting in July to provide Aboriginal citizens with at least the same level of services that are provided to other citizens.

Although I have been referring to the future and to what will happen, in fact the town campers assistance program has already begun to operate. My Department has earmarked a total of $4m for expenditure on town camps in 1983-84. These funds will be spent in conjunction with the Aboriginal Development Commission and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. It is also interesting to note that even at this early stage of the program, two State Governments, New South Wales and Western Australia, have entered into joint funding arrangements with the Commonwealth in respect of certain projects. This demonstrable co-operation in New South Wales and Western Australia is in marked contrast to the situation in Queensland. The Queensland authorities declined to present any views or attitudes to the House of Representatives Standing Committee when it undertook its investigations. I will now mention several key aspects of the program.
Land Tenure

The question of land tenure is recognised by the Committee as a threshold issue to be resolved in the development of programs of assistance. Apart from the sense of security which comes from tenure there is also a practical economic reason-substantial improvements in facilities cannot be made without a guarantee of security over the land on which the improvements are to be made. I will do everything in my power, through legislation and special arrangement, to gain land tenure for those campers who currently lack it.
Excisions

The Committee also recognised the needs of former residents of pastoral leases living in town camps who want to return to live on those leases, and recommended that procedures be developed to make this happen. The Committee considered that the granting of excisions could arrest the drift of Aboriginal people into town camps from pastoral properties. The question of excisions is a most important one not only for town campers but also, of course, for Aboriginal people already resident on pastoral leases, but having no secure tenure over the land on which they live. In respect of the Northern Territory, Mr Justice Toohey, in his recent report, has recommended that Northern Territory legislation be enacted to provide a machinery for consideration of excision applications by a tribunal headed by a Northern Territory Supreme Court judge and, where excisions are recommended, for these to be held as freehold land by Aboriginal land trusts. I have had discussions with the Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, concerning early implementation of these proposals. Last year I wrote to a large number of Territory pastoralists urging them to negotiate in-principle agreements with Aboriginal applicants. The response of the pastoralists and their cattlemen's organisations has been a generally positive one and I commend them for it. Resolution of as many problems as possible, in advance of tribunal involvement, should make the tribunal's work a good deal easier and quicker. In Western Australia, the only other State for which excisions are a significant issue, administrative action has been taken by the State Government to resolve outstanding excision requests. For the longer term, the Seaman inquiry into land rights in Western Australia is expected to recommend the most appropriate method for achieving excisions.
Local Government Co-operation

The Committee noted the important role of local government authorities on the matters of land tenure and the delivery of services to Aboriginal camps. Local government decisions have an immediate impact on the daily lives of campers. Some authorities have been sympathetic and generous. Others, I regret to say, think that they have a responsibility to ordinary ratepayers only. This has meant that the people living on the fringes of towns have often been ignored and have gone without essential services. Officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and other portfolio agencies are initiating discussions with local government authorities to find ways of overcoming some of the current barriers to the provision of equitable services to Aboriginal town campers. Where appropriate, arrangements will be made to employ Aboriginal liaison officers to identify needs and assist peope to utilise local government facilities. This arrangement is now working, and working well, in a number of local government areas, for example, at Port Augusta.
Improvements in Living Conditions

Australia has been criticised, with justification, for allowing conditions to continue in some Aboriginal communities which are similar to those in underdeveloped countries of the Third World. The provision of adequate housing and shelter will play a key role in the Government's strategy towards improving the living conditions of Aboriginals in town camps. We do not, however, want to repeat the mistake of the assimilationist policies of the 1950s by expecting campers to live in urban, western-style settings. Some campers have tried conventional housing and have rejected it. We do not pretend to know exactly what types of housing and facilities campers want-they have to tell us, and we have to make their choice possible. The challenge is to develop appropriate technologies and styles of dwellings through consultation with the people who will use them. The task of providing accommodation will be shared by my Department, the Aboriginal Development Commission, Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, and the Department of Social Security through its homeless persons assistance program, as well as the States. All of these agencies will be responsible, with the National Aboriginal Conference, for consultation about housing. The Government has increased by $23.8m, or 28 per cent, to a total of $108m, the funds for Aboriginal housing and accommodation in the current financial year. Of this, $13m has been allocated to Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, $43m to the Aboriginal Development Commission and $52m has been earmarked for Aboriginal housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Although this is a creditable response to a very important area of need, we are under no illusion about how much more still needs to be done.
Employment

Town campers have not benefited to any extent from most of the Aboriginal employment programs and unemployment is at very high levels. Most camps depend almost entirely on welfare payments. We will make sure that the town campers benefit from government employment schemes, such as the community employment program, which will receive a total of $300m in the current fnancial year.

Within my portfolio, my Department's special work program this year received a 73.4 per cent increase over last year's allocation. The Aboriginal Development Commission and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd will also assist through their programs directed to the employment of Aboriginals. The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations will give high priority to the provision of appropriate training for the future employment of town campers under the training for Aboriginals programs.
Public Awareness

Very high among the problems town campers experience is the unsympathetic attitude shown by many Australians. The conditions in which campers live are taken by many people to mean that campers themselves are, in some peculiar way, unworthy of the types of services and opportunities which the rest of the nation take for granted. The Government has begun a public awareness program designed to help promote a climate of understanding about the problems of town campers and the Aboriginal situation as it is today.
Concluding Remarks

Mr Speaker, the Standing Committee is to be commended for drawing attention to the very real difficulties faced by town camper, outstation and pastoral property communities. I have outlined the Government's multi-faceted response which involves more employment; improved living conditions; security of tenure; and public awareness; and which overall seeks to enable Aboriginal town campers to gain for themselves, a better future. If we are to succeed, governments, Aboriginal organisations and individuals, and members of the wider Australian community must all work together. The Australian Government is determined that the town camper program will succeed. Common humanity demands that we succeed.

In conjunction with the NAC, we will monitor progress. Each year, a situation report on each town camp community will be provided to Parliament and be made available to State and Territory governments, relevant local government authorities and to the communities themselves. This annual report will show us how much has been achieved and indicate how much more remains to be done. Let me assure honourable members that this Government will not stand by and allow Aboriginal people to be denied a fair go.

Mr Speaker, I present a schedule providing the Government's response to each of the recommendations made by the Standing Committee. I present also a schedule showing in summary form, the existing situation in respect of the town camps identified in the Committee's report. I table the schedules and I also seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.
Leave granted.

GOVERNMENT RESPONSES TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES' STANDING COMMITTEE ON ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS' REPORT ''STRATEGIES TO HELP OVERCOME THE PROBLEMS OF ABORIGINAL TOWN CAMPS''
Recommendations
Present situation
Proposed response
Local Government Liaison with Town Camps
1. That the Department of Aboriginal Affairs:

(a) initiate discussions with local government authorities with town camping communities within their boundaries (identified in Appendix VI) about establishing Aboriginal liaison committees and/or appointing Aboriginal liaison officers;
(b) initiate discussions with local government authorities, identified in Appendix VI, to develop projects for the provision of services to town camps; and
(c) provide funding to local government authorities where suitable projects are developed;
Aboriginal Liaison Committees/Officers:
New South Wales. Partly implemented. Some Shire Councils have appointed youth or community workers with State funds.
Queensland. Mt Isa, Cairns, Townsville.
South Australia. Port Augusta.
Western Australia. Halls Creek, Kwinana.
Northern Territory Darwin area, Jabiur, Katherine, Alice Springs.

(a) Endorsed in principle. A feature of the proposed arrangements for the town campers program is the development of local level consultative procedures. Consultation arrangements will ensure that Aboriginal women are directly consulted and directly involved in decision making. Members of the town camping communities, with assistance from DAA and Aboriginal organisations will be encouraged to identify needs and formulate programs. Discussions with Local Government Authorities will be conducted at this level and local arrangemens will vary accordingly. The establishment of Aboriginal liaison officers will be encouraged. Aboriginal liaison committees have been established and Aboriginal liaison officers appointed in a number of localities.

(b) The Minister has written to State Ministers responsible for Aboriginal Affairs seeking their co-operation in the town campers program and that of their colleagues responsible for local government and lands. It would be for the local level consultative groups to discuss with Local Government and other Authorities projects for the provision of services to town camps. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs will assist as appropriate.

(c) The Government will consider appropriate funding for projects identified at the local level. Attempts will be made to encourage State and Local Government authorities to share in the provision of services. Where possible funding by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs will be in the form of grants to Aboriginal organisations.
Alcohol
2. Each State and the Northern Territory establish a co-ordinating committee on Aboriginal alcohol problems with significant Aboriginal participation;
State Co-ordinating Committees on Aboriginal alcohol problems have been established in New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia.

The future direction of the State Committees in South Australia and New South Wales is currently under discussion and at present they only meet infrequently. The Western Australian Committee meets monthly. All the above committees have at least a majority Aboriginal representation.

Victoria. Alcohol problems are dealt with by the Victorian Aboriginal Health Resources Consultative Group, an all Aboriginal body, which includes a member representing the Aboriginal alcohol projects in that State.
Queensland. The recently formed Aboriginal and Islander Health Advisory Council provides the opportunity for expression of Aboriginal views on alcohol matters.
Northern Territory. Two of the five members of the Northern Territory Drug and Alcohol Committees are Aboriginal.

Endorsed. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs has recognised the significance of alcohol problems in Aboriginal communities, and has been assisted by the findings and recommendations of the Standing Committee's Final Report on ' Alcohol Problems of Aboriginals'. The Department will consult with the National Aboriginal Conference, the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation and with the Australian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependency which has, in the past, provided advice on Aboriginal projects. State Co-ordinating Committees on Aboriginal alcohol problems have been established in New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia. In Victoria and Queensland, Aboriginal committees on health advise on alcohol matters. In the Northern Territory two of the five members of the Drug and Alcohol Advisory Committee are Aboriginal.
Homeless Drifters
3. The Department of Social Security, as the Department responsible for the administration of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act:
(a) encourage the appropriate local government authority and relevant Aboriginal organisation to apply for funding for the establishment of night shelters for homeless Aboriginals; and
(b) give favourable consideration to such requests for funding when the need for such shelters is established;
In 1981-82, the Government allocated $10m to a three year capital program for homeless persons for which $1.2m was earmarked for Aboriginal projects.

In 1982-83, the Department of Social Security, under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act, has provided funds to a total of nine Aboriginal organisations in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, and Northern Territory. The amount comprises 20 per cent of the 1982-83 allocation for homeless pesons. (The Department of Social Security is currently funding the construction of ablution blocks and shelters for town campers in Camooweal, Queensland.)

The Homeless Persons Assistance Act provides for Aboriginal organisations and other non-Government organisations as well as Local Government Authorities to seek funding to establish shelters for homeless Aboriginals. The Homeless Persons Assistance Program is currently being reviewed along with a number of crisis accommodation programs. The Transients

4. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs be responsible for, and consult with local Aboriginal communities, relevant local government authorities and Aboriginal Hostels Limited about evaluating the need for alternative style accommodation for transients.
Reviews have been undertaken by Aboriginal Hostels Limited in conjunction with DAA Regional and Area Offices in the Northern Territory and elsewhere.

Agreed. Identification of the need for alternative accommodation for transients will take place at the local level. 5. Funding be provided to an appropriate agency to establish transient facilities where the need for such facilities has been established.

Aboriginal Hostels Limited currently operates or funds 15 hostels for transients (which provide 453 beds) one in Victoria, four in Queensland, five in Western Australia, four in the Northern Territory and one in South Australia.

In Western Australia the Department of Aboriginal Affairs funds two organisations which provide accommodation for transients, namely the Anglican Health and Welfare Services Nungar Shelter in Perth and the Bloodwood Tree Association in Port Hedland.

Aboriginal Hostels Limited or existing Aboriginal housing co-operatives would seem the appropriate groups to establish transient facilities, Aboriginal Hostels Limited currently operates 15 hostels for transients and would generally be the appropriate authority to establish transient facilities. The Government will give favourable consideration to further financial support for Aboriginal Hostels Limited where needs are demonstrated. Transient facilities would not need to be provided with essential services.
6. The charter of Aboriginal Hostels Limited be reviewed to allow it to provide alternative type accommodation for transients where it is the appropriate funding agency.

The 1979 Commonwealth-Aboriginal Hostels Agreement limits Aboriginal Hostels Limited (AHL) to the provision of temporary or semi-permanent accommodation. The Review of the AHL Charter is nearing completion and a Submission will be put to the Minister shortly. AHL has been involved in the provision of alternative- style accommodation at Parkeston (near Kalgoorlie) and Camooweal (near Mt Isa) which is funded under the Homeless Persons Assistance Program. There is a need to clarify AHL's role in provision of alternative type accommodation for transients.

The Charter of Aboriginal Hostels Limited provides for the Company to operate within guidelines, agreed upon between the Minister and the Company each year. Amendment to the Agreement or the Charter will ensure that the Company can meet the needs of transient people for accommodation and other necessary facilities.
7. Local Aboriginal organisations be given the responsibility for operating transient accommodation wherever possible.
Currently 62 of the 117 hostels funded by Aboriginal Hostels Limited are operated by local Aboriginal organisations under its Third Party Program.

Supported. Transient accommodation is provided by Aboriginal Hostels Limited in association with other Aboriginal organisations. Local Aboriginal organisations are given the responsibility for operating transient accommodation wherever possible. Aboriginal Hostels Limited Third Party Agreements combine local management participation and Hostels' expertise, and are to be encouraged.
8. In the construction of such accommodation the design should be appropriate to the needs of the campers.

The first such modified hostel built by Aboriginal Hostels Limited was the Syd Ross Hostel in Alice Springs (1976). Since then Aboriginal Hostels Limited has developed a number of new designs in line with the needs and circumstances of the Aboriginal groups concerned, most recently at Parkeston, Western Australia and Camooweal, Queensland. The Company has designed aged persons accommodation and nursing homes, for example, an aged persons home in Alice Springs which accommodates tribal and non-tribal people.

Endorsed. In general, designs should seek to meet the requirements of the local communities. Liaison will need to be maintained with local government authorities to ensure that the designs meet the requirements of local building regulations. Negotiation may be required to have modified designs appropriate to the needs of the transients approved by local government authorities.

Powers and responsibility of local government authorities (mandatory/permissive) vary greatly between the States. In some States (Western Australia, Victoria) local government authorities have little responsibility and some would be unwilling to assume responsibility.
New South Wales. Local government authorities are unable or unwilling to provide services for those town campers living on freehold estates.

Western Australia. Essential services provided by DAA to the State Energy Commission, Public Works Department (in part) and communities themselves funded by DAA.
Generally. Local government authorities have been unable to provide much assistance.

The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations was allocated $25.76m this financial year for employment and training programs which will assist over 4,700 Aboriginals. $16.524m has been allocated towards assisting 1,700 Aboriginals to take up training in public sector departments, authorities and organisations-$3. 156m towards formal training assistance for some 900 Aboriginal trainees-$4.68m for employer subsidies in the private sector for on-the-job training assistance for some 2,000 Aboriginals-$1.2m for 60 special courses to assist Aboriginals in areas where suitable training is not available. $.2m towards other assistance such as clothing allowance, fares, etc. to assist Aboriginals to take up or continue training or employment. Discussions took place during the term of the previous Government. Developments included:

Department of Health to Aboriginal controlled health services and an increase in the number of community controlled health services. - Aboriginal Health Organisation in South Australia to administer programs and provide Aboriginal advice to the State;

Not applicable in New South Wales and Victoria.

Northern Territory. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has written to the owners of 39 pastoral properties urging them to negotiate for excisions sought on their leases, a number of which involve town camp groups.

Endorsed. Since the 1971 Gibb Report only 11 pastoral lease excisions have been achieved in the Northern Territory, 3 in Western Australia, and 2 in South Australia. Western Australia. Since 1974 when the WA Government acted to provide an excision at Looma, only a further 2 excisions have been granted. South Australia. Two excisions have been approved. There appears to be no immediate pressure for further excisions.

Queensland. There are no known requests for excisions. Due to historical lack of protection for Aboriginal residence and entry to pastoral leases in Queensland, attachments appear to have been eroded over time.
Community Attitudes
33. That the Department of Aboriginal Affairs:
(a) actively pursue its proposal for a public awareness campaign to improve understanding of Aboriginal people and society in the wider community; and
(b) make a school-based education a particular focus of the campaign.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs conducts an Information Program directed at keeping Aboriginals and the wider community informed of current initiatives, policies and events in Aboriginal Affairs. Under this Program the Department has increased the flow of information about Aboriginals by producing a comprehensive information kit which has enabled targetting of information material to specific audiences at national and local levels. Much of this information is distributed to schools in support of school projects in relation to Aboriginals.

The Department commissioned a study of attitudes towards Aboriginals which has led to the development of proposals for a Public Awareness Program aimed at improving race relations specifically in rural areas.
In the 1983-84 Budget, the Department has been allocated an amount of $350,000 for public awareness activities and projects.

(a) Agreed. Following completion of a study of attitudes towards Aboriginals, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has increased the flow of information about Aboriginals through its Information Program and has developed a major proposal for a Public Awareness Program aimed at changing attitudes at the community level. The Department will consult with Aboriginals and relevant authorities on all aspects of the Public Awareness Program. Proposals being developed for the Public Awareness Program include support for: information on awareness projects initiated by Aboriginals; projects highlighting Government initiatives; encouraging the interest of the wider community in Aboriginal Arts; a television series for Aboriginals, community forums; community awareness campaigns and a school project kit. As in other information projects undertaken by the Department where expert advice is required, the Department will seek the advice of the Commonwealth Department of Education and the National Aboriginal Education Committee on the content and use of material considered of value to schools.

(b) Endorsed. Resource material such as the film series and project kit would support and enhance education about Aboriginals in schools. While the Public Awareness Program is not specifically oriented towards school-based education, schools would be encouraged to take advantage of the Program by participating in community forums including seminars and discussions led by Aboriginal people and visits to Aboriginal communities. Instead of these activities being exclusively for schools, the Department believes that they should be available to the entire community.

Policy discussions were held with most States during 1982.

(i) The Government is reviewing arrangements for the assessment of programs and determination of priorities in the broad context of the relationship between the Government and the National Aboriginal Conference.

(ii) A review of arrangements for funding of programs, including the funding of Aboriginal Medical Services is under consideration by a working party comprised of representatives of the N.A.C, and the Departments of Health and Aboriginal Affairs. This consideration is at an early stage. Definite approaches to review have not been determined pending resolution of the matters referred to in (i) above.

(b) The Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs and Health, in association with State/ Northern Territory Ministers for Health, continue to make provision for involvement of Aboriginals in the delivery of health care.
Cf. Recommendation 23

(b) The Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs and Health, in association with State/ Northern Territory Ministers for Health, will continue to make provision for involvement of Aboriginals in the delivery of health care.
(c) Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments and educational institutions be urged to provide training and scholarships for Aboriginals in medical, and para-medical fields of study.

In co-operation with the Department of Education, approaches have been made to professional health groups, Aboriginal Medical Services, tertiary institutions and State/NT health authorities about increasing opportunities in education and training in Aboriginal health. Developments include review of health worker training courses in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia, Northern Territory and special arrangements for Aboriginal nursing trainees in South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. In addition the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations provides special training programs for Aboriginals

(c) Current consultations with State/ Northern Territory authorities, tertiary institutions and professional groups are complemented by a review of scholarship scheme benefits. Normal Aboriginal Study Grants (Abstudy) benefits are available to those undertaking a wide range of courses including those related to the Health field. Assistance for full-time courses is not provided to those in receipt of income. The Abstudy scheme is under review by consultants, and a report is expected to be available in March 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I believe the Government responses to the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs ought to be incorporated in Hansard. I think by doing so a courtesy would be paid to the members of this House who have done a great deal of work in relation to this specific investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for providing me with a copy of his statement in advance of its being presented to the Parliament. I think that this arrangement assists the working of the Parliament. The report entitled ' Strategies to Help Overcome the Problems of Aboriginal Town Camps' was presented to the Parliament in October 1982. So some 16 months has elapsed between the tabling of the report and the presentation of this Government's response. This long delay is of concern to the Opposition. Whilst an election was held last March it has still taken a year for the Government to respond. Many members of parliament have put a great deal of work into this report and into similar reports. I think it is the duty of the Government to respond to the Parliament faster than it has done on this occasion.

The report arose out of a concern held by the previous Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, about the deplorable conditions in many fringe dweller camps. The Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs was asked to review the situation and this report was the result. The Opposition joins with the Minister in recording its appreciation for the detailed work done by all members of the Committee, especially the Chairman, Mr Philip Ruddock, the Liberal member for Dundas.

The Minister in his statement quoted parts of the report which highlight the grave situation faced by fringe dwellers and town campers around Australia. I only add to that by saying that just as when in government we were active in developing and pursuing policies to overcome these problems, so in opposition we continue to regard the resolution of these problems as needing to be given a very high priority.

I come to the report itself. The Standing Committee undertook considerable research into the problems of Aboriginal town campers or fringe dwellers and their particular socio-economic problems. It presented a series of wide ranging recommendations on how some of the problems identified by the Committee could be overcome. In particular, it made recommendations concerning the direction of funding for town campers, administrative improvements to facilitate the provision of services and the implementation of programs to assist town campers and more specific recommendations with respect to how the health, accommodation and employment problems of fringe dwellers could be overcome.

This is a very comprehensive report covering a broad area of activity and, as the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), has just said to me, this is one of the best reports into a very difficult problem. As I well know, the honourable member has a number of these camps in his electorate and he can see the benefit of the report and the implementation of its recommendations.

In general terms the recommendations of the Standing Committee fall into three categories. Firstly, there are the recommendations which are aimed at streamlining the administration and implementation of programs to assist town campers. These recommendations relate to liaison between departments, local government and State governments in the delivery of services to fringe dwellers. They are designed to improve existing programs and make them more effective and to involve the relevant authorities where their responsibilities cut across the boundaries of the responsibilities of other bodies.

The second category of recommendations involves the need to consult and include Aboriginal input in the planning and delivery of programs. This is in accordance with the need for consultation and a recognition that unless the Aboriginal people are closely involved there is a good chance that the programs ultimately will fail.

The third main category of recommendations refers to funding. It includes recommendations for more money for night shelters, transient facilities, houses and dwellings for town campers, the Aboriginal Development Corporation and a public awareness program. In addition-and this could perhaps be a fourth category but it is an isolated recommendation-there is a recommendation relating to land tenure. The Committee correctly recommended that the problems of land tenure must be overcome before other recommendations such as those relating to the provisions of water and sewerage services can be implemented.

The Government has agreed to nearly all of the Committee's recommendations. I want to look in detail at some of the responses by the Government but first I want to consider the statement by the Minister. The Minister outlined the setting up of a town campers assistance program. I welcome the involvement of all the government agencies and the Aboriginal organisations and communities in that program. It is essential that a co-operative approach be adopted.

The Minister then went into some detail about excisions. The Committee recommended that procedures be developed for excisions to be granted to Aboriginal communities on pastoral leases. The Northern Territory Government was moving in this direction last year. It had prepared legislation to do just that. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs then asked the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Paul Everingham, not to proceed with that legislation. He asked the Northern Territory Government to delay any action in relation to the implementation of that legislation until the Toohey report was handed down. It has been handed down and it recommended that the Northern Territory Government is the appropriate authority to implement such a policy for excisions. The Minister, after delaying the implementation of the Northern Territory legislation for about 12 months, is now saying that he had discussions with Mr Everingham concerning 'early implementation of these proposals'. The Minister's interference in this matter has led to a 12 months delay and no net benefit to the Aboriginal community.

I turn now to funding. The Minister has said continually-generally, in relation to this report and in response to some of the recom- mendations-that this Government has given a high priority to funding to overcome the problems facing Aboriginal communities. He said that funds had been greatly increased. The truth is that under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, for example, whilst there has been an increase in the total allocation of funds, the share going to meet the needs of the Aboriginal community is exactly the same as the amount provided by the previous Government. So the argument that this Government is giving a higher priority to funding housing for Aboriginal communities has a distinctly hollow ring about it.
I turn now to some of the specific recommendations. Recommendation 12 states:
An investigation take place to determine the responsibility for provision of essential services in those camps with land tenure.

It is clear that that recommendation addresses the fact that buildings alone will not solve the problems facing the Aboriginal communities. The last sentence of the Minister's response to this recommendation states:
Every effort will be made to ensure that the provision of essential services for town campers is integrated into existing systems for the provision of these facilities to the wider community.

That is a very imprecise and unclear statement of what this Government intends. It is an example of how the Australian Labor Party rhetoric about providing funds to overcome the dismal housing situation has not been matched by its action. The Opposition believes that the Government needs to give this matter more attention. It is a high priority issue and the response given by the Government is unsatisfactory.
Recommendation 16 states:
The Aboriginal Development Commission:
(a) present a program for meeting the housing requirements of Aboriginal town campers, both as to type and location of houses and dwellings, by 1988; and
(b) be provided with increased funding to enable it to meet these requirements.
In relation to this issue, the ADC, in its report tabled by the Minister this week, states:

In late 1982 a Commission survey revealed about 8,000 Aboriginal families were either on its waiting list for home loans or were living in appalling circumstances as town campers, not, at that time, having been registered with appropriate authorities for housing assistance. At the current rate of housing expenditure, which provides for about 500 additional homes a year this backlog will not be cleared for 16 years.
The recommendation was that the ADC present a program for meeting the housing requirements by 1988. The ADC--

TALK.START.PARA: —The bicentennial year.
—It is our bicentennial year, as the honourable member suggests.
—The Minister himself was very interested in this proposition.

—I think that is right. The recommendation was that this program be implemented and completed by 1988. The ADC says that it has no hope of completing if for at least 16 years. What is the Government's response to the recommendation? The response was that the Government has assigned high priority to meeting the housing backlog, including the housing needs of town campers, and has increased the allocation for Aboriginal welfare under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in 1983-84 to $52m. I have already addressed that aspect. That is exactly the same proportion of the total funds being allocated under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement as was allocated under the previous Government. The meaning of high priority is very doubtful. The Government's response continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Community Profile statistical collection is presently being revised. It will provide information on current housing and shelter needs, and form a basis for programs.
As I understand it, the ADC has done such a profile. I ask the Minister: Is this revision undertaken by the ADC or is it being undertaken by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs?

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been completed.
—It was completed by whom?
—By the ADC.

—I thank the Minister for that information. I was concerned that if it was to be undertaken by the DAA there would be unnecessary duplication. Going on with the Government's response, in paragraph (b) it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Responsibility for Aboriginal accommodation does not rest with the Aboriginal Development Commission alone. A co-ordinated approach is required involving implementing agencies and those with policy responsibilities or interests. Funding arrangements for Aboriginal Housing will be re-appraised in 1983-84 in the context of re-negotiation of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

That, to me, is a classic bit of bureaucratic jargon which makes absolutely no commitment. What this Parliament needs to know in relation to the recommendation from the Committee which has been outstanding for some 16 months is what the Government is going to do. That bureaucratic jargon is no answer.
I turn to recommendation 18, which says:
The Department of Aboriginal Affairs investigate expanding the Aboriginal Family Resettlement Program within New South Wales and extending the program to other States and the Northern Territory.
I am concerned that, whilst the Committee supported the Aboriginal family resettlement program, the response from the Government leaves the whole question up in the air. The response says:

Investigations will be conducted outside New South Wales to establish whether Aboriginals see resettlement as a priority. A review of the program in New South Wales is being conducted. Following the completion of the review, discussions will be held with the New South Wales government regarding continuation of the program and possible funding arrangements.

That response from the Government throws doubt on the continuation of the program in New South Wales. The Aboriginal family resettlement program gives assistance to Aboriginal people if they choose to move to areas where there are better prospects for jobs and better accommodation. The Minister's response suggests that there will be another review. What we need is a commitment from the Minister that the purpose of the review is to find a way of implementing the Committee's recommendations rather than an exercise in finding a way to knock the recommendations on the head.

TALK.START.PARA: —This says it is supported.

—That is right. As the honourable member for Dundas says, the Government's response says the recommendation is supported but the detail of the response certainly leaves it open to question. We ask the Minister to say what the Government's intention is in relation to that recommendation. Another matter raised with me-I ask the Minister to consider it-is the need in the housing and building programs for town camp areas to provide to Aborigines as many as possible of the jobs that will be created under this program, especially those Aborigines from the town camps. There are good Aboriginal housing organisations. I have spent some time with the organisation in Alice Springs, which I believe is doing a very good job under the Tangentyere Council, and I hope that the Government can find a way to ensure that Aborigines are employed in building houses for their own use, whatever types of houses they are. The Minister quite rightly says they probably will not be typical suburban brick houses, but something to meet their own needs. I welcome the Minister's suggestion.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the Opposition welcomes this long awaited response to the Standing Committee's report. Action must be taken in this area and, whilst I have expressed some reservations about some of the responses to the Committee's recommendations, we welcome the fact that at least some action will be taken by the Government.

Finally, I want to refer to three paragraphs of the Minister's statement. On page 5 of his statement, in regard to the implementation of the town campers assistance program and the organisations involved, he said:

These organisations and individuals will be involved in the town campers assistance program to varying degrees but the contribution of all to the program will be guided by the principles of consultation, Aboriginal self-determination and-
note this-
the need to develop flexible responses to the individual needs of each community rather than meeting any one particular need on a national basis.

To that the Opposition says 'Amen'. That is exactly the argument I have used continually in relation to the Minister's proposal for uniform land rights legislation. The Minister is adopting here an approach of meeting the housing needs of individual communities. But in relation to uniform land rights, he is adopting the absolute opposite approach. The Minister is totally inconsistent in his approach to his portfolio. He wishes to meet the individual needs of Aboriginal communities in the area of housing but not in the area of land rights , where he has rushed headlong into imposing legislation on the States, which are also in the process of considering what legislation ought to be implemented in the land rights area. In other words, they are doing for land rights exactly what he is doing for housing, and they are saying to him: 'Why don't you let us do the same for land rights'. He is saying: 'No, I am going to impose ALP principles on land rights on all the States'. We see another contradiction on page 8 of the Minister's statement. The second paragraph on that page states:
I will do everything in my power, through legislation and special arrangements, to gain land tenure for those campers who currently lack it.
He says 'to gain land tenure'. That is an interesting approach because on 8 December the Minister introduced into this House a motion which states, in part:
the recognition by this Parliament of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people's rights to land, in accordance with the following five basic principles:
The first basic principle is:
Aboriginal land to be held under inalienable freehold title.

So he is saying in that motion that Aboriginal land must be held under inalienable freehold title. In relation to housing for fringe dwellers, he is saying in this statement that secure tenure ought to be granted. Why has he suddenly backed down? To me, this is the approach we have been looking for. It is certainly an approach that the Opposition has been proposing for a long time. There is no point, in our view, in getting hung up over the term 'inalienable freehold title'. What is needed is secure tenure. Therefore, whilst we welcome the Minister's statement, it seems to be directly contradictory to the terms of his motion. The motion will be debated later this session, so perhaps we will get some answers then. That is one matter I raised with the Minister when the motion was introduced. I have yet to get an answer and now he is adopting the proposal I put when that motion was moved. Perhaps he will agree to some amendments I have to the motion. Finally, the last paragraph on page 9 of the statement reads:

In Western Australia, the only other State for which excisions are a significant issue, administrative action has been taken by the State Government to resolve outstanding excision requests. For the longer term, the Seaman inquiry into land rights in Western Australia is expected to recommend the most appropriate method for achieving excisions.

Again I ask the Minister why he leaves excisions to the Western Australia Government and yet continues to press on with his idea of imposing uniform land rights legislation on all the States. Western Australia is in the process through the Seaman inquiry. Certainly Seaman will make recommendations to the Western Australian Government regarding land rights legislation applicable to that State. So again we have this contradiction in relation to excisions. He has now accepted that the Northern Territory and Western Australian governments are the most appropriate bodies to recommend the appropriate method for achieving excisions. Yet when land rights legislation is being implemented in almost every State-certainly in every mainland State-the Minister says: 'No, the States are not to have a say in that. I intend to implement overriding legislation'. I suggest to the Minister that he reconsider his approach in relation to his uniform land rights legislation. I welcome the approach that he has adopted in this statement.
Motion (by Mr Ruddock) proposed:
That the House take note of the paper.

—There is concern among members of the Opposition that this is a very important report and areas for which they have responsibility will be affected by it. They would like to join in the debate.
