DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The alarm and confusion among Australia's elderly created by the Government's decision to yet again review the direction of its proposed assets test on pensions.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise as a matter of public importance on behalf of the Opposition the continued widespread concern and, indeed, distress amongst the aged and people nearing retirement over the threatened assets test of pensioners. This time last year Australians were told that a Labor government would bring new levels of consultation to the decision making processes. This was to be a government of consensus. That was the rhetoric. But what is the reality? Why is it that after less than a year in office we have the elderly organising to campaign, and justifiably so, against the Government during its cynical, premature election exercise? Why is it that we have the almost daily spectacle of the Minister responsible shifting ground on the shape and form of Labor's assets test? Why are the media now talking about 'grey power' in Australia? And why did we have last week's ludicrous spectacle of a Government in total disarray on the assets issue?

SPEECH.PARA: The answers to these questions are bound up within the sorry saga of the clumsy and heavy-handed attempts by the Government to reintroduce the assets test. The previous coalition Government abolished the assets test in 1976. We abolished the assets test for very sound reasons. They were: First, an assets test, of its own nature, is extremely complicated to administer; secondly, it is extremely costly to administer; thirdly, an assets test is intrusive into people's private lives-that is why the Hawke Goverment had to recruit an army of 1,400 enforcers. Fourthly, and above all else, an assets test is filled with inequities. These factors were as clear as crystal to the coalition then as they should have been to Labor last August.

There was reason to believe that Labor politicians understood the inequities of an assets test. The former Leader of the Opposition, the present Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden), was unequivocal in his opposition to an assets test. He said that it was:

. . . another kick in the teeth for the aged and retiring citizens as well as half a million widows, invalids and supporting parents. The argument about millionaires receiving pensions is a cruel and emotive device to cover up the Government's real intentions . . . of ripping the pension off ordinary people with modest savings they have worked for all their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was the former Leader of the Opposition. Let me read to honourable members the 1982 Australian Labor Party platform because that agreed with the statement of the former Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden. The 1982 Labor Party platform said:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor believes people past retirement age should have security of income and services which would allow them to enjoy their lives and leisure.

Less than a year before Senator Grimes became the Minister for Social Security he made his position clear. In a written statement, Senator Grimes said that a Labor government would be 'ensuring that pensioners with savings are not penalised by policy changes'. Let me repeat that statement of Senator Grimes, the current Minister for Social Security: He said that Labor would be 'ensuring that pensioners with savings are not penalised by policy changes'. There can be no misunderstanding about what that means. That was Labor's position during the election campaign last year. The elderly were not to be disadvantaged by any changes in policy by the Labor government. Pensioners were justified in believing that there was bipartisan agreement that there would be no assets test . It is important to get the position clear. It is important to understand the position before 5 March 1983 because it contrasts markedly with the duplicity that has followed.

The first serious indication that the Hawke Government would not honour its commitments to the elderly came after only a couple of months in office. In its mini-Budget the Government introduced the 30 per cent lump sum superannuation tax as a bolt out of the blue. The way it was introduced-the lack of discussion, the lack of consultation, the confusion, the anger, the confrontation and the backing down were all part of a governmental behaviour pattern that has been repeated time and again. It is a way of doing business which is light years away from the much vaunted consensus. The super slug caused uncertainty and upheaval which will not die down.

In August, the Government chose to introduce its assets test using the same tactics. Again, it came out of the blue. There was no prior indication. There was no prior consultation with the representatives of those affected. That became crystal clear in the aftermath. What the Government proposed was shot full of anomalies and inequities. It was manifestly unfair. It showed beyond doubt that the Government was willing to ignore those fundamental reasons which motivated the coalition Government to scrap the assets test in 1976. The same inequities, the same injustices which plagued the previous test did not matter to this Hawke Government.

It was those inequities and injustices which generated such vehement opposition . Pensioners, their organisations, social service organisations and the Opposition united in condemnation. It was not as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) charged in a fit of face-saving hindsight, after having votes ripped off him at the by-elections last Saturday week when he said that scaremongering by the Opposition parties had brought about his change.

From the day that the Government's intentions were made known there was genuine concern about what the assets test would do to Australia's elderly. The extraordinary form which the assets test took when it was first introduced- although it is still there in principle, reiterated by Senator Grimes two days ago, and reiterated by the Prime Minister today-fanned the concern and the uncertainty. It was to be a tax which did not penalise pensioners for some assets-they could lose their pensions for having money in the bank, but they might not lose the pension for having a collection of paintings. They could lose their pensions if they had a holiday home, but they might not lose the pension if they had jewellery or antiques. The fact was that the assets test went against the grain. It crudely threatened the things which mean the most to Australians-their homes, their savings, their security and their independence in retirement. And it still threatens them because bear in mind that it is only the nature of that test which is being re-examined by some ill-defined and as yet unannounced panel.

Even some of the Government back benchers began to wake up to the implications of the assets test. They should take their minds back to it. With the pressure mounting, the backsliding began. The twisting and turning of course only added to the confusion. The Government attempted to buy off some of the resistence with its so-called leisure package. But that made matters worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Confusing.

—Totally confusing; the honourable member is absolutely right. What was a fair level of leisure allowance? Was it $30,000, $40,000 or $50,000? The debate and the uncertainty, honourable members will recall, rolled on through November, three months after Labor's announcement.

SPEECH.PARA: Fearing an electoral backlash which would torpedo his leaking ship, the Premier of New South Wales joined in the condemnation. In the process he simply reiterated what the coalition had said since 1976-that this assets test brought in by the Government is unfair in its operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the penciller got something right.

—The penciller got something right that time but he has still got an assets test looming over his head and that was confirmed by the Prime Minister today. New South Wales pensioners would pay the penalty of living in a State which has higher property values, we were told. Was it fair that the leisure package would disadvantage pensioners in New South Wales and Queensland? The Government's pathetic reaction to these rebuffs was to replace the carrot with the stick. If they could not buy off resistance they would resort to standover tactics. On 17 March Senator Grimes had rejected as false a news story that Labor's promised increase in pensions would not be paid. But eight months later and feeling the pressure of resistance to the assets test, the Minister threatened just that. Pensioners would not get an increase unless they knuckled under.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Labor Government under pressure from all sides was now threatening to break yet another promise to the elderly. The net result of that heavy handedness was that the Prime Minister and his Ministry slipped deeper into the quicksand of their own making. And all the time, is it not recalled, the anxiety mounted amongst the elderly and within the ranks of the Government. At year's end Labor was clutching at straws. It argued at that time that it was not the product, but the marketing campaign that was wrong. In time worn fashion the Prime Minister said that the assets test had to be sold better. The Government would do this through a series of national workshops. Another twist in the assets knot. It is significant that at the same time the Government called in the super salesman on the assets test it was launching another marketing campaign. Again, it was pushing a bodgie product, an early election. It was neither the question of fairness nor the continuing concern and uncertainty amongst pensioners which brought about the latest act in the assets test farce.

Last week the nation witnessed a Government in disarray over this issue. On 22 February the Prime Minister used the forum of the National Press Club to announce what, at first glance, was a backdown on the assets test. He talked of mistakes and of the possibility that this was not the best assets test. After six months of twisting and turning he had reached the conclusion which the majority of Australians had reached last August. There was to be another look at Labor's assets test. He added a new term to his buck-passing vocabulary. There would be a panel established to look at the assets test. But let us face it, there would be, and there is no scrapping of the assets test. The next day it became clear that the Prime Minister was shooting from the hip. His own Minister , Senator Grimes, had to face the embarrassment of learning of the Prime Minister's pre-emptive strike while watching the news. The Prime Minister's extraordinary performance last week ended up with Labor in a Clayton's backdown on assets testing. It is the backdown you have when you are not really having a backdown. It is a position devoid of credibility.

Australia's elderly are now faced with further vacillation and uncertainty over the future of the pension. We are to have a panel of indeterminate composition which will report its findings either at the end of this session of Parliament or to do it, if the Government is a position, after some election depending on whether you believe the Prime Minister or Senator Grimes. Honourable members can reach their own conclusions. In the meantime pensioners live in uncertainty, unable to make major personal decisions and unsure whether or not they will have a pension later this year.

The tortured history of this Government's attempts to impose an assets test on pensioners has caused tremendous concern throughout the community-concern about the security of the elderly; concern about a government that talks of consensus but practices bully tactics, and concern about a government which changes course as regularly as people change their clothes.

In less than a year in office this Labor Government has run up a record of unparalleled duplicity in its dealings with Australia's retired and elderly. From a 'no assets test' position and promises of better conditions for pensioners while in Opposition the Hawke Government has moved in the opposite direction-the 30 per cent lump sum superannuation slug; the assets test; the means test for over 70s; threats of not meeting its commitments on raising pension levels; failure to rule out federal death duties, and promoting the cause of a capital gains tax. The record speaks for itself. This Government has replaced heart disease as the greatest health threat to Australia's senior citizens.

The way out of the assets test quicksand is certainly not through the vacillation of this Government. It is not through setting up another panel of review, in other words, reinventing the wheel. The way out is clear. As the report of the Australian Council of Social Service found after consulting pensioner representatives during January and February:

The strong sentiment, virtually unanimous among pensioner groups, was that the Government might better institute a review of the income security system in conjuction with its review of the taxation system.
That ought to be done by sending the matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. I urge the Prime Minister to do just that if he is not going to cancel and scrap the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not need to wheel the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) in here to do over the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). The Leader of the Opposition made great play in his speech of some supposedly disastrous results for the Labor Government in recent by-elections. In fact, as the Leader of the Opposition would know, in the seat of Richmond, as one example, there was a swing to the Government. It was the first swing to a national Labor government in 60 years. That followed the decimation of the Fraser Government at the last general election. Heaven knows what will happen at the next Federal election. We have just heard the pathetic utterances of a Leader of the Opposition who is in his death throes. I will say more about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance refers to 'the Government's decision to yet again review the direction of its proposed assets test on pensions'. There is no review of its direction on policy for the aged. The Government's policies are very clear in regard to the aged and the assets test. The Federal Government is committed to the principle that expenditure on pensions should be directed to those who most need it. The Leader of the Opposition agrees with that, as I will point out a little later.

We recognise that many elderly people have been worried and alarmed about the assets test. That is why the Government has decided to establish a broadly based panel of community based representatives to advise on how the principle of a needs based pension system can best be implemented. But why have we got to the stage where there is confusion? The confusion has not been caused by the Government. The confusion has been caused by the utterances from one end of Australia to the other of members of the Opposition, in particular the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock. Mr Peacock has run from one end of Australia to the other deliberately creating confusion. He knows that 85 per cent of Australia's pensioners will be in the same position as they are now, or better off, under the assets test. He knows that. He has advocated a similar test in past years but he has deliberately attempted to confuse aged people. So there is confusion and we admit it. That is why the Prime Minister quite rightly moved last week to dispel that confusion. He announced the setting up of a broadly based committee to make sure that we have some equitability in the pensions test and that when it is brought in it will benefit Australian society.

Another reason why this confusion and political point scoring is being carried on by the Opposition is apparent when one reads the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald of 21 February. An article by John Short states:
Plans to hold up the Government's controversial assets test legislation in the Senate for six more months will be presented to the Opposition's shadow ministry next week.
The move would see the scheduled introduction of the assests test pushed back from November to May next year.
That is 1985. The article continues:
The proposal, by the Opposition spokesman on social security, Senator Messner, is aimed at maximising the political backlash against the assets test in an early federal election.
The last part is the most interesting. It states:
Liberal Party tacticians believe community opposition to the test could quickly dissipate once it was introduced because it is not as draconian as many people believe.

That was on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald only 10 days ago. Those are some of the reasons for the Opposition's political point scoring. It has nothing to do with facts about the equitable nature of the test. It has nothing to do with the fact that some people have half a million dollars tucked away in bank accounts or cheque accounts and are receiving the maximum pension as the result of a system created by the previous Government of which the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, for most of the time was a prominent member of Cabinet. Let us not forget that he was a prominent member of the Fraser Government which introduced that system. A large book put out by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) shows that many people have vast sums of money and assets yet still receive their full penion. I will mention a few examples. In New South Wales one couple has $107,000 in a cheque account yet receives the full pension. Another person in Victoria has $165,000 in various capital growth and friendly society investments. That person is receiving the full pension. Another person in Queensland has $270,000 in a family trust and, of course, is receiving the full pension. Another person in Queensland has $449,000 in a cheque account. Those people obviously have been wrongly advised or they are not telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is four.

—I have a whole book of them here. This has happened under the system that the Opposition created. The now Leader of the Opposition, as a prominent member of that Cabinet, was part of those decisions. Let us look at what the Leader of the Opposition thinks about means testing and an assets test. Let us go back to an address by the Hon. Andrew Peacock of 11 September 1981, just over two years ago. At that time the honourable member for Kooyong said this:

SPEECH.PARA: By socially productive I mean a Budget-
he was talking about the Budget which had been released a few weeks prior to this speech-
which caters for carefully identified areas of genuine human need and avoids the situation where those who don't need government assistance are given help at the expense of those who do.
Five days later, at a National Press Club luncheon, Mr Peacock again said this about how to cut the growing 27 per cent which goes to social welfare in the Budget:

The way to cut it is to ensure that it goes to those who are in genuine human need, and not to those who I've described as demonstrably not needing it. Now that means perhaps some form of income or means testing.
That is what the Leader of the Opposition said back in 1981, just over two years ago. Further on, at the same luncheon, he said:

But with the ageing of the Australian population, the percentage we spend on social welfare now is going to increase and we have to face up to this harsh reality. I am not in a position to implement the changes but if I ever become in a position-
I do not think he ever will; in fact I know he will not-

to implement change I will certainly be seeking to see that the sort of things I am giving voice to, not only today but over the period of the months ahead, will become a reality. I am not engaging in rhetoric for its own sake.

There he was talking about means testing, income testing and other sorts of testing yet here today, and over the last six months, we have heard the exact opposite, purely for political reasons, as the Sydney Morning Herald pointed out only a few days ago. I reiterate what Mr Peacock said. He kept saying it. In the Sydney Morning Herald on 17 September 1981, under the by-line of Mr Paul Kelly, it states:
The former Minister for Industrial Relations said that social welfare spending 'has to be cut'.
'The way to cut it is to ensure it goes to those in genuine human need,' he said.
'That means, perhaps, some form of income or means testing, difficult as that may be for some.'
That was Mr Peacock. On 3 March 1982, in the Australian Financial Review, under the headline 'Lynch calls for means test', an article starts off by saying this:
A senior Cabinet Minister, Sir Phillip Lynch, has argued strongly for the return of means testing for all old age pensions and other social welfare benefits.
Further down the article states:
The former Cabinet Minister, Mr Andrew Peacock, has spoken publicly about the need to direct welfare to those in need.

I am glad that he agrees with the Hawke Government's policies. Addressing the National Press Club in Canberra, the Leader of the Opposition said that social welfare spending had to be cut. He continued:
The way to cut it is to ensure that it goes to those who are in genuine human need.

He explained that this meant 'some form of income or means testing'. I am glad that he agrees with the Government. He has now changed his tune for the political reasons I have already described. Let us turn to the Liberal Party. A resolution passed at the Liberal Party Federal Council of 1983 reads:
That this Council expresses its support for a needs-based social welfare system and therefore believes that welfare benefits should be payable subject to a means test . . .

That resolution was passed only last year, yet honourable members opposite have the hide to come into this House and say exactly the opposite and parade from one end of Australia to the other. The credibility of the Opposition and, in particular, that of the Leader of the Opposition, is in total tatters. Judging from the results of the by-elections recently, the Federal Opposition will be even more tattered after the next Federal election.

Let us look at what the Fraser Government did and what the Leader of the Opposition, as a member of the Cabinet of that Government, was a party to. During its term of office the maximum rate of pension, with which the needy 80 per cent of pensioners are concerned, declined from around 24.5 per cent to 22 per cent in December 1982. So much for that Government's concern for the neediest members of our community! What about the future? One would have thought that the Liberal Party would by now have unveiled some policies. No policies from the Opposition are coming forward. I can understand that in the case of the Leader of the Opposition, because his intellect does not go that far, but I thought someone may have come up with some sort of policy. But no on has come forward with one. We are debating a very important matter. The Leader of the Opposition has left the chamber; he is not concerned. He has said his bit and gone. Only four members of the Opposition are listening to the debate. That shows what the Opposition thinks of the pensioners in this country. Its rhetoric does not match its performance. Let us consider the previous Government's performance with respect to fringe benefits for pensioners. It failed to increase fringe benefit levels thus disadvantaging many pensioners in our society. It increased the levels of taxation applied to lower income earners, yet high income earners had a reduction in taxation levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't noticed any action on your part with the tax scales.
—The honourable member's Party has been in government for 31 of the last 34 years. We have been in government for 11 months, so the honourable member need not talk to me about performance.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Isaacs will take no notice of the interjections.

—I refer to the taxation performance of the former Government of which the honourable member for Mitchell was a part. Taxation is an area which affects all people, including pensioners. The record shows that between 1975-76 and 1981-82 a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children, earning a wage of $11,000, had a percentage change in net tax of proportional income of 72.9 per cent. A taxpayer with the same family composition earning $16,000, or average weekly earnings at that time, had an increase of 21.6 per cent. A family earning in excess of $1,000 a week had a decrease of nearly 3 per cent. Those are the policies that the former Government put to the people of Australia. That is why the vast majority of people found themselves in poverty and looked for a change in government. They voted for that change in no uncertain terms 11 months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Canning (Ms Fatin) will elaborate on the policies of this Government and on what we have done and what we intend to do. Let us talk about what we have done with regard to the assets test. The assets test proposal was a very sound one. We have consulted many groups, as can be seen by the changes that have occurred over the last few months. Given the Opposition's stated attitude to deferring and continuing to defer the proposal in this Parliament, the Government is prepared to consult even further. We have decided to utilise the additional time available to us to establish the broadly based panel of community representatives announced by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Social Security. This will be done and I am sure that there will be an equitable system of pensions and benefits to the advantage of the vast majority of Australian pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1,400 rubber stamps which said 'Government approved' have gone back into the drawers of 1,400 public servants. There has been a stay on their use. The 1,400 public servants who were to use their stamps to mark 'Government approved' on assets held by people throughout Australia have been temporarily withdrawn. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today made it clear that it is the Government's intention to proceed with an assets test. The stamps are in the drawers ready to be brought out and used to stamp assets and savings when the new assets test eventuates. What will the stamps be used on? What will be stamped 'Government approved'? Will it be the family home, the savings account, the cheque account, the building society account, the jewels, the diamonds and rubies, the boat, or the antiques? Will these things be stamped ' Government approved'? Will they provide that only the quarter acre block of land will be Government approved? Will they want to search under the bed and use the Government's stamp there? Will they stamp part of the family farm 'Government approved'? What is the intention of the Government with regard to the assets test?

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that not one Minister is in the House to support the assets test; there is not one Minister to reveal the Government's intentions to defend its decision to backtrack, or to defend the people's committee set up to look at the matter. There is not one Minister in the chamber supporting the Government's attitude to the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance is here. He is watching the money.

—As the honourable member says, the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) is here. No one knows what will occur, but everybody waits with apprehension. Almost from the first day, the Government commenced to attack those who are most vulnerable in our community. The Government attacked them and has continued to attack them, not only with the assets test. The Government has raised uncertainty and concern in the minds of all those with savings and assets. It has attacked those who are aged over 70 with a means test. It has attacked retired people with a lump sum tax on superannuation benefits. Yesterday in the House two more measures were brought in that will affect the savings of those who have retired.

SPEECH.PARA: But the assets test is not the only action being considered. The Government has a number of other measures under consideration; for example, a gifts tax and a capital gains tax to which many Ministers say they are committed. It also has a wealth tax under consideration and is considering death duties. All these matters are being thought about by the Government so that it can further attack retirees. The Government's policies are in disarray. It has nothing for retirees . The only policy it has is that people must conform to what the Government considers are people in need. That is the one policy. The attack on savings and assets is not limited only to those people affected. It is not confined to this most vulnerable group in our community. It affects their families, their children and their grandchildren. Decisions on retirement, on savings and on assets are not made in an ad hoc way. They are made over a long period. They are discussed at the breakfast table. They are discussed during the commercials that appear on television. At family gatherings, Christmas time and other times during the year families sit down and talk together about the well being of members of their families.

Such decisions are not just taken by a person who is seeking to avoid taxation or to rip off the Government; these are careful decisions. They are planned jointly by families, with many generations joining in those discussions and making those decisions.

Planning is used to initiate goals and also to further the dreams and aspirations of families. It is not an impulsive decision in any way to prepare for retirement. People building a weekender do so in their spare time. The whole family participates. It may take a number of years to complete the project. Yet honourable members opposite are saying that such a family does not conform. We will see what the Government says. People working and saving in this way add to the production of the whole nation. When their individual goals are accumulated they add up to what drives the nation ahead. National productivity is the result of families planning and working together for their personal goals. We all benefit and we all feel secure when families do this.

Why does the Government want to disallow this process? Why must the Government stamp everything 'approved' before this vulnerable age group can realise its dreams? Australians do not want that. They do not want such interference. They do not want government involvement; they want their freedom. It is almost as if the Government does not trust them. It is almost as if the Government cannot give its confidence to the people of Australia.

I think we need to encourage our retirees. They must have productive lives. They must have predictable lives and they must have their personal freedoms. The Government, by a series of measures, has raised so many concerns for people who have retired or who are about to retire that the community is saying that the Government does not care, it does not understand, and it has no policies for people in retirement.

I think that all honourable members on this side of the House want people to have their goals. We want them to strive for things that they see to be important and we want them to plan for their goals without interference. We want them to use their initiative to achieve those goals. We do not want, nor do we stand for, government interference. I believe that the Australian Labor Party has created the need for people to plot, not plan, their future and the use of their resources, savings and assets. While they are plotting they are surrounded by concern and worry because they do not know what the Government is likely to do next. In order to achieve the Government's stamp of approval-'Government approved'-they have to plot, and while they are plotting they are worrying and they are concerned. That does not lead to healthy and long lives and happiness for people who are retiring; it leads to illness and abuse. That is what the Government is fostering and encouraging by its actions.

I believe that worry and concern are no substitute for people's dreams, but the Government has caused this worry. Plotting is no alternative to planning one's future. I believe that government approval can never replace individual initiative. The Government is set on a deadly course in every action it has taken since the National Economic Summit Conference in regard to these important matters. There is no comprehensive overview. The Government has lost course. It has lost direction and in so doing it has damaged the future, the well-being and the sense of security which a vast section of our community needs. As I have said, the Government has affected not only that vulnerable group of people but also their families and their grandchildren. I believe that these people will judge the Government at election time as being inadequate to deal with their circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If any one thing has characterised this Labor Government during the past 12 months it has been our determination to make Australia a fairer society. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) has been talking utter nonsense and much of what he said was scaremongering. He made deliberate and misleading statements. I refer, for instance, to the suggestion that the Government would go into people's houses and look in their drawers, look at their possessions and check them. It is absolute and utter nonsense to suggest that. This Government has a higher regard for its aged persons. It cares about the elderly in this society to the degree, I suggest, that within a very short period we will have an Office of Aged Care in this country. The objectives of that office will be to secure a range of services for the aged which are equitable, comprehensive, balanced and cost effective.
—What is that going to do for the family?
—In reply to the honourable gentleman at the table, it will bring together and prevent--
—That has got you.

—No, it has not got me. It will co-ordinate the services for the aged in this country and put them under one office so that we can better serve the aged people in this land. We will help prevent the confusion and time wasting that often occurs in the administration of programs for the aged in this country . As I was suggesting, it has been our determination to make Australia a fairer society. This was the basis of our campaign to win government, and it has been the underlying motive in all the actions that we have taken since our election last year. After seven years of Liberal-National Party government the people of Australia were crying out for fairness to be restored to Australian society. They showed clearly how they felt about the years of discord and hypocrisy under the conservatives when they voted in a Labor government last March, and they have supported us ever since. Let us think for a moment about events in the last few months and the discussion which has surrounded the assets test. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the proposed test in August with the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: We must reform our taxation and welfare systems so that tax burdens are spread throughout the community on the basis of capacity to pay, and welfare payments are provided according to needs.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) immediately began a long series of discussions with pensioner organisations. My colleagues on this side of the House and I went out of our way to explain the proposed test to pensioners and their families in our electorates. I can say quite categorically that I personally saw dozens of pensioners who left my office, having been reasurred about their positions and fully supporting the Government's moves in this area. They are not the pensioners with diamonds and pictures and other such things. What were members of the Opposition doing at this time? They were ranting and raving about attacks on pensioners and thoroughly frightening people about the proposed test. Yet it is the Opposition which has been entirely inconsistent in its approach to retirement incomes. It appears that the Opposition does not have a policy at all, let alone an alternative suggestion to put forward.

When members of the Opposition were in government, the basis of all their decisions was the number of votes at stake. Why else would they have made the politically cynical and socially irresponsible step of abolishing the means test in the first place? Why else would they have turned a blind eye to the recommendations to restructure the taxation and welfare systems which were piling up from government advisory bodies? Why else would they have paid lip service to the rights of the elderly, and at the same time let the value of age pension slip to only 22 per cent of average weekly earnings? I spoke before of this Government's commitment to direct welfare payments to those in need. I really think that the antics of the Opposition over the assets test must be caused in large part by its utter confusion in finding its leader to be in total agreement with a Labor government.

Let us just remind ourselves about the stated position of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) concerning welfare payments in Australia. Even though my colleague has mentioned some of these statements I think I should quote them again. A report in the Australian Financial Review of 3 March 1982 states:
The former Cabinet Minister, Mr Andrew Peacock, has spoken publicly about the need to direct welfare to those in need.
Addressing the National Press Club in Canberra he said that social welfare spending had to be cut. The report of the address states:
The way to cut it, he said, was to ensure that it goes to those in genuine human need. This meant, Mr Peacock explained, some form of income or means testing.
Again, in addressing the Melbourne Press Club on 11 September 1981, the honourable member said:

So, in future, I would like to see a Budget framed on the basis of its being as economically and socially productive as possible . . . By socially productive I mean a budget which caters for carefully identified areas of genuine human need and avoids the situation where those who don't need government assistance are given help at the expense of those who do. In other words if you see a Budget in national housekeeping terms, there is no inherent virtue in coming out even at the end of the period if, in the meantime, some members of the family have been allowed to be gluttons at the expense of those who have been undernourished.

The Labor Government recognises that pensioners are a highly vulnerable section of our society. Obviously, the Opposition knows this too or it would not have chosen the issue of pensions as the main target to vent its spleen on the Government and get rid of some of its frustration at finding it had been thrown out of power. I can assure the Opposition that its cynical exercise of stirring up confusion about the assets test has been recognised by the people of Australia as just one more example of its philosophy of confrontation and conflict.

Madam Deputy Speaker, much mention has been made recently of this Government's total commitment to returning the age pension to, and maintaining it at, 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We are also aware that pensioners are exploited by banks, property trusts and investment sharks. Because of this we are seriously considering proposals to finance pension advisory services, to help people make the crucial decisions about how to arrange their financial affairs. What has concerned me most about the assets test debate is the extent to which some of this Government's political opponents will go in their effort to score points and win votes. We are not denying that confusion has been created by the proposal to introduce an assets test. What I can say with certainty is that the cause of the confusion stems in large part from the sensational, headline grabbing statements made by members of the Opposition.

I turn now to the positive actions that the Government is taking to make sure that legislation on an assets test is as fair as possible. The panel of people who will be asked to advise the Government about the test will consist of men and women who are experienced in the field of retirement incomes and pensions. To suggest, as the Opposition is doing, that this will create further confusion is surely an insult to the intelligence of Australian pensioners.

Let me finish by looking at just what the Government is proposing in the assets test which has so excited the Opposition. Under the proposed legislation a single pensioner could have $17,100 in savings and still receive the maximum pension. Married pensioner couples could have $28,500 on top of their home, car and personal effects. Single pensioners could have personal property and assets of up to $106,434 without losing the pension, and so it goes on. I conclude my remarks by restating this Government's absolute commitment to the principle that pensions are paid to those who need assistance. No responsible person could believe in the fairness of any other proposition. In taking this position, the Government has the overwhelming support of the Australian people, who have seen through the transparent and desperate attempts by the Opposition to make political capital at the expense of the elderly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present the Committee's report entitled 'The Provision of Development Assistance and Humanitarian Aid to the Horn of Africa', and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This report was tabled in the Senate on 15 December, after this House went into recess. The purpose in making it available through the Senate was so that it would be, as soon as possible, in the hands of the Jackson committee, which was at that stage conducting a review of Australian aid. As the report deals particularly with the conduct of Australian aid and some of the broader questions of Australian aid to a particular part of the world, we of the Committee thought it important that the Jackson committee should be aware of and familiar with the report. I do not intend to repeat the tabling statement made by my colleague, the chairman of the sub-committee of the Joint Committee, Senator Sibraa. For the information of honourable members, it is to be found in the Senate Hansard of 15 December at pages 3852 and 3853. What I would like to do is point up some of the issues, particularly in relation to the question of food aid. The report points out at page 114:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's food aid contributions have increased significantly over the years. It is necessary on humanitarian grounds in view of the recent droughts and continuing refugee problem that relief aid be provided. Relief aid is justified where there is an urgent problem requiring attention, but its usefulness is only short-term.
I stress that. The report continues:

There is a danger in the long-term provision of food aid only. Once established , unless there is potential or incentive for recipients of aid to produce their own food, aid becomes self-perpetuating and is very difficult to cut off.
The report is saying that unfortunately a relief mentality develops, which in itself can be counterproductive. The Joint Committee report also states:

The Committee recommends that, because of Australia's expertise in dry-land farming and other agricultural techniques, and the growing problem of the lack of self-sufficiency in food production in the Horn of Africa, ADAB-
the Australian Development Assistance Bureau-
should continue to support the concept of self-sufficiency in its future aid program.

Early in February I had the honour of leading the Australian Government delegation to the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference, which was held in Lusaka, in Zambia. Food aid was one of the main issues discussed. One reason was that the food problem had been accentuated by the drought of the last two years in the Southern African area. I was very impressed by a paper, presented by the Nordic countries, entitled 'Policies in Agriculture and Rural Development'. Having discussed the particular problems of agriculture and the impact of drought, the paper went on to say:

These problems are of a long term nature. While drought and also in some instances armed aggression by South Africa has caused the acute difficulties, declining agricultural production appears to be part of a wider pattern. Food output per capita has fallen in Africa since the beginning of the 1970s, and the trend appears to have accelerated in the 1980s. FAOs projections of demand and supply of food in Africa by the year 2000 do not give cause for optimism.
For the benefit of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) who seeks to interject, the report stresses the role that small farmers can play in increasing agricultural production.
Also-and I am sure, Madam Deputy Speaker, that you will be interested in this comment-it argued for the recognition of the role of women and pointed out that:

In some countries women constitute between 60 and 80 per cent of the rural labour force. Yet it would hardly be an exaggeration to say that women are fairly consistently excluded partially or wholly from access to the benefits of agricultural policy.

I believe that that statement certainly can be endorsed by the Government, although the National Party may have difficulty in doing so. The report of the Nordic countries went on to raise the very interesting question of pricing policy. It pointed out:
Here the record of many governments is rather dismal with a persistent urban bias favouring low prices to the vocal and politically potent minority of urban consumers.

I suppose as politicians we can all well understand the pressure on any government to attract political support by keeping the prices of basic food items low. Such policies can operate to the detriment of the agricultural producer, reduce incentive to produce and result in food shortages. However, there is also-and this was perhaps the elaboration that I made of the Nordic paper at the conference-a significant impact not only on domestic pricing but also on international pricing. As we all know-and I am sure that again members of the National Party will agree with me-commodity prices have reached their lowest level for 50 years and have contributed to a serious decline in terms of trade not only of developing countries but also countries such as Australia. The international terms of trade have worked against countries like Australia and the developing countries and have diminished, particularly for developing countries, the incentive to produce.

I should also point out that the access of the less developed countries to markets, despite various preference schemes, has been drastically reduced. A report in the UNCTAD Review in 1981 noted that the loss of market share through the European Common Market's Common Agricultural Policy between 1962 and 1979 cost the developing countries about $9,000m. I would suspect that the amount of official development assistance coming from the European communities would not add up to that loss through trade that the less developed countries suffered. The operation of the Common Agricultural Policy through the export of artificially created agricultural surpluses has also created a devastating impact on the less developed countries. I would like to refer to a 1981 House of Lords report which concluded:

European Community surplus exports serve to depress world prices and make food imports cheaper. But in the long run European Community activities reduce the less developed countries' incentive to improve their own food production capabilities.

So the dumping of subsidised surpluses and, indeed, food aid itself, as distinct from emergency relief, has the effect of depressing prices, which in turn reduces local production and compels continuing reliance on imports.

It is obvious that food aid is a complex subject. It has the potential and, indeed, the reality of being counter-productive. Our longer term objective should not be food aid but aid in the growing of food. Australia, with its experience of dry land farming and animal husbandry, along with a very well developed resource capacity and also an agricultural extension service, can play a useful role. It is to this area that I believe we should direct our attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report entitled 'The Provision of Development Assistance and Humanitarian Aid to the Horn of Africa' is one of the three reports which a Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has prepared or is preparing. The first report, entitled 'Some Observations on Australia's Diplomatic Representation in Africa and Adjacent Indian Ocean Island States', was presented late last year. The second is the report now before the House and the third will be a more political report dealing with the geo-political situation in the Horn of Africa. The Committee decided to prepare this report more rapidly, as the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) has pointed out, and it was tabled in the Senate last year so that its research and recommendations would be available to the Jackson committee on foreign aid before that committee prepared its report. That was achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously Australian foreign aid is concentrated on the south-west Pacific. However, there are trouble spots in the world which make demands on Australia's humanitarianism. I refer to such trouble spots as Central America or the Middle East. The Horn of Africa is a particular case. It is three quarters of a million square miles in area, much of it desert, comprising Ethiopia, Somalia and Djibuti-countries in which some 40 million to 50 million people live and for most of whom life is nasty, brutish and short. They have produced some 10 million refugees, which represents half of the world's total. In recent years some 200,000 have died of famine in the region. So it is no wonder that Australia's aid to the Horn has been increased in those same terrible years from 2 per cent of our total foreign aid to some 10 per cent of our total foreign aid , or, in dollar terms, to some $56m. It will, I assume, be a region to which the Jackson committee will also be giving attention.

The Committee reached a number of conclusions. It noted that the people of the region suffer from few diseases which require high technology to control. Such things as improved water supply and sanitation, nutrition, health education, vaccinations, immunisations and simple curative measures are needed. Consequently, the Committee noted the self-help primary health care program in Somalia, begun a little over a year ago by Community Aid Abroad, which aims to teach Somalis to take responsibility for their own basic health care. The Committee recommends that the Australian Government continue its support to Community Aid Abroad for this work.

In the same spirit, the Committee noted that relief aid, however essential in the short term, brings its own dangers. Not only is there a risk of the relief mentality being established but also there is the danger of the population increasing as a result of the reduction in mortality that relief brings and the increase in population making the longer term situation worse. It is important that relief aid be supplemented by programs to help the recipients produce their own food. For this reason the Committee makes some recommendations in relation to the fishing industry and dry-land farming in which Australians have developed expertise and in which Australians are already helping in Somalia.

The Committee also makes recommendations on more controversial matters. The matters which I have just mentioned are important but they could hardly be regarded as controversial. For example, the Committee examined the difficulties in delivering aid to Eritreans who are in revolt against the governing regime in Ethiopia. The Committee reached the opinion that Australian aid channelled through Sudan to the Eritrean Relief Association is an effective way of ensuring that aid reaches those in pressing need in Eritrea. Such aid can be channelled through non-government organisations based in Australia which have close association with the Australian Eritrean Relief Committee. I say this is controversial because it will obviously not have the support of the Mengistu regime in Ethiopia.

The Committee also examined the various allegations that the aid program to the Horn had been misapplied and was subject to corruption of one kind or another and should therefore be terminated. Allegations include the claims that aid is being or has been syphoned off to the armies, sold on the black market or used to finance Soviet arms bills. The Committee was satisfied that the evidence for these allegations is unsatisfactory. The Committee was not satisfied that there has never been any misapplication of aid but it could not obtain reliable evidence that corruption is on a significant scale. Mistakes of judgment in this area are easily made. For example, visitors to the Horn observe Australian food aid containers in the marketplaces and conclude that they contain Australian foodstuff which is being sold there and misapplied. In fact, these containers are valuable in themselves in these countries and will be used many times, long after the food aid once in them has been used up. Again, observers note what is plainly Australian food aid being sold in the market and ask why. The explanation is given that sometimes inappropriate aid is delivered-for example, cooking oil is given when there is little or nothing to cook-and that it is normal and accepted procedure to exchange such donations for more appropriate food aid.

Nevertheless, while not satisfied by the evidence of misuse or corruption, the Committee noted that Australia is too dependent for monitoring on international agencies in which Australia is not represented-there are some signs of change- and lacks the capacity for on the spot scrutiny. Our closest diplomatic post to the Horn is in Nairobi. This is a problem that must be addressed. In this respect I refer to the first report of this Committee, 'Some Observations on Australia's Diplomatic Representation in Africa'. The Committee recommended that consideration be given to the establishment of a mission resident in Addis Ababa . Australia's Ambassador to Ethopia is in Nairobi. The Committee recommended this because, among other things, it would meet the need to monitor the effectiveness of Australian development assistance and humanitarian aid to Ethiopia.

The Committee also considered the possibility of representation in Somalia but concluded that the opening of a post in Mogadishu could not be justified given Australia's other priorities and the scarcity of financial resources. Still, close attention should be paid by the Department of Foreign Affairs to developments in Somalia. The Committee noted that Australia does not have resident representation in Djibouti and in any case lacks the capacity for independent assessments in the whole of Francophone Africa, including Djibouti. It recommends that consideration be given to opening a post in one former French colony, such a post being then able to service other Francophone countries, such as Djibouti.

I hope and believe the report will be useful to the House and to the Jackson Committee. In conclusion, I support the Chairman in thanking Mr Ron Wiber and Justine Francis for their very valuable services to the Sub-Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 217th report of the Committee, relating to the Finance minute on report 186-Advance to the Minister for Finance (Appropriation Acts 1979-80), and I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 217th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts contains the Department of Finance minute on the Committee's earlier report-No. 186-on expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance under the Appropriation Acts 1979-80. The Department of Finance minute is the formal mechanism used by the Government for responding to the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's 186th report, which examined departments' expenditure from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, was tabled in Parliament on 17 April 1981. In accordance with normal practice the Committee obtained from departments 128 explanations relating to items from the Advance to the Minister for Finance in 1979-80. Four departments-the Departments of Finance, Social Security, Transport and Veterans' Affairs-were selected for public examination and additional written information was requested from a further 11 departments. The only amounts which should remain a charge to the appropriations for the Advance to the Minister for Finance at the end of the financial year are urgent and unforeseen expenditures which arise between the time of preparation of the additional Appropriation Bills-Nos. 3 and 4-and the close of financial year. In its examination, the Committee seeks to ascertain whether or not expenditure from the Advance has been confined to urgent and unforeseeable requirements for which provision could not have been made in the original or additional estimates .

The Committee concluded that in most cases expenditure was used according to the accepted guideline. In other cases, and in particular in relation to the Department of Transport, the Committee wrote to the Secretary to the Department of Finance and requested additional information on and clarification of the departmental responses to recommendations. The Committee considered the departmental responses did not adequately address the questions asked of it and failed to answer the more detailed questions concerning a number of deficiencies in the Department's estimating of financial control procedures. In the response from the Department of Transport there was evidence of clerical errors, inefficient estimating procedures and delays which caused expenditure to be charged to the Advance when provision should properly have been made in the Additional Estimates. The Committee is now satisfied with the response by the Department of Finance to report 186. I commend the report to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fry Mr K.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's report on the parliamentary zone development plan, together with extracts of the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report I have just tabled concerns a draft development plan for the parliamentary zone. Last October, the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory along with the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House received a briefing from the National Capital Development Commission on proposals for the future development of the parliamentary zone. Until recently the major planning priority has concentrated on the location, design and servicing of the site of the new Parliament House. This included the road access to the new House which the Committee has previously reported on. With the finalisation of major planning decisions concerning the Capital Hill area, attention then focused on the remainder of the parliamentary zone.

SPEECH.PARA: During the briefing by the Commission, it was pointed out that the quality of landscaping in the central northern part of the zone was poor. The landscaping had always been a temporary measure until the site for the permanent Parliament House was decided. Consequently it was minimal and poorly defined. The NCDC put before the Committee plans for correcting these deficiencies by creating a more coherent plan for the northern part of the zone-that is, for the area between the present House and the lake. The design reinforces the Burley Griffin land and water axis, provides a framework within which future public buildings can be located, and encourages increased tourist and pedestrian use of the lake edge.

The parliamentary zone is the focal point of the national capital and it should now be developed as such. The completion of the new House and the major design elements of the remainder of the parliamentary zone by 1988 will be a fitting way to mark the bicentenary in the national capital. The designs presented to the Committee are still evolving and the final designs may differ in some aspects. However, to work within a tight timetable and in keeping with good planning practice of allowing comment on planning at an early stage, the Commission has sought an early in principle approval of the plan. Several elements will require gazettal action and detailed scrutiny at a later date.

A major concern of the Committee was the lack of provision in the proposal for consultation with all senators and members or for that matter with the community . Parliament's role in the planning of the parliamentary zone was made clear in the Parliament Act 1974. The Act establishes Parliament's control over major works in the parliamentary zone. Therefore the Committee believes that all members and senators should have an opportunity to examine the proposals in detail and comment on them before final decisions are made. We have requested the NCDC to follow this procedure.

Despite its concern about the lack of consultation the Committee believes the development plan to be a good one because it provides an overall framework within which road proposals, landscape proposals and long term development can be resolved in a way that will complement the new Parliament House; the plan will complete Griffin's land axis between the new Parliament House and the lake; and the plan is sufficiently in keeping with Burley Griffin's plans given the structure and location of existing buildings and the need for the zone to cope with modern day traffic problems including tourist and commuter traffic. The 1983 plan provides a much clearer road system and an improved pedestrian environment in the Parliamentary Triangle. In general, the layout is now more suitable for tourists. I strongly recommend that all honourable members and senators read the report and, more importantly, examine the proposals for themselves when they become available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Deputy Speaker, I speak on this matter as a member of Parliament concerned about the way in which the Parliament has been treated in this case. The Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on the Australian Capital Territory has exhorted all honourable members to inform themselves about this very important matter of the development of the Parliamentary Zone and the particular plans that have been produced for that purpose, and has asked that honourable members inform themselves by reading the report. The fact of the matter is that most honourable members will not be able to inform themselves adequately by reading the report. They will be able to inform themselves adequately only if they have access to the very comprehensive material prepared by the National Capital Development Commission, outlining the plan about which the Committee has reported to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman mentioned that the Committee was of the view that the draft development plan it had under consideration ought to have been circulated by the National Capital Development Commission to all members of Parliament so that the Committee would be in a position adequately to seek the view of other members of Parliament about the proposals.

In many respects the National Capital Development Commission is a very competent and professional body. Anybody who has had any dealings with that body would know of the way in which it presents itself to the Committee. Very often it makes other organisations that appear before the Committee somewhat embarrassed about the way in which it is able to come forward with magnificent presentations. One could almost say-I am sorry I say it in the presence of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins)-that no expense is spared in presenting matters to the Committee and ensuring that information is put before it. It is done in a very professional way.

Of course in this case it did so again. Back in 1982 it produced its first draft plan, a very glossy production containing rather attractive pictures. One can see the comprehensive way in which the planning for the parliamentary precinct is to be undertaken. A further plan was prepared in September 1983. This is the document that we believe ought to have been circulated to all honourable members so they could be adequately informed about what is to be done in this region. The fact of the matter is that the Commission is asking for expedition of consideration of and parliamentary approval for the road variations intended in the plan and it wanted to ensure that members of the Committee were aware of them well beforehand so that its recommendations would have an easy passage.

I know, and other members will know, that time and time again we are asked in this Parliament to approve a whole lot of variations to the plan for the Parliamentary Zone. Those variations include police boxes-a very important matter, I am sure-and road barriers, of equal importance. People, sometimes at great difficulty to themselves, ensure attention to detail and ensure that the Parliament is informed on these matters. Yet, when it comes to informing honourable members at a stage when they can adequately consider variations within the Parliamentary Zone, we find that the Commission is unwilling to make information available to the Committee. The Committee, when it deliberated on this matter and made its comments, had before it a letter from the National Capital Development Commission. The Chairman wrote to the Commission and asked that all members of the Committee be given copies of this document so that they could discuss it with their collegues. On 24 February, Mr Browning, on behalf of the Commission, responded without commenting on that specific matter of the Commission's willingness to make this information available to other members.

I see that a number of honourable members are in the House at the moment. Some of them, such as the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Fry), already know about this matter but I hope that those who have heard the discussion will note the way in which the National Capital Development Commission is treating the Parliament in this instance and will feel as distressed as I do about the way in which this particular presentation has proceeded, and will not only take careful note of the Committee 's report but also seek from Committee members copies of the draft Parliamentary Zone development plan and make known their personal dissatisfaction that in this important area, at a time when planning is taking place, the Commission seems so unwilling to inform members adequately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Minister for Administrative Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals Nos 1 to 4 (1984) and Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 ( 1984).

The Customs proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. The proposals formally place before Parliament, as required by law, tariff alterations made by Australian Government Gazette notice during the recent recess.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1984), operative on and from 21 December 1983, amends the wording of tariff sub-item 22.09.1 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. This amendment removes the possibility of goods being incorrectly entered under the sub-item.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 2 (1984), operative on and from 13 January 1984, contains changes arising from the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on lawnmowers, certain engines and parts. Following consideration of that report, the Government decided that the general tariff rate of duty on lawnmowers will remain unchanged at 25 per cent while the duty on spark ignition engines up to 4.5 kilowatts will be reduced from 35 per cent to 25 per cent. Other engines under reference now enter at minimum rates of duty . The duties on filters under reference in the IAC's report will remain basically unchanged for the time being but will be reviewed in the context of the Government's consideration of the IAC's forthcoming report on heavy commercial motor vehicles, parts and accessories. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 2 (1984) also contain the following three changes:

First, an amendment to the description used in the rates of duty applicable to canned tomatoes of paragraph 20.02.69 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act. This change enables the duty intended for these goods to be correctly applied;
Secondly, an amendment to restore the margin of preference to certain plastic laminates of Canadian origin; and
Finally, an administrative change to align certain item numbers in Schedule 5 with the corresponding item numbers shown in the table in sub-section 26A (3) of the Customs Tariff Act 1982.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1984), operative on and from 27 January 1984, contains a change arising from the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on copper and certain copper products, including removal of export control. The Government accepted the IAC's recommendations that imports of copper semi-fabrications remain dutiable at 10 per cent and that mimimum rates of duty apply to all imports of copper matter, unwrought copper, whether refined or not, and copper waste and scrap. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 3 (1984) also inserts new sub-item 90.28.5 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act. The new sub-item applies to certain temperature control units and restores the levels of assistance which were removed from such goods by an Administrative Appeals Tribunal judgement.

Customs Tariff Proposals No. 4 (1984), operative on and from 24 February 1984, contain changes arising from the Government's decision on the Industries Assistance Commission report on fatty acids and certain aliphatic acids, their salts and esters; glycerol and tall oil. The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations with the exception of those applying to crude glycerol, glycerol lyes and lead stabiliser lubricants. The new general tariff rates which now apply are:
10 per cent in respect of oleic, stearic and other fatty acids, including tall oil fatty acids. Acid oils from refining and refined glycerol, and
20 per cent in respect of lead stabiliser lubricants.

No changes in general tariff rates are involved for the remainder of the goods under reference in this report. Crude glycerol and glycerollyes remain dutiable at minimum rates. The Government has decided that a 10 per cent duty on such imports as proposed by the IAC would have no protective value and would impose a tarriff induced cost only on Australian refined glycerol manfacture. A summary of alterations contained in these proposals has been circulated for the information of honourable members.

The excise proposals I have just tabled relate to a proposed alteration to the Excise Tariff Act 1921. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1984) formally place before Parliament, as required by law, a tariff alteration introduced during the summer recess by Excise Gazette Notice No. 8 (1983) under the authority of section 160B of the Excise Act. Excise Tariff Proposals No. 1 (1984) increases the excise duty on naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas from $48.57 to $ 49.23 per kilometre operating on and from 1 January 1984. This change was announced by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) on 19 December 1983. I commend the proposals to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 February, on motion by Mr Young:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, may I first congratulate you upon your appointment as Deputy Speaker. It is a most significant appointment for this House. Also I congratulate the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) who apparently competed with you very closely in your Party's ballot for the position. That again is significant. It is very nice that each of you will be presiding over this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Both the Liberal Party of Australia and National Party of Australia are committed to the removal of discrimination against individuals on whatever basis . Both are committed to equality of opportunity for individuals and in government took action in many fields to eliminate discrimination and enable genuine equality of opportunity to be achieved. An objective analysis of the previous coalition Government's record in immigration and ethnic affairs, the status of women, human rights, Aboriginals, disabled and otherwise disadvantaged persons shows this to be true. The previous Government established the National Women's Advisory Council which the present Government has arrogantly and foolishly abolished. The previous Government established the Human Rights Commission with the object of handling a wide range of matters relating to alleged discrimination and equality of opportunity. The administration of the proposals now before us will be by that Commission.

The previous Government was committed to introducing legislation aimed at eliminating discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy. In fact at the time the election was announced, my friend and colleague Tom McVeigh, the honourable member for Darling Downs, was about to bring to Cabinet- in his capacity as Minister for Home Affairs and Environment-a draft Bill for that purpose. That draft formed the basis for the Bill of which the new honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has given notice. The procedures of this House may not enable that Bill to be discussed, but it is to the credit of a new member that he has introduced a measure of this character. I am informed that all members of the National Party support that Bill, and that fact ought to lay to rest the absurd view emanating from certain quarters that legislation of this character in some way weakens the family by facilitating the entry of more married women into the paid work force. I do not doubt that some people genuinely hold that view, but it is an incorrect one nonetheless. If families or children were to suffer because of anti-discrimination legislation, no member or senator of this Parliament would even contemplate initiating let alone supporting such a measure.

There are differences between the legislation now under debate and that proposed by the honourable member for Gippsland, but it is significant that they both cover the same areas of activity in which discrimination occurs. The honourable member for Gippsland has concentrated his attention on discrimination in the Australian Capital Territory and in Commonwealth employment throughout Australia. If legislation of this character were remotely to threaten the wellbeing of families and the children within them the honourable member for Gippsland would not have given notice of this Bill. He would hardly take the view that it was reasonable to harm the families of the Australian Capital Territory or Commonwealth employees and not other families. On the contrary, what the honourable member has done is to act pursuant to long-standing policies of the Liberal and National Parties. There will always be room for disagreement on detail but the Opposition parties are united in principle.

If any honourable members opposite doubt that let me refer them to the first policy statement made jointly by the two parties when they contested the 1974 elections as a coalition opposition. The detailed statement on women in the community reveals a sound understanding of social and economic influences, the aspirations of women and the attitudinal barriers which they face in having genuine equality of opportunity with men. Despite the considerable progress made by the last coalition Government, the fact that there has been sustained and vocal opposition to this legislation demonstrates how deeply ingrained are the notions about the role of men and women in our society. There is distinct improvement in the outlook of those under 40 years but even though many males under 40 are now doing more of the parenting and domestic chores and are encouraging their wives to resume their careers outside the home, generally men are still not taking women's career aspirations seriously. I believe it to be important that I quote at length from page 51 of 'The Way Ahead', which was the coalition document in 1974 as its comment and commitment are as valid today as they were 10 years ago. Page 51 states:

The Liberal and Country Parties are dedicated to the pursuit of social freedom and the maximisation of equality of opportunity and status for men and women in the Australia community. Any form of arbitrary discrimination of social, economic, legal and educational nature is inconsistent with the philosophy of the Liberal and Country Parties. Where such discrimination is seen to exist, it is the policy of the Parties to strive concertedly for its elimination.

Certain differences in status continue to exist between the roles of men and women in the Australian society. These exist in both institutional and attitudinal terms. Were these differences are seen to arise from unfair discrimination or inequality of opportunity, a Liberal and Country Party Government is pledged to work actively for their elimination.
A Liberal and Country Party Government will promote, as a basic responsibility, those conditions in society that will enable all individuals to acheive their full potential.
