One of the most important developments in the latter half of the twentieth century has been the major reassessment of the role of women. The advancement of technology, the greater availability of education and the continuing decline in the number of children per family has greatly reduced the demands on women to fill a totally domestic role. Therefore the options and opportunities available to women today exceed those of her counterpart in past generations.

Throughout the twentieth century women in western society have been granted greater legal, political, and social status. There still remain areas in community life, however, where women have not yet achieved full equality with men. It is towards the eradication of these pockets of discrimination that the main thrust of a Liberal and Country Party Government's policy for women will be directed.
Governments, employers, trade union and education institutions are not fully attuned to the changing social attitudes and relationships in modern society.

The Liberal and Country Parties believe it is not sufficient to rely on slow evolutionary change to achieve full social justice for women. Rather the Parties are committed to the active advancement of women's rights in the context of a broad and integrated women's policy.

The first step towards the achievement of equal rights must abviously be to create and develop in the minds of all Australians a consciousness of the degree to which sexual discrimination continues to exist, the reasons why it continues to exist, and the means necessary to accelerate its eradication.

The 1974 policy statement of the coalition parties then went on to commit the coalition to action in education, child care, employment, training, taxation and family planning. It promised a national inquiry into the role of women, and out of that inquiry the previous Government established the National Women's Advisory Council which did much to break down the attitudinal barriers against women. Extensive efforts were made to identify women who were as qualified as men to serve on Government bodies. As a result, a range of government advisory and statutory bodies which would formerly have contained only men of Anglo- Celtic origin now contains people of ability regardless of sex, race, religion, or country of origin.

As a logical extension of that policy the coalition promised in 1980 to legislate to render unlawful discrimination on the grounds of sex. Had the Government completed its three-year term that legislation would have been enacted in 1983 and much of the controversy surrounding the present Bill would not have occurred. It is now a matter of record that this Bill was very badly drafted. So many amendments were necessary that the Bill had to be withdrawn and redrafted in a major way. There are still many changes which individual members of the Opposition would feel should be made and amendments will be moved in the Committee stage in order to remove certain defects. In government we would examine the operation of the legislation and amend it in whatever way then seemed appropriate. One factor of great relevance then would be the attitudes of State governments towards legislation of this character.

It is important to remember that the first such legislation was introduced by Liberal governments in Victoria and South Australia and the present Labor Government in New South Wales. Those Governments recognised the importance of such legislation and identified a desire for it. I cannot say, but it is quite possible that there is not the same desire for such legislation in the other three States. There presumably is in the Northern Territory because the Chief Minister there has criticised the Bill now before us as not going far enough. Mr Everingham has observed that the Bill does not deal with particular forms of discrimination against women in rural areas or that suffered by Aboriginal women still subject to discriminating tribal laws. Moreover, he is critical of the Bill for not dealing with prostitution. Mr Everingham bases his criticism on the fact that these problems are addressed particularly in the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. That Convention was signed by the previous Government and the ratification process begun by it was completed by the present Government. This Bill gives effect to certain of the provisions of that Convention, and not others.

In the Senate the opposition expressed its concern about the use of the external affairs power. I will speak in more detail on this matter when the House is in Committee examining individual clauses. It is sufficient to observe at this stage that it is difficult to say precisely how much of the Bill in practice will rest on the external affairs power. For example, most non- government schools are incorporated and for them the validity of the Bill rests on the corporations power. Non-incorporated schools can, it seems, be reached only by use of the external affairs power.

In practice the actual reliance on the external affairs power to legislate in areas not otherwise valid under Commonwealth power might prove to be slight or even marginal. Nevertheless the Opposition would not have relied on the external affairs power in government and will move in the Committee stage of this debate to have reliance on that power deleted from the Bill. The Government refused to accept that amendment in the Senate but I ask it to reconsider the matter as it is not essential to the overall effect of the Bill and represents a serious threat to the spirit of federalism underlying the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia. For these reasons the Opposition will move an amendment to the motion for the second reading clarifying its position regarding the implementation of certain parts of the UN Convention and the use of the external affairs power. It will not oppose the second reading of the Bill. Depending on the outcome of the Government's response to the Committee stage amendments some members of the Opposition may feel obliged to oppose the third reading of the Bill.

In the remaining time available to me and prior to moving the second reading amendment I wish to place this legislation in a social and economic perspective. In the coalition policy document of 1974 many pages were devoted to a thoughtful analysis of, and policy commitments regarding, women in various facets of Australian life. I have time to quote only one paragraph, from page 52, which states:

The provision of more adequate child-care facilities, greater and more flexible work opportunities are essential in our modern industrial and urban society if the family unit is to continue its role as the basis of our society. The precise proposals of the Liberal and Country Parties on these issues are outlined in the Education and Government Administration policy sections. For too long now, governments in framing their policies, and individuals in forming their attitudes have adhered to an over-rigid definition of the family. Both have failed to recognise that the family structure is changing. We recognise the increasing number of women who survive as widows to support a family on a widow' s pensions. We recognise and make accommodation for the growing number of single parents in the community. We recognise the fact that an increasing number of unmarried mothers are now keeping their children in preference to having them adopted.

The previous Government tried to deal with the problems disclosed in that and other parts of that document. It introduced the concept of family allowances to begin the process of lifting the status of women otherwise totally dependent on another person's income. That Government also greatly increased various forms of child care-including assisting the formation of occasional, holiday and after- school care facilities. But the demand outstripped the capacity to supply. The present Government is finding the same problem. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, outbid Mr Fraser in his election promise for child care but both the May mini- Budget and the August Budget disappointed those who wanted that promise fulfilled. At the same time some State governments have cut back on child care and pre-school assistance.

I warn the Government now that if it does not use its influence with the State governments and, through the States, local government to meet the needs of local communities for child care it will be betraying the trust of many who voted for it and will receive and deserve serious admonition from the electorate and the Opposition. For again, it remains even more true than in 1974 that child care and early childhood development are essential facilities which must be fostered and partly supported by the three arms of Government. The Coalition's 1974 policy stated: 'We believe that pre-school education is of fundamental importance to the development of each child and its later achievements. It is important therefore to provide children with the opportunity for access to pre- school education'.

In the great education debates of the nineteenth century there were arguments about those whose responsibility it was to educate children-the parents or the state. The answer was, and remains, both. The arbitrarily chosen starting age of five years has long been seen to be inappropriate in terms of the child's learning capacity. Early childhood development on a federalist approach is, therefore, most important for the child. But its relevance to this debate lies in the ability of child care to enable parents to pursue for some hours each week things which they deem vital or important for themselves and other members of their family. Extended families once provided occasional care facilities but now the main source of this assistance is from child care centres. So ultimately the ready availability of quality, cost-effective child care is crucial to the ability of parents to exercise their rights as individuals to equality of opportunity. I stress the word 'parents' because early childhood development and child care are the responsibility of parents, not simply mothers as is commonly supposed. Child care, including work-based facilities, ought to be open to the children of male and female members of the community. Child care is not solely the responsibility of women but, while it is thought to be, the absence of child care facilities discriminates against women as well as the children who would otherwise benefit from the additional development which quality child care centres provide.

Children are a nation's most important resource and its greatest responsibility . The responsibility is primarily that of parents but the community must aid those parents and their children variously. The debate over early childhood development belongs in a broader community debate and, when that is generally accepted, the question of equal opportunity for women will be viewed in a more rational light and more progress will be made. At the heart of that debate, also , is the explanation for the fact that while most women are not dependent on welfare, the vast majority of people who have to exist on welfare are women. The conduct of men towards women and the rights of women as equal individuals has huge implications for a range of government policies. To talk, for example, of cutting the welfare bill without examining social change is utterly futile.

Thus, this Bill is a symbol of the commitment of this Parliament to remove barriers of law and practice to the exercise of equality of opportunity regardless of sex, marital status or pregnancy. It is an important part-but only a part-of helping to change discriminatory attitudes. Sadly, these attitudes are deeply entrenched-as is evidenced by the reports of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity in Victoria and the Anti-Discrimination Board of New South Wales.

Discrimination is probably not increasing but it does not seem to be diminishing either. The increased number of complaints indicates that people are exercising newly created rights rather than leaving jobs or suffering discrimination. It is disturbing to see how extensive has been the discrimination and sexual harrassment at the work place and we may only yet see the tip of the iceberg. It is even more disturbing to read of the rise in the incidence of indirect discrimination. And it is appalling to find that some practices intended to be eliminated by State laws are continuing and may even be increasing.

Thus, it is disturbing to read in the Victorian report of 1983 that women continue to suffer disadvantages with credit, finance, banking services and insurance. Discrimination against women seeking accommodation also remains a greater problem than one would have hoped after six years of operation of the Victorian Act. Those six years have revealed examples of indirect discrimination which are prohibited by this Bill. I will refer more fully to reports on State legislation and to the incidence of discrimination when the debate reaches the Committee stage. Anyone who doubts the need for this legislation or legislation of this character ought to read those reports.

Public education is essential to change these unthinking biases and the operation of this and similar legislation will assist this process but of course it will not complete it. The importance of this education lies not only in the rights of individuals to equality of opportunity, but also in Australia's making the maximum use of her human resources. How stupid we would be to squander over 50 per cent of our human resources on the grounds of sex. Yet that is what we are in danger of doing. The experience of the three States which have equal opportunity legislation reveals what the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity in Victoria calls:

The persistently greater potential for discrimination against women in all aspects of employment; the fact that women are especially vulnerable to discriminatory treatment in termination of their employment; and the pervasive sexual harassment which continues to destroy women's enjoyment of work, hamper their effective performance, and threaten them with loss of their jobs.

On the broader matter of the contribution of women in the paid work force I wish to refer to a recent survey by the Centre for Government Studies of the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology entitled 'Women who work in Local Government'. That report showed that in local government in Victoria, within the next five years, 50 per cent of the women now employed expect to remain in local government, most with the same council; 21 per cent of those now employed do not expect to be in the paid work force in five years; and 26 per cent would be out of local government but still in the paid work force. The sad and stupid situation regarding the 26 per cent is, to quote the report:

This is a critical group. Not only are they primarily professionals, other than social workers, but they are in the 26-35 age group which is, workwise, a productive period following training, and the group from which future managers will emerge. Most importantly, they are leaving because they are dissatisfied with their current work and conditions, especially the lack of promotion prospects. This finding emerges consistently throughout the results.

That finding would be bad enough if it were confined to local government but I have no doubt that it is equally true of all areas of the public sector employment and nearly all areas of the private sector in Australia. As a result, we are wasting the creativity, training, experience and energy of half of those who are or wish to be in our paid work force. If we want to lift our national productivity that would be a good place to start. To quote the report again:

Statistics indicate high levels of participation in the work force by women, together with an increasing trend for women to return to work after child bearing. They now more closely than ever approximate male rates of participation in the work force . . . in Victoria in 1982, women made up 45.7 per cent of the work force (ABS time series). 63 per cent of working women were married while 41 per cent of married women were in the work force, as compared with 13 per cent in 1954 and 25 per cent in 1964. This trend is supported by American data.
The report records further what has been revealed elsewhere:
In 1978, in Australia women comprised 45.5 per cent of professional, technical and related fields and 12.5 per cent of administrative, executive and managerial categories.

Despite their greater participation in the work force where they are almost on the same participation rate as males, less than 1 per cent of women hold managerial and executive jobs. Even with jobs requiring special skills, such as teaching, women are clustered at lower levels in spite of comparable qualifications with men. Moreover, not only are women disproportionately represented in certain occupational groupings but also they receive lower monetary rewards. Evidence of this may be found in various Australian Bureau of Statistics publications, reports of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the Australian Quarterly, summer issue 1983 , papers produced for the 1983 Australian National University conference on social justice for women in Australia and documents issued for the National Economic Summit. Moreover, that research shows that women account for many of those who want to work but are so discouraged by their failure to obtain work that they do not even register with the Commonwealth Employment Service for jobs unless they are entitled to unemployment benefits. Thus, many married women who are searching for jobs are among the 'hidden unemployed' and do not appear in the monthly statistics. In 1981 it was estimated that there were as many hidden unemployed as recorded unemployed. In March 1983 the ABS found that there were 113,000 discouraged job seekers, of whom 84.8 per cent were women. The ABS data also showed that there were 559,000 women who wanted a job but were not actively seeking paid work. The number of women recorded as unemployed represented only 35 per cent of the total number of women who wanted a job.

It should be obvious to all that many women already wish to participate in the paid work force as much as do married men. When they seek to exercise their rights they ought not to be discriminated against in any way. The Bill, when enacted, will not persuade more people to enter the paid work force, but it will ensure that those who do will not suffer discrimination without rights of redress. It is in the enlightened self-interest of employers and for the benefit of individuals and Australia that this discrimination be exposed and eradicated. As foreshadowed earlier, on behalf of the Opposition I now move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst welcoming the intention of the Bill to remove discrimination against the people on the basis of sex, marital status or pregnancy, the House is of the opinion that:
(1) the Bill should not rely on the external affairs power as a head of power;
(2) Australia's signature to the United Nations Convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women should not be used to extend the powers of the Commonwealth;

(3) the removal of discrimination against people on the basis of sex should be recognised as not obliging anyone to enter the paid work force or alter their views of their responsibilities towards their spouses or children;

(4) no decision or action by any educational or child care or other body established for the education of students or the care of children in accordance with the doctrines of a religion or creed or in accordance with stated principles should be affected where that decision or action has been taken in good faith to enable the body to conform with those doctrines or principles;
(5) nothing in the Bill should be taken as approving those articles of the Convention which are not implemented by the Bill, and
(6) the clauses of the Bill should be re-drafted accordingly.'

TALK.START.PARA: -Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me very great pleasure to speak at long last on the Sex Discrimination Bill. It is a most significant promise of the Australian Labor Party, to which I belong, and has been implemented as quickly as possible. I thank the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) for his very learned and extended support for most of the principles of this Bill. I would like to correct one or two things. While we appreciate the very great value of the work of the National Women's Advisory Council, our policy is-and it is in the process of being implemented-to replace that body with a much wider group of women who can consult with the Government and who can give us the benefit of their wide base of experience.

SPEECH.PARA: That is under way and that will continue to be under way. That work is being backed up by the status of women committee of this Government which meets every week to care for the concerns that have come up during that week. The Office of the Status of Women has been transferred, as honourable members know, to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and upgraded to the rank of Division. That is evidence of our seriousness about the status of women.

I was very glad to hear the honourable member talk about the need for child care, including work-based facilities, because one of the things that I do in this place is work on the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House. To my astonishment, I found at the beginning of last year when I joined the Committee that in that enormous building with its upwards of 4,000 people who will be working there no child care facility had been provided. I am very proud to be the the chairman of the sub-committee looking at providing child care facilities for the new Parliament House. I am glad to say that it is not too late to look at child care facilities for the new Parliament House.

The important question is whether this legislation is necessary. I believe the honourable member for Balaclava has demonstrated extremely clearly its necessity . If this is so, will it change the fabric of our society in a way which could have undesirable consequences? It is a matter of demonstrable and demonstrated fact that women have not been fairly treated in many aspects of life. Perhaps it is enough for us to contemplate for a moment the balance in this House. That question really answers itself. Of the 123 members, six are women. They are all from the party with an affirmative action policy and a commitment to removing discrimination. I do not believe that the Liberal and National Parties have no women capable of bringing, or desiring to bring, to the legislative process the necessary skills. Nevertheless, here we are. There are no women on the Opposition side and six on this side. It is not an enormously good record, is it ?

Listing the evidence of clear discrimination in employment, in education, in clubs, in businesses, and in other areas of public life would take the rest of this debate, and it is well documented for anyone who wishes to take the trouble to examine it. If a group of the population is being discriminated against, no fair-minded government responsible to its constituents can or should ignore that fact. It is fairly common that those who are discriminatory, and who always have been, do not understand their action and attitudes to be so, and that those who have always been discriminated against can accept that position-some of them at any rate. That is not, however, a sufficient reason for a government to draw back from legislating against customary or deliberate discriminatory actions within the public arena. This Bill does not attempt to legislate against attitudes, but against actions. It forbids the kinds of behaviour which would, on the basis of gender, or factors such as pregnancy arising from that gender, lead to the exclusion of women from opportunities or services which would otherwise be available. Apart from the pregnancy provisions, the Sex Discrimination Bill applies to men as well. We ought not to forget that. However , it is more important to women because they are the people within our society who have been discriminated against. This has been distorted to mean an attack on family life, an attempt to force women into the work place against their will , and an attack on the freedom of the Australian people.

I will deal with the last issue first. I have received a rather curious letter from a Mrs Jackie Butler, Chairman of the Council for a Free Australia, which closes with the statement that '. . . free Australians will never accept these savage restrictions on their choices'. Just exactly who are the free Australians for whom Mrs Butler takes up the cudgels? Are they, for example, the people who wish to be free to continue to practice sexual harassment in the work place or in educational institutions, or are they those who perhaps wish to be sexually harassed? That is their choice. They may invite it if they will, but they may not impose it. Thousands of Australian women will be glad of this 'savage restriction' on the liberties taken with their persons. In this House there are people who would do well to remember that. Or are they the people who wish to be free to exclude women from promotion to senior positions, to exclude them from employment, from admission to clubs using public facilities, from admission to partnerships and who wish to take for themselves alone the privileges which should, in a just society, be properly shared? I reject those freedoms because they depend on discrimination against more than half the population.

Clause 6 forbids discrimination on the grounds of marital status. Unless one is prepared to defend the notion that marriage, per se, removes skills and decreases intellectual ability, one must admit that discriminating on the grounds of marital status should be either abandoned or applied to all married people.

Clause 7 defines discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy, and clause 31 provides an exemption for the rights and privileges granted in connection with pregnancy or childbirth. Either one accepts that pregnancy and childbirth are normal physical functions, impairing skills and expertise not at all, or one is faced with the proposition that there is something not quite right about these functions. I am sure that none of the fecund fathers in this House would want to take that on. However, it is unreasonable to expect that one can totally ignore pregnancy and childbirth and therefore the conditions which are necessary protections are exempt.

Let us consider further the issues involved in the women in the home question as opposed to the women in the work force question as this is at the heart of the real concern expressed about legislation such as this. When equal opportunities provisions or sex discrimination legislation are discussed, the discussion tends to centre around the problems encountered by women in the work force. Those women whose work is in the home feel somewhat devalued by this emphasis. Their work is in any case devalued by the whole of society. Their feeling of devaluation because of the emphasis on the problems of women in the work force is a serious problem to anyone wishing to discuss sex discrimination.

This Bill, although it is certainly concerned with employment factors, is by no means wholly concerned with them. It very largely deals with discriminatory practices in the provision of goods and services and in the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs. This makes sure that women are not discriminated against in their financial and business affairs, in their requirement for accommodation, in education, and in a wide range of other matters not connected with employment, but extremely important to all women. We have endless evidence to suggest that women are discriminated against in accommodation, particularly if they have children. They are discriminated against in financial and business affairs because it is considered by those people who do not understand the difference between being equipped to deal with something and being of one sex or another that they are not equipped to deal with such affairs.

Those people who would draw the simplistic dichotomy between mothering and homemaking as good and proper for all women and maternity and career as bad are doing an enormous disservice to all women in their opposition to the correction of the wrong treatment of women because they are women. Women's traditional work is very restricted in scope. It may not use a woman's full abilities and women quite rightly resent a restriction upon the use of their abilities imposed by custom or allowed by law. However, it is this perception of women either as mother and homemaker or contributor to the restricted work which has had some influence on the position in which women as a group find themselves-passed over, pushed aside, not short-listed, not promoted, not treated as seriously able to deal with business matters, not able to run their affairs properly, not desirable tenants, not acceptable club members, and altogether not quite real people who can use a screwdriver, fix a fuse and efficiently and effectively do a whole range of things which are considered to be within the normal almost innate capacity of men.

None of the proposals in this Bill will have the effect of forcing women out of the home if that is where they want to be, but if they wish to do something else they will not meet the kinds of discrimination which have previously been lawful . In talking about the policies and practices of the previous Government, discriminatory factors which allow women to be discriminated against in a range of employment are lawful and will remain lawful until this Bill is passed. It is the experience of every member of this House in talking to large groups of senior or important people, whether in education, some society or other, or simply to people who are running various aspects of society, that women are heavily under-represented. The group may well pretend to be a group based on merit, capacity, interest, or simply based on its members wanting to be there. One will find that the same thing is true in voluntary societies all over the country. The people who do the work tend to be the women and the ones who make the decisions tend to be the men. It has been one of my interests to keep saying to women: 'You see that you are president and leave the men to be secretaries and coffee-makers'.

Sexual harassment in education has been a very serious problem for a long time because it has been covered up. There has been no redress for young women and girls-unless they are under the age of consent-who are sexually harassed by people who should be concerned only with their educational progress. There have been many instances of sexual blackmail of young women students in universities and tertiary institutions. It is a disgraceful part of our society that that could ever be covered up or could be seen to be something which had to be put up with. This Bill forbids that and gives redress to those young women should they be harassed. One of the things in regard to educational institutions is the provision in this Bill which exempts:

. . . an educational institution that is conducted in accordance with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a particular religion or creed, if the first-mentioned person so discriminates in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherence of that religion or creed.

The Bill has been written very carefully all the way through to exempt those groups of people, those parts of society and those elements of employment which do not discriminate on the grounds that they just do not think women can do it, but which discriminate on the basis of some other properly held ground.

I believe that the amendments which have been made to the Bill are, in some cases, fair enough. I do not like the amendment which the Opposition has now moved, because that certainly has nothing to do with the guts of this Bill, which is about removing the possibility of people in the public arena making decisions disadvantageous to women generally and to society as a whole. Redress will be available when this Bill becomes law and that redress has to do with fair and proper hearings of complaints and cases. It has to do with the fact that one simply cannot make laws and hope that people will obey them; one has to put a few teeth in them somewhere.

As I said before, we are not legislating against attitudes. We do not pretend to be able to do that. One would hope that attitudes will change as the legislation takes hold and people discover that attitudes they have held have in fact militated against the better progress of their businesses or of the society in which they live. One thing is certain: We can wait no longer to legislate against discrimination, because all the exhortation, all the advisory councils and all the publicity in the world have not made any difference at all to the practices which we now would forbid. Because those practices are so ingrained in our society and in our thinking we would have to wait for generations before we could change them. I know that there have been changes in attitudes to women, but those changes have to be translated into action. The attitudes which will not be changed will not be able to be translated into the kind of action against which we would legislate.

I know that many honourable members want to speak on this Bill, so I will cut short my speech. I will simply say that I think this is one of the most important pieces of legislation that this Government has introduced. I am glad that the Opposition will not oppose the second reading. I hope that it will see that its amendment is not appropriate to this Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to compliment all honourable members who have been involved in the debate on the Sex Discrimination Bill, particularly the last speaker, the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer). I wish to compliment the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), who is the Opposition spokesman on this issue. I have been to every meeting which he has conducted on this subject. Many of us have put a lot of time into this matter. I feel though that for the Bill to be acceptable to me, the Government will need to accept our amendment. I know that it has treated this amendment with the seriousness that it deserves and I trust that it will accept it. I have some fears that it may not. Therefore, at this early stage in the debate I need to put down the reasons why I think the Government should accept our amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three major areas of concern regarding this Bill. It compromises the sovereignty of the Federal and State parliaments of Australia through unnecessary reference to an external United Nations convention; it employs State coercion in seeking desirable social goals; and it gives new regulatory powers to commissioners separate from our courts of law.

As an Australian and as a federalist I deplore the passing of any legislation that purports to effect an external convention. The United Nations has some value in providing an international talking-shop, a safety valve, and some useful mechanisms and agencies. However, I believe the people of Australia would be horrified to think of it as some kind of incipient world government, whose decrees and conventions are morally superior to the laws of this country-far from it. Most of its member nations are not democracies and many are ruled by Marxist tyrannies. Hypocrisy and humbug are their stock in trade. At times there may be no harm in Australia's subscribing to those UN conventions which set forth desirable principles or innocuous sentiments however much we may doubt the sincerity of our fellow signatories. It is quite another matter to give such a convention any kind of legal standing that would interfere with the lives of Australians.

The UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women makes perfectly good sense if it relates to the removal of social and legal repression of women as it exists in many Third World countries. Its application to Western democracies is more doubtful. Either it is irrelevant or it becomes the vehicle for the imposition of unspecified and limitless demands, creating rights that connote burdensome duties for our society. The point remains that it is too vague to be applied to Federal and State law. Therein lies the danger. Determined, selective interpretation of this alien contract could bring forward changes in the future that this Government would not dare to introduce in this Parliament.

We already have an example of how a foreign convention has been used to subvert State authority and trample the rights of some individual Australians. I refer of course to the World Heritage Listing that led to the Franklin Dam decision. I do not particularly want to canvass that issue because many advocates in this Parliament could do it far better than I. Parts of Mr Justice Murphy's judgment have a wider bearing. He said:
Increasing use of the external affairs power will not be exceptional or extraordinary but a regular way in which Australia will harmonise its internal order with the world order.
Some world! Some order! Mr Justice Murphy further asserted:
Parliament has the authority to take Australia into the 'one world', sharing its responsibilities.

With all due respect to His Honour, this is a sentiment which, quite frankly, would disgust the great majority of Australians, particularly my people in Western Australia. We want to be governed by laws passed through Australian parliaments by members responsible to the people through the ballot box. Neither this Government nor any other was elected to subordinate Australians to some dubious supra-national authority. We do not want Iran, Libya or the Soviet Union having the most indirect of inputs into our national life. At the same time we stand warned that there are people in high places who appear to view such a development with positive approval.

It is all too clear that some vague foreign convention can be, and has been, to overrule the decision of an elected Australian Parliament in Tasmania. Still unresolved are compensation and other matters that have been raised by Tasmanians in this place in the last two days. To write into this or any other Bill a reference to the United Nations anti-discrimination convention provides a sinister catch-all clause extending the matter a lot further than is spelt out in front of us today. Selective interpreters of this marvellously opaque convention, whether they be of the judiciary, Cabinet, or bureaucracy, will have a field day. Despite current assurances that some aspects of the Convention will not be implemented, any reference to the United Nations Convention could be a means by which the unacceptable face of the program of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) would one day be imposed upon the people of this country.

External conventions are a useful means of breaking down the authority of elected State parliaments over areas that, by established tradition and practice , have been left to them. I believe that the people of Forrest, and of Western Australia generally, want those things that most affect their daily lives to remain with the State parliament, a sphere of government that is closer to them. While this Parliament has proper authority over such areas as defence, foreign affairs, overseas trade and general economic management, the States have looked after law and order, and have regulated social relationships, to the extent that that is necessary in a free society. Not only do we have a federal government buying into this area with a vengeance but, to back that up we have a catch-all clause which refers to a United Nations convention.

What I fear is so-called affirmative action. Although this Bill does not mention it, the matter is highly relevant when we have in Cabinet a Minister who makes no secret of her desire to inflict this upon us. Affirmative action can mean only one thing-the rejection of qualified applicants because they do not belong to the sex, race or group judged worthy of assistance. There is all the difference in the world between removing legislative and administrative impediments to human potential-the proper role of parliament-and trying to foster the social advancement of any group of Australians, which can so easily degenerate into that great twentieth century evil, social engineering. Even now affirmative action causes damage in the United States where students are denied entry to some tertiary faculties because they are not black. That is a long way from John Kennedy's struggle to enable blacks to go to the university. The example is quoted of the American who said, 'In the twenties I couldn't get into Harvard Law School because I was Jewish; now my grandson cannot get in because he is white'. I have too great a concern for the advancement of women in Australia ever to see created a situation in which a man would have grounds to say to a female colleague: 'I got here because of my ability and hard work; you got here through affirmative action'. Once we cease merely to remove injustice and seek rather to promote advancement of groups or sexes in place of qualified individual men and women, we do harm to the very people whose interests we seek to promote.

I turn now to the general reservations that I have towards a Bill that regulates social conduct. Whenever it is proposed to instil morality by legislation we should ask whether the application of law and bureaucracy will really diminish social evils and increase the sum of human happiness. Will wrong social conduct really be curbed by law? I often call to mind these words of Professor Lachlan Chipman in 1979 when discussing the principle of all anti- discrimination legislation:
It has long been known that the bad man was never made good, only cunning, by laws rendering his immorality illegal.

People who have a deep prejudice on racial or sexual grounds will find a way around legislation, while innocent employers may find themselves coerced into accepting unsuitable staff for fear of an ill-defined law. I believe that has happened in Victoria to quite a large degree.

Again, it would seem far more suitable for the States, rather than the Commonwealth, to have responsibility for detailed anti-discrimination legislation in this and similar categories. Essentially, this Bill will deal in areas traditionally governed by State law. I refer to labour relations, working conditions, education and public decorum. The people of Australia should be left to charge their State parliamentary representatives with implementing any laws appropriate to sex discrimination. If they feel that their State governments are not responding to their wishes, the mechanism of the ballot box will continue to be effective. The constant intrusion of this Parliament in the activities of States is hailed by some as a positive development, a national coming of age. I rather fear that it betokens a subtle national decline, a retreat into sterile centralism, a hardening of the national arteries. Government becomes less responsive rather than more so.

Government supporters will say that opposition to the Bill will mean that I as an individual am unconcerned or hostile to the advancement of women. On the contrary, I believe that the Federal Government has a duty to ensure that barriers against the employment of qualified women are swept away in all areas under its jurisdiction. This should be a constant process, not one requiring blanket legislation. There will be occasion for specific reforms to allow more women to achieve their full potential. On the one hand we need to introduce income splitting, so that some women now working of necessity can choose to become full-time homemakers, while on the other hand child minding expenses for single mothers should be fully rebatable. In that way some women might have the option of returning to the work force rather than depending on the State. I believe that anomalies that disadvantage women can be weeded out swiftly and simply if there is a will on the part of government.

The overall thrust of this ill-drafted Bill is to create suspicion between the sexes. At a time when the law is being withdrawn from the field of sexual relationships, a development that in the main is healthy, we are confronted with a new principle-that the manner of acting towards someone of the opposite sex has become a matter of public concern and public law. I have yet to be convinced that legal coercion is the proper means of overcoming negative social attitudes. One cannot instil morality through law. Recognising this, Australian society has moved to a de facto if not de jure toleration of homosexuality. Now, through this Bill, we are moving in the opposite direction. Libertarians as well as social conservatives should be concerned.

Central to the Bill is the elimination of discrimination in employment. I do not dissent from that objective, although I consider that changes in employer attitudes, which have already taken place, have removed a great deal of unfairness. After all, the employer is the loser if he or she allows sexist prejudice to deprive the firm or institution or individual of a better qualified employee. This Bill makes the unwarranted assumption that when the sole apparent difference between two applicants for a job is their sex, the person making the choice must have chosen on the grounds of sex. No recognition is given to the likelihood that more appealing personal qualities and the ability to work in harmony with existing staff could have influenced the decision. For this reason, I am entitled to have a valid concern that such a law could result in unsuitable applicants forcing themselves upon employers, using the threat of the coercive machinery of the Act, as much as by actual decision of the Commission. A person could force his or her way into an employer institution with whose principles that person was not conscientiously in agreement.

I make no apology for affirming the right of a school or like institution to insist on standards of sexual behaviour on the part of its employees or students . Indeed, parents have a right to expect that the school environment will foster the moral development of their children. To maintain such an environment may require the setting and enforcing of standards of private behaviour. After all, staff are not compelled to work in independent schools, nor parents to send their children there.

The new clause 38 goes some way to protect the integrity of independent schools , but I am unconvinced that it goes far enough. True, a teacher forming a sexual relationship with a senior pupil will be unable to claim the protection of the Sex Discrimination Act. Yet, a school has to admit that it discriminated. It has to prove that it did so in good faith and in accord with religious precepts. A malicious and determined litigant may ask the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and ultimately the judiciary precisely what aspect of religious doctrine was being upheld. Clause 38, therefore, might not protect the school unattached to any specific denomination but run on broad, conservative ethical principles. Parents remain entitled to the assurance that their children will be educated in this particular ethical environment, yet the school will not be able to claim that it upholds behavioural standards to accord with religious ideals.

Turning to Division 3 of the Bill, I fully agree that sexual harassment is an evil. Yet I fear that this Bill will do more for lawyers than for the genuine victims of harassment. Words and phrases such as 'unwelcome', 'disadvantage', ' reasonable grounds for believing', 'in any way', 'possible', and 'statement of a sexual nature' are delightfully vague and give enormous grounds for litigation. I am greatly concerned that a person so accused would have the job in front of him or her to prove his or her innocence and fight his or her way out of the legal thicket. Far more thought should have been given to this section of the Bill.

Threatening to accuse someone of sexual harassment could become a subtle means of blackmail. Sexual advances, once welcomed and reciprocated, could be retrospectively brought forward in quite a new light. Equally, what most of us would sensibly regard as friendly, outgoing behaviour between the sexes in the workplace could be subject to a new interpretation in a court of law or some bureaucratic star chamber. It would be rather sad if this zealous regulation of social behaviour made us all that more withdrawn into ourselves. Again I remind the House that the employer who harasses staff in a sexual manner will create his own punishment when able staff choose to work elsewhere.

I appreciate that the enforcement procedures of the Bill have been modified in the Senate. Thanks to the efforts of the Senate Opposition and the Government, to which I gave an accolade at the beginning of my speech, no longer do the rules of evidence disappear in inquiries by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and the Human Rights Commission. Nor will people be denied the right of legal representation before the Commission. The onus of proof before the Federal Court will not now be reversed. Nevertheless, there is no reason for us to be filled with gratitude. It is an old political trick to drop the most outrageous features of a proposal in order to secure 80 per cent of one's objective in a wave of popular relief. An example of this is the assets test. This Government has quite a talent for it. Still, we are entitled to question the sincerity and morality of an Attorney-General and a government that would allow such unjust, dictatorial proposals to go before Parliament in the first place. We can only assume that the original Bill contained exactly what the Government would like to inflict on us, if it could get away with it. It is a grim warning of what the Hawke Government would do if it controlled both Houses of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to the Committee stage of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1984 when I will then join with my colleagues in answering many of the claims made by members such as the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond).

SPEECH.PARA: This is both an historic and a proud day for me and for many women throughout Australia. For the past 14 years many of us have argued about the need for sex discrimination legislation and now years of hard work are about to be fulfilled. In a matter of days this Government will enact that legislation. I am proud to be standing here taking part in this debate, proud of my Party, of the Government, and of the many women who will rejoice with me when this Bill becomes law.

Madam Deputy Speaker, before I address myself to the Bill itself, I want to acknowledge my Caucus colleagues in this Parliament, and congratulate them on their attitude towards the elimination of sex discrimination. When I first became a member of this place I did not expect to see the level of commitment from my male colleagues towards the advancement of women. That commitment is there and I acknowledge it. I wish also to acknowledge the many women who have spent years striving for this result. There are thousands of them but I am able to mention just a few. First I mention those who at the turn of the century fought for women's rights. Among them were Marion Phillips, Alice Henry, Jean Beadle, Muriel Matters, Irene Driver, later Irene Greenwood who is still fighting for women's rights, Jessie Street and Muriel Heagney. May I also mention a few women who today are known to me and who have fought for women's rights over the years. They include Edna Ryan, Elizabeth Reid, Sara Dowse, Eva Cox, Gail Radford, Nancy Refeld, Debra McCulloch, Senators Susan Ryan and Patricia Giles, Rosa Walden, Mary Owen, Dot Goodrich and Carmel Niland.

There are two problems which arise whenever a human rights issue is opened up for debate. The first is that people who have not been the victims of some form of discrimination find it very hard to grasp the essence of what it feels like to be treated as a person outside the mainstream of social, economic and political life. That this problem has arisen during the sex discrimination debate has been graphically illustrated by the contributions made by some members of the Opposition in the other place. Tribute must be paid, however, to the many insightful and sensitive comments from men and women on both sides of that chamber which have given great encouragement to those of us who have long been committed to introducing sex discrimination legislation.

The other problem is that wherever one finds grossly unfair discrimination or inequality, one will also find a group or section of society profiting in some way from the situation. And, of course, it will be these people who will shout the loudest when a proposal is put forward to eliminate those forms of discrimination. Thus we are finding in the sex discrimination debate at typical 'roads to ruin' outcry: The very structure of society is under threat it is claimed, that totalitarian state is taking over, and individual freedom and liberty are about to be denied.

Those honourable members who know something of the history of political, legal and social reform will recognise this as the very same argument which was flung at the people who first suggested abolising slavery in the Deep South of America or who campaigned in favour of laws to stop small children being sent up chimneys or down coal mines. Like every politician in Australia, I have received a certain amount of correspondence during the last 12 months about both the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and the Sex Discrimination Bill. With only one or two exceptions, the Opposition to the Convention and the Bill has not been based on the factual content of implications of either document. I have supplied all my correspondents with detailed information, and I am happy to report that as the information was disseminated through the community, so opposition to the Convention and the Bill has been overcome. I pay tribute to the staff of the Office of the Status of Women for the excellent quality of the explanatory leaflets and guides which they have produced during the last year.

Let us just look at some of the other groups and individuals who have indicated their support for the Bill as it now stands before the House. Mention has already been made in the other place of the Women's Electoral Lobby, the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women, the National Council of Women of Australia, the United Nations Association of Australia, the Union of Australian Women, the Women and Development network and the Young Women's Christian Association of Australia. To this list my colleague Senator Crowley has added the Catholic Church, the Young Liberal Movement and Judith Roberts, the former South Australian chairperson of the Liberal Party. Dame Beryl Beaurepaire made a notable contribution to the debate last year when she indicated her support for sex discrimination legislation. Perhaps the most significant sign of the groundswell of support for the Bill is the statement signed by nine of our most prestigious Opposition senators at the conclusion of the Senate debate. This statement clearly sets out the positive factors which guided the senators in reaching their decision to vote in support of the Bill.

For the sake of those inside and outside this House who have not had the time, the opportunity or perhaps the inclination to inform themselves about this Bill and the types of discrimination it seeks to counter, it is worth considering some of the facts with which Australian women of all ages are confronted today. We now make up 37 per cent of the work force, as compared with 30.6 per cent in 1966. The female labour force increased by 68.1 per cent between 1966 and 1982 while the male labour force increased by 25.9 per cent.

Between 1966 and 1982 the number of married females in the labour force increased as a proportion of the total female labour force from 52.2 per cent to 59.8 per cent. In 1981, 45 per cent of women with dependent children were in the labour force and women with dependent children comprised 37.6 per cent of the female labour force. Research has indicated that only 26 per cent of families in Australia fit the nuclear model and that about 15 per cent are single parent families. In 41.2 per cent of married couple families both husband and wife are in the labour force. Of these 58.9 per cent have dependent children. More than 90 per cent of single parent households are headed by women. The number of single parent families increased by 57 per cent between 1976 and 1981. I ask the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) to take note of those figures. In 1981, 13 per cent of children aged less than 15 and 11 per cent of those 15 to 19 years of age lived in single parent households. A submission to the National Economic Summit Conference in 1983 stated that women's earnings are a major factor in keeping families out of poverty.

Obviously the expectations of young women today are, by choice and necessity, vastly different from those held by their mothers and grandmothers at a similar age. The majority of women in Australia can now assume that they will be employed, or seek employment by choice or necessity, for a much greater proportion of their lives than women have before. Yet employment is the area in which discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy is most rife. The 1982 figures released by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations show that a women's choice of occupation is still very limited. Only 38.3 per cent of women have post-school qualifications compared with 42.4 per cent of men. This figure drops to 2 per cent in the area of trade qualifications compared with 22.2 per cent of men. Unemployment rates for women are consistently higher than for men, and women account for 78.4 per cent of part time workers and 87.6 per cent of discouraged job seekers. The ratio of female to male earnings of all adult full time workers stood at 0.8 per cent in 1981 and 0.78 per cent in 1982.

Theoretically, of course, equal pay principles have applied in Australia since 1975. Obviously however, the equalisation of award rates has not resulted in an equalisation of average wages. In a paper subtitled 'The Cost of being a Woman' F. L. Jones identified the problem still being faced by both men and women in the area of employment discrimination. He says:

Because economic inequality in the sense of simple discrimination has now been effectively eliminated, what remains must result from complex discrimination, amounting to all those social forces which produced sex segregation in the division of labour in the first place and have sustained it largely unchanged in the present century as well as those social forces which define women's participation as peripheral and secondary to their role as homemakers, childbearers, and supports for another's career.

The fact is, as Chapman points out in the survey 'Australian women and wages', men and women are not treated the same by employers. Chapman says that employers overstate the difficulties and costs of hiring and promoting women, and concludes that there is a need for governments to provide information and guidance and even legislation to counter inequalities in the labour market. I know that in the light of comments of this kind and more particularly because of their own experiences and observations, the Government's Green Paper on affirmative action will give rise to as much informed comment and be just as widely supported and welcomed as the Bill which is before the House today.

It has been very noticeable during the passage of the Sex Discrimination Bill so far that none of the opponents of the legislation have dared to question the basic principles of equality on which the Bill is based, but I cannot help feeling that many of the critical comments made during previous debates have a very hollow ring to them. One wonders just how deep a commitment to equality goes when every ludicrous, far-fetched and exaggerated example imaginable is dredged up to support an argument against legislation designed to eliminate discrimination.

The Government is determined that the Sex Discrimination Bill will become law because it is the most important way of showing that our promise to the people of Australia is being fulfilled. The Australian Labor Party has reason to be proud of its record in the area of women's affairs. Under both this Government and the previous Labor Administration, the status of women has become an issue of real significance and progressive thinking. Unlike some members of the Opposition, we are prepared to pay more than lip service to the principles of equality between men and women, we are willing to confront the issues, to research the areas where Government intervention is appropriate, and to undertake wide-ranging consultation about how unfairness and injustice can best be overcome.

Let me talk in more detail for a moment about exactly what it is that I and thousands of others who support the Bill hope will change once the Bill becomes law. Let me tell honourable members about some of the real life experiences that can happen to me, not because I am uneducated or criminally inclined or mentally deficient, because I am none of these, but simply because I am female. I can be denied finance by banks and lending authorities unless I produce a man who will take ultimate responsibility for my financial dealings. I can be the most experienced applicant for a job yet be passed over because higher positions traditionally go to men. I can be transferred out of a highly visible position if I become pregnant because of the supposition that pregnant women are unattractive and distracting. I can be ruled ineligible for a job because I am under six feet tall even when there is no reason for such a requirement to be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had that trouble, too.

—I am about to recognise that. It is vital to remember that men are also disadvantaged by discrimination related to their sex and marital status. Certainly the indirect discrimination over matters such as height affects men just as much as women. Even more common is the situation where a single man is passed over for promotion in favour of a married person simply because married people are supposed to be more reliable and stable. The Sex Discrimination Bill deals with all these forms of prejudice and can truly be said to be of major significance to both women and men.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the questions which have been raised by both the supporters and the opponents of the Sex Discrimination Bill is whether a matter which is as firmly entrenched into our economic, political and social thinking as sexism is in Australia can ever be resolved by Government intervention. Let us look first at exactly what we mean by sexism. According to Elizabeth Reid, one of the most influential and significant figures to emerge from the political realm of women' s affairs in Australia, sexism is:
. . . The artificial ascription of roles, behaviour and even personality to people on the basis of their sex alone. This does not simply create differences, but inequalities.
For a similar definition from a quite different source we can turn to the Commonwealth Schools Commission report entitled 'Girls, School and Society'. The commissioners say:

Sexism is a process through which females and males not only progressively learn that different things are required and expected of them because of their sex, but learn these things in an unexamined way.

Obviously sexism, like all other forms of prejudice, depends on deeply socialised attitudes towards oneself and the rest of the world. Even so, a responsible government which recognises the unfairness and individual hurt which results from sexual discrimination has a duty to act in such a way that the results of discrimination will not be rewarded. It is also important that the way should be made as clear as possible for attitudes to change as and when they surely will. As Joan Bielski of the Women's Electoral Lobby has argued, legislation is society's way of expressing disapproval of anti-social behaviour as well as providing women, who experience discrimination in isolation and are powerless to do anything about it, with a means of redress.

The Bill also makes provision for eliminating as far as possible discrimination involving sexual harassment in the work place. I know that to many men and some women sexual harassment is something of a joke. However, those of us who have been the victims of sexual harassment know that it is one of the most degrading, humiliating and frightening situations to be faced with. In some cases, the man in question obviously doesn't even realise that his actions are so grossly offensive and intimidating. Most of the time the man's attitude betrays a common assumption about women and women's place in society-women are inferior to men, second class citizens, objects to be used as playthings.

I have already referred to the number of letters I and most of my colleagues have received about the Sex Discrimination Bill and the Convention. The theme which seems to be common to all the complaints about this Government's attitude to women is that people will be forced to do certain things like go out to work or place their children in child care. As those honourable members who have studied the Bill and the associated literature will know, this assumption is absolutely false. The motives of certain members of the community who have perpetrated this myth are beneath contempt. The effect of the Bill will be to loosen the stranglehold of the stereotypes which are robbing people of both sexes of the chance to fulfil themselves as human beings. Let me quote Senator Missen's words:

This Bill does not take away rights of women. It gives greater rights to women. It means that those who want to go out into the work force, those who want to have education, those who want to join clubs, those who want to be active in different ways, can do so. It does not take away from anybody the rights which they already have.

The idea is that in a fair society no one is forced into any course of action because of inbuilt social prejudices. We do not want to force people to go out to work any more than we want to force them to become full time housekeepers or parents. At the moment, however, many people are being denied these choices not because of their natural inclinations or their inherent capabilities but because of the purely arbitrary stereotyped assumptions about how males and females, husbands and wives or pregnant women behave. The effect of the Bill will be to open up the areas of choice. Because choice is one of the fundamental prerequisites for any meaningful kind of freedom or liberation, the Bill will take a significant place in the annals of human rights legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — Over the years society changes in its emphasis and in its outlook. Parliaments which are of the people and for the people need to reflect those changes. History has taught us that whilst the goals of society are purported to be enshrined in the hearts and minds of its citizens people will be abused, used and discriminated against unless they have the protection of the law and the right to pursue that protection. Out of this real experience of human behaviour there grew the great common law of England. Over the centuries it has developed, and the judiciary's rulings, made and recorded, were added to by statute. The cord between the two was bound by the knowledge that no matter how we try to educate people as to what is right and what is wrong people will transgress these ideals and norms. In order to protect the weak from the strong and the strong from the weak there is a need for legislation and appeal to the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: People, when discussing matters relative to the role of women in society, tend- one can understand why-to become emotional sometimes due to beliefs based neither on fact nor on logic. The history books of civilisation's development are interspersed with pages of women's struggles-and a struggle it has been-to obtain recognition as equals. It is not long since women were given the right to vote. However, it seems to me that we men always insisted that they had the right to work, and work they did. The art galleries of the world contain great sculptures and paintings which depict women at work and even the heaviest of manual work. They were drawers of water and hewers of wood. Society seems to have accepted that they could do these jobs without pay in order to support the family. One suffers somewhat, therefore, when today's people say that it is wrong for a woman to wield a hammer or paint brush or drive a truck to earn some money in order to provide for family or self.

I have some difficulty-might I suggest even great difficulty-in understanding how it was right three or four decades ago for a farmer's wife to milk cows and drive the horse teams without pay in order to save paying wages to a man so that the money saved could be used to buy food and clothing for the family and it is now wrong for a woman, with the aid of labour saving devices at home, to enter the work force and take a job to obtain money to buy food and clothing for the family to assist her husband or, in many instances, to be the breadwinner. Surely there is no difference. It is disappointing that those who oppose for opposition's sake do not acknowledge the facts.
Women now comprise a significant percentage of the work force in Australia. There are 2,576,000 Australian women in the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too many.

—The honourable member for Franklin can make his own speech. I have strong views and I am entitled to express them. There are 1,475,900 women employed full time. Forty-four per cent of Australian women over 15 years are in the work force and 42 per cent of these are married. Several of the States in Australia have legislated to ensure that women are not discriminated against. They, quite rightly, have the protection of the law. South Australia pioneered this type of legislation in 1975. Incidently, because some opponents of the legislation drew attention to the fact that the United Kingdom has not ratified the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women-but it has signed it-it should be recorded that the United Kingdom legislated, as we are legislating today, this week and next week, in the same year as South Australia. The United Kingdom, like us in this national Parliament , was sensitive to the needs of the society in which we live. I submit that that is what government is about; that is what this Parliament is for.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a great deal of confusion about the Sex Discrimination Bill, its aims and its objectives. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and the Government need to recognise that they are largely to blame for this. The product of the Bill is the result of an original private member's Bill by Senator Susan Ryan which was, in its concept, lacking in detail and preciseness of expression without any deep appreciation of its effects on Australian society. In effect it was the product of one person's mind. The Bill we are debating today is the product of many hours of discussion and is an expression of a plurality of views with a common thread.

It is good that the Bill we are now debating has been drastically changed from its predecessor following detailed discussions and suggestions from all facets of Australian society. For those who may be confused, I want to say a few simple truths. It has absolutely nothing to do with homosexuality, nor does it seek to make all women enter the work force or put the Australian Government under the authority of the United Nations. Fortunately, we in Australia are bound by the decisions of this Government and not by the decisions of a foreign power. It appears to me that the people who did not know the true ambits of the Bill, who sought to deliberately misrepresent the position, are not cognisant of the discrimination shown against Australian women in many spheres. I will not tolerate that discrimination. For my part I state clearly and unequivocally that I support wholeheartedly this type of legislation. I have some reservations about certain clauses and I, like others, will be advancing these doubts at the appropriate stage in Committee.

As a former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment-I am most grateful for the kind personal remarks expressed towards me by my colleague the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), who on many occasions has been misreported and misunderstood-I had Cabinet approval to issue guidelines for legislation for Commonwealth employees in all States of Australia and, I ask honourable members to note, for all people in the Australian Capital Territory. Our legislation would have applied to both men and women beacause we poor unfortunate men are sometimes discriminated against also. The private member's Bill presented by my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) basically follows that legislation. I want to be quite specific: I was proud to be associated with the Fraser-Anthony coalition legislation. I had the carriage of it. I am proud to be associated with the private member's Bill of the honourable member for Gippsland. Equally, I am proud to be associated with this legislation.

It has been said by some critics that this legislation seeks to take over the power of the States using the external affairs power. My colleague the honourable member for Balaclava, Mr Macphee, laid these fears to rest. There is only very minimum reliance on this power. It needs to be pointed out, however, that governments in Australia make the laws but the High Court interprets them. It is all right for someone to disagree with a proposition but it is not legal nor fair, I submit that it may not be honourable, for people to continue to use arguments based on supposition and emotion when the High Court rules otherwise. The High Court is the supreme and lasting interpreter of the Constitution and the High Court has ruled that it is a legitimate operation of the Federal Government to introduce laws based on the external affairs power. It needs to be pointed out that the possession of power does not necessarily mean that the central government has to use it. I instance in passing that the Fraser-Anthony Government did not use that power in the Tasmanian dam situation.

I want to rebut some views held in the community that this legislation will tend to break down family life. I do not accept this argument. No force is used to pressure women to enter the work force. In fact, child care, which is almost necessary to allow women to enter the work force, is not even mentioned in this Bill. No extra benefits are provided in this Bill for women, married or otherwise, who enter the work force and no woman who chooses not to be in the work force is affected.

The existing law regarding maternity leave and equal pay is largely unchanged and no employer will be forced to employ women. An employer is only required to employ the best person for the job, and in many instances the best person is a woman. To those critics who have used this argument, which I believe is wrong in law and baseless in fact, I want to say that it behoves all of us to do what we can to allow all women the absolute right of choice as to whether they enter the work force or not. For those many splendid women who prefer to stay at home-and there are equally many splendid women who choose to work-we need to develop an income welfare system which allows people to have a lifestyle which suits their position, moral obligation and conscience.

I want to indicate that the original concerns of people in education and accommodation are no longer valid because of the changes made to the legislation . There will be no offence created by religious bodies which provide accommodation, nor where accommodation is provided by charitable or non profit making bodies, and where the employer lives on the premises and no more than three other persons reside with him on a commercial basis. Contrary to what many people originally thought-and unfortunately many still do-it is possible to have single sex schools and clubs. I can understand, as a parent whose children attend religious schools, the concern of principals and people associated with those schools as to the original intention of the legislation in these matters of teacher employment and pupil admission. This no longer applies as the Government has agreed to amend the legislation whereby people can be employed at the discretion of the school concerned. I would be happier if the scope were widened a little and enabled schools such as grammar schools, which are neither state nor religious schools, to have the same rights as the religious schools in the employment of teachers and in granting admittance to students. I will be raising this matter at the appropriate committee stage.

There were, too, many grave fears that the legislation would allow abortion basically on demand. In the Senate debates this matter has been clarified and I am satisfied, and this has been confirmed by discussions with many people, that the legislation does not apply at all to abortion and it is wrong for people opposed to the legislation to use this as an argument against it. The Bill is about discrimination and, as I understand it, abortions are able to be performed only on women, so how can this be discrimination against them on a sex basis, just as a prostate gland operation can only be performed on a man and this is not discrimination on a sex basis. However, I do support the remarks of Senator Brian Harradine concerning the law as it relates to chemists who may be proceeded against if they refuse to provide contraceptives to unmarried young persons of school age. In later stages of the debate I will be passing some comments on conscientious beliefs strongly held. One realises that it can be argued that a chemist need not stock these contraceptives, but there are some who believe it to be appropriate to do so, but who believe it is inappropriate to supply them to the above-mentioned people.

I am totally opposed to discrimination against any person. I believe that the most singular way of determining the culture and strength of a nation is to observe how its people are treated and whether the same law and rules apply to the richest and poorest, to the strongest and weakest, to the most able and the most handicapped. We need to overcome discrimination.
