Unfortunately there are many instances of discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy and this can happen through both direct and indirect methods. Indirect discrimination can occur when stereotype images influence the way a person is treated. For example, a woman who is not appointed to a position because women have high absentee rates is discriminated against if her own employment attendance record is satisfactory. Far too often we read where the best person does not get a job for no other reason than that she is a woman.

It needs to be pointed out too that discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status in the Bill is defined as having occurred if the aggrieved person is treated less favourably by reason of that person's sex or marital status or a characteristic appertaining to or generally imputed to persons of that sex or marital status, or if the aggrieved person is required to comply with a requirement or condition with which a substantially higher proportion of persons of the opposite sex or different marital status are able to comply which is not reasonable having regard to the circumstances of the case and with which the aggrieved person does not or is not able to comply.

There are now safeguards in the Bill which should satisfy persons who believe in the right of the individual and that all are free before the law. Even in matters such as superannuation, time is allowed to see what problems might develop. The Fraser-Anthony Government formed the National Women's Advisory Council, which is indicative of its belief that the woman's role in society needed to be discussed and given its right and proper place. The Government had excellent advice from that Council, which had two great leaders in the persons of Dame Beryl Beaurepaire and Mrs Quentin Bryce. Both these leaders were able to form government consideration policies based not only on the rights of women but also on rights formed after due consideration of concern for all people in society and the best way that women could help mould a truly great future society.
The bill can be no better described than by my using the words of the Hon. Bob Ellicott in signing the convention on behalf of the Australian Government some years ago and I quote from his statement:
It is a question of treating each woman as an individual with her own dignity and self respect of the power to make decisions about her own destiny.

I would like to add the words 'her destiny is one of equality with all and each of her fellow citizens'. This legitimate aim does not conflict with the laws of God. It is up to us to make sure that the laws of man do not conflict with these noble ideals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand in this House very proud to be speaking in support of this legislation, the Sex Discrimination Bill, but particularly proud to be speaking after the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh). That is one of the finest speeches I have heard him deliver in this House and I must congratulate him on the sentiments of that speech. I may not agree with every point, but it was a fine speech. If all the members of the Australian community, both men and women, had the same thoughts and sentiments as the honourable member for Darling Downs there would be no need for this legislation to be before us tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Darling Downs pointed out so much of the misunderstanding in our community that has surrounded this Bill. He blamed the Government to some degree for that misunderstanding. I disagree with that. There have been a few mischief makers in our community who have deliberately distorted the significance of this Bill and the role it will have of changing the Australian community.

This Bill has been accused of destroying the family, of forcing women into the work force and even of spreading homosexuality. To give one example of the distortions that have occurred, I will read to this House extracts from a letter that I received today from a constituent of mine asking me not to support this legislation because, the letter states, it would:
. . . allow homosexuality to gain a foothold in our schools and institutions because it:
(a) spreads AIDS
(b) stunts the maturity of young boys when they should be persevering in development as well-rounded, happy heterosexuals.

The letter goes on to state that it forces people 'to violence to their own and other bodies, e.g. King's Cross brutal and sadistic murder of taxi drivers'. That is the sort of nonsense that has been talked about this legislation. The aim of this Bill is not about any of those things. The aim is quite simply to remove discrimination against women in society. Can any honourable member of this House, even the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), say that discrimination does not exist? We have only to look around this chamber to see that it clearly does exist. If honourable members spend one day with a woman in their electorates they will know that there are clubs that they cannot enter and jobs that are not available for them.

This legislation is not to force women out of the home. It is not to force them to do anything that they do not want to do. It is to provide opportunities and offer greater opportunities to women to make choices. That is simply what this legislation is all about. Discrimination is entrenched in this society and it is experienced by both women and men. But it is most strongly experienced by women, especially in their public lives, such as in paid employment and when seeking credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you get into Parliament? It cannot be that bad.
—I got into Parliament, like every other woman in this Parliament, because I worked hard.
—You were treated as an equal.

—We are treated as equals now we are here but women generally in society are not treated equally. If they were, there would be more women in this Parliament. Fifty-one per cent of the Australian population are women and in this Parliament there are six women out of 125 members. They are all on the side of the Govenment. That speaks for itself and shows that there is discrimination in our society. Commonwealth and State experience has shown that most discrimination occurs in the employment area. Women make up 40 per cent of the total labour force but it is estimted that some 88 per cent of discouraged workers, that is, potential workers who do not constitute part of the total counted unemployed, are female. In addition, two-thirds of women who are employed are confined to four main industries-28.3 per cent in community services, 22.9 per cent in the wholesale and retail trades, 12.6 per cent in manufacturing and 11.5 per cent in finance, insurance, real estate and business services. Of all female full time employees, 38.3 per cent are in the clerical field. Even within occupations where women predominate, they are seldom found in any key decision making roles. Examples of this phenomenon exist everywhere. One area that I am particulary conscious of is in the Commonwealth Public Service. The Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration in 1975 was informed:

SPEECH.PARA: For decades the Public Service Act and Regulations explicitly discriminated against women. From 1915 to 1949 women were excluded from selection tests to the Third Division. Until 1966 the Public Service Act prohibited permanent employment of married women. These prohibitions were reinforced by differential rates of pay and conditions of employment.

We are still seeing the effects of that discrimination today. By 1981 the situation among senior staff in the Australian Public Service was that 96.93 per cent were men and 3.07 per cent were women. That refers to the Second Division of the senior executive service. That is what we are talking about. We are still living with that discrimination. Can we as a society afford to let that situation continue? Can we waste so much of our talent?

The situation today is little different. Some senior women have been appointed. There is one in the chamber tonight. But with a Second Division in which only 2. 3 per cent of permanent officers are women, it is not surprising that we have so few women at the top of the Public Service. Predominantly women have been in the Third and Fourth Divisions doing clerical work.

One can follow the careers of women through the Public Service. For example, we took one class of graduates from 1975. We examined them after three years in the Public Service. From that intake, three male officers had progressed to Class 11 level and to the Second Division three years after entry while no woman from the same graduate intake had progressed to that level in the same three year period. It is true that that is old information but that situation continues to exist today. Women do not progress in public service and industry in spite of identical qualifications with male counterparts. The reason is that people on selection committees tend to select clones of themselves. That is why women of Australia at all levels of employment need role models-women on selection committees.

This legislation is set up to ensure that women are treated equally with their male counterparts. The problem is not specific to the Public Service. Women in industry have the same problem; those who select for promotion select people just like themselves. Men, and some women too, just cannot visualise women in positions of authority. Women have been expected to manage the private sphere, perform amazing feats with tiny budgets and large overheads and meet extraordinary demands by those they manage, while men tend to the public sphere. But when it comes to promoting women as managers in the realm of business, women are told that they do not qualify because they are not management material. Of course, women are not told this directly; it is much more subtle.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is garbage.
—The figures speak for themselves. How can it be garbage?
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will have his opportunity to speak later in the debate. I call the honourable member for Canberra.

—The discrimination in this area is very subtle. Women are simply not noticed when it comes to selecting a new generation of businessmen's own kind. What a waste of talent that is for Australia. How many honourable members have encountered a male typist or a woman bank manager? How many of the representatives of industry and the trade unions who attended the National Economic Summit Conference were women? The recent review by the Business Review Weekly of 500 top executive salaries included only one woman.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the area of wages, in 1972 the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission set a new principle of equal pay for work of equal value. This meant that award rates for all work was to be considered without regard to the sex of the employee. The new principle was to be phased in by 1975, meaning that equal pay principles have applied in Australia since 1975.

What is the reality today? Equalisation of award wages has not meant equalisation of average wages. In 1972 the ratio of female rates of pay to male rates was 0.65:1, in 1976, 0.76:1, in 1979, 0.79:1 and in 1982, 0.78:1. This information clearly reinforces the contention that women in Australia still earn considerably less than men. Subtle forces of discrimination operate in society. Values in society determine a stereotyped role for women, that is, that women's participation in the work force is peripheral and secondary to their role as homemakers and childbearers. That is not to denigrate their roles as homemakers and childbearers. It is simply to point out that it is those forces in society which seek to keep women in non-paid service roles. The legislation before us tonight will provide the legal possibility for those women who want to participate in the work force on a more equal basis to do so. I emphasise again that this Bill will not force women into the work force. It will not erode the concept of the family. It will work to remove discrimination against those women who want to enter the work force and it will ensure equality of opportunity for men and women by the elimination of unjust discrimination.

The Bill also makes unlawful discrimination in the provision of goods and services, including services relating to banking, insurance, the provision of loans, credit and finance. Complaints of discrimination in the provision of goods and services represent the second largest area of complaints, although they fall a long way behind complaints in the area of employment. Getting a loan depends on one's predictable ability to repay the money, but in spite of evidence to the contrary, there are still money lenders who believe women will be distracted from their debts by motherhood or some other exclusively female peculiarity. Let us take the case of a young, married working couple. The woman was told by a bank loans officer that he hoped she was not going to have a family for five years because the couple could only just afford the loan based on their two incomes. The couple went elsewhere. In another case, a couple were asked to sign a statutory declaration to the same effect.

The New South Wales Anti-Discrimination Board documented the case of a couple with a joint bank account who separated. They took out separate accounts, both overdrew. The man overdrew his account by $1,500 and the woman overdrew her account by $300. His cheques were honoured, hers were bounced. Some retail stores are known to be key offenders. A divorcee in a country town sought a $50 budget account with a clothing store but was told that she needed a married male over the age of 21 to act as guarantor. She was perplexed as to why a male young enough to be her son would be considered more responsible than herself. While financial institutions state that they do not discriminate against women, there are stories which illustrate that they do. One such example is that of an unemployed young man receiving a Bankcard while the pensioner mother on whom the boy was dependent was unable to get a Bankcard. That the pensioner mother had satisfactorily managed the family's finances for many years was simply not taken into account.

Credit scoring systems are based on the past performance of applicants and on the past performance of the credit provider. Credit providers who have systematically excluded women in the past have enshrined a principle of no credit for women unless they can get a man to go guarantor. It is for this reason that we urgently need legislation to redress this inbuilt inequality in the realm of credit. As a final example of discrimination against women in financial institutions, I relate the case of a couple who had a policy of putting her name first on official forms. With only one exception the bank would always write to the husband. When challenged, bank officials said it was not their policy to deal with a wife without the husband's agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —And vice versa very often.

—Not very often. The cases are well documented. I found the same thing happening to me. If discrimination is to be prohibited in the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities, especially by trading, banking and financial corporations , it is appropriate that the heads of Commonwealth constitutional powers be relied upon. In addition, certain provisions of the Bill will give effect to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particulary pleased that this Bill will apply to the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory, and those States without legislation of their own. It gives me particular pleasure that we in Canberra will now have our own anti-discrimination legislation. We have waited some time for that. As the honourable member for Darling Downs said, he attempted to initiate some legislation in this area that would affect Canberra. I appreciate the work he put into that. Once this legislation is through, we will have anti- discrimination legislation of our own. I hope that it will have some impact, particularly on the Commonwealth Public Service. No legislation can eliminate all forms of sex discrimination, just as the equal pay provision could never assume that women would have equity in wages. The Bill is a beginning on the long road towards the provision of equality of opportunity for women and men in Australia. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —One approach to the Sex Discrimination Bill, an approach held by many reasonable people such as the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), who has just spoken, is that it will simply advance the cause of equality of women, especially at work, but also in such areas as education, accommodation, club membership and the like. Further, according to this approach, the Bill allows for the usual sensible exemptions, including charities, religious and voluntary bodies, military service in combat areas and genuine occupational qualifications. Finally, according to this approach, the Bill does not require affirmative action, that is, the use of unfair and discriminatory techniques of promoting equality. The Bill therefore is legislation in the spirit and tradition of John Stuart Mill's The Subjection of Women.

SPEECH.PARA: The other position is that while the Bill may seem moderate in some of its terms, it should be seen in the context of the wider movement against individual rights and against the traditional family, which for most people is still their great citadel of freedom and independence in the face of the ever expanding state. They certainly see in the Bill a further erosion of freedom of contract and of choice, and at least a step towards affirmative action. These critics generally see the Schedule to the Bill, the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, as giving us the hidden agenda of the Bill. They see the Convention as reactionary.

I support the objects of the Bill. Indeed, I gave a notice of motion in November last year of a private member's Bill to achieve these objects in a different way. Because I support these stated objects I find myself in sympathy with some of the critics of this Bill. I believe that it approaches the problem in the wrong way. In matters of human relations such as this, there are two kinds of legislation. One, the wrong kind I believe, is to establish defined offences with sanctions and penalties for the offender. That is what this Bill does. The other is to avoid legal definitions and penalties and to seek progress by conciliation, negotiation and education. That is the approach taken in my private member's Bill which, strange to say, the Government has not brought on for debate.

An example of what I consider to be the right approach is that taken in New South Wales. The New South Wales Privacy Committee Act established a privacy committee to examine threats to privacy in New South Wales, to make recommendations, and to solve disputes by negotiation. The legislation was derived from a report by Professor W. L. Morison, who advised against establishing a tort, or offence, of invasion of privacy with associated penalties, and urged the establishment of a conciliatory committee without sanctions.

I served on this Committee in the mid-1970s and this experience has had a lasting influence on me in the consideration of matters of this kind. The Privacy Committee was extremely effective in a range of matters from consumer credit, criminal records, medical records, personal data systems, unsolicited mail, unsolicited phone calls and so on. It operated under guidelines but without defined offences and penalties, and it operated well.

When there was a change of State government in 1976, the new Labor Government, which in opposition had argued for the legalistic approach and put much emphasis on the need to introduce penalties for offences against privacy, asked the Privacy Committee what teeth it wanted. The Privacy Committee said that it did not want any; that it was working well without them. This is one model. It is the model I had in mind when I gave my notice of motion.

Another model-in the Commonwealth area and one relating to sex discrimination- is the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation. This was set up after the former Government ratified an International Labour Organisation convention. This Committee reported to the previous Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. There were and are committees in each State and Territory as well as a national committee. These committees include representatives of government, employers and employees. No doubt the committees vary in standard from time to time and place to place, but all agree that they have had an excellent record of success in removing discrimination in employment. They operate by guidelines without rigid definitions and legal penalties and without a legislative basis. The only sanction that they have is to report to the Minister. They are charged with the responsibility to reduce discrimination on the grounds of sex, race, colour, political opinion, national extraction and social origin. In recent years they have extended the definition of 'sex discrimination' to include discrimination in superannuation schemes and discrimination by sexual harassment , without, need I say, the damaging legal techniques we have seen in New South Wales under its legalistic sex discrimination legislation.

The point is that this new legislation is simply unnecessary. We have in place, and operating well at the Commonwealth level, a national committee, with State committees, which are achieving the object of removing discrimination and doing it by conciliation, without a cumbersome apparatus of legal definitions, court hearings, sanctions and penalties. All that is needed is to give the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation a statutory basis and to extend its jurisdiction to the areas outside employment which are covered by this Bill. I refer to clubs, accommodation, education, the provision of services and so on. That is the simple approach, based on the existing operations of a Commonwealth committee. That the Government did not adopt this approach despite urgings from the National Committee on Discrimination is my basic objection to this Bill.

Let us look at the Bill, which far from emphasising conciliation, in the extraordinary words of one member of the Human Rights Commission, will be ' vigorously implemented'. There is no reliance on the slow but effective methods of persuasion here. It will be vigorously implemented, and woe betide the poor man or woman who has other views or conscientious objections.

The Bill, after scores of amendments to the first sloppy and authoritarian draft, has been improved. We must all agree with that. Some exemption is provided for church schools which, in their hiring or firing, will not now be committing an offence if they act in accordance with their religious faith. In hearings before the Human Rights Commission the defendant, as he or she may as well be called, will be allowed legal representation if the Human Rights Commission uses counsel. Formerly the defendant had to face, without assistance, a panel of vigorous enforcers aided by counsel. Now when a matter reaches the Federal Court the defendant will not have the onus of proving his innocence, and the finding of the vigorous enforcers will no longer be prima facie evidence of the truth of the finding.

But let us note that these reluctantly made amendments do not go far enough. The Bill is still a legalistic, punitive and authoritarian measure, in my view. It is still the case that legal representation is permitted only if the Human Rights Commission has legal assistance. So the defendant can be heard without representation by a group of people who are not judges upholding established law but who are committed to the vigorous implementation of a change of community attitudes, and who are not bound by the laws of evidence. Is that what our idea of a fair hearing has come to? As Professor Lauchlan Chipman has pointed out, this is like a person charged with driving under the influence being judged by a group of militant abstainers.

Further, although reverse discrimination is not mandatory in the Bill, it is permitted by clause 33. It is also to be noted that although there are four pages of definitions in the Bill and everything from 'accommodation' at one end to 'woman' at the other is defined, there is no definition of that equality which clause 3 (d) says is one of the objects of the Bill. This clearly leaves it open to the Human Rights Commission or the Sex Discrimination Commissioner to take 'equality' to mean not equality of opportunity but numerical equality; that is, there is inequality and discrimination until 50 per cent of all occupations are staffed by women and 50 per cent by men. That is one very obvious interpretation of equality and it is one which would make reverse discrimination quite mandatory. To be fair, clause 33 refers to 'equal opportunities', not numerical equality. But it is a defect still that no definition of equality is given in clause 4, especially in view of the well-known preference of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) for reverse discrimination and numerical equality.

In voting for the Bill I have to make almost an act of faith that the conciliatory and not the punitive themes in the Bill will predominate when it become law, but it is only sensible to be cautious about a Bill based on this kind of approach. Fundamentally, we still have a Bill which is based on definitions of offences and ultimate sanctions. Of course there is talk of conciliation, and I hope that prevails, but still where is the spirit of conciliation when it is conducted by vigorous enforcers well aware of the power to refer a matter to the Federal Court? This is an area in which there are nuances and qualifications and special cases which should be covered by guidelines, flexibility, conciliation and education, not by legalistic rules and by courts.

I now turn to the Schedule to the Bill, which is the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, to which the Bill gives partial expression, and which clearly indicates the way we are to read the Bill. It is the ideal of which the Bill is an imperfect expression, but at least it is a step towards full expression. We must assume it is included in the Bill because it helps in some way to understand the Government's intentions in introducing the Bill, otherwise why would it be there? We have to assume that because the Bill could stand by itself and be equally effective without the Schedule. Of course, consequently, without clause 3, which states that the object of the Act is to give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations Convention, and without other sections referring to the Convention the Bill could then stand on its own. In any case Australia has signed the Convention, so what light does it cast on our understanding the Government's intentions with this Bill?

The Schedule has many worthy articles which few would object to, ranging from the right of women to vote to the right to retain nationality. These and others like them are the articles which encourage some people with whom I have discussed the Schedule, especially members of the Liberal Party, to see it as advancing enlightenment in a world where women in some countries are still oppressed by such customs as suttee, or the traditional self-immolation of a widow, and female circumcision. It is noteworthy, and a point in favour of those supporting the Convention, that the countries supporting such practices-or most of them in Asia and Africa have not even signed, let alone ratified the Convention. They obviously see the Convention as directed at these infamous practices. It may turn out that the Convention through the influence of some of its better articles will advance the cause of enlightenment.

However, one must have serious reservations about several of the Articles. The one about which I have most reservation is Article 5 (a), I have reservations about others associated with it, such as 11 (2) (c) and 10 (c). Article 5 (a) calls for:

. . . Appropriate measures . . . to modify the social and cultural patterns of men and women with a view to achieving the elimination of prejudices and customary and all other practices which are based . . . on stereotyped roles of men and women.

Taken with 10 (c), which calls for the revision of text-books, school programs and teaching methods, and 11 (2) (c), which calls for 'a network of child-care centres', Article 5 (a) can only be taken to be aimed at one 'stereotype'-to use that word-which I believe is at the basis of a free society; that is, the sterotype of the man as bread-winner and the woman as home-maker, in other words , the traditional family. The traditional family must be a so-called 'stereotype ', in the terms of the Convention and the Convention is against all stereotypes and therefore is against the traditional family. I can find no other meaning for those Articles and therefore I am against them.

The traditional family is, in the words of the British writer Ferdinand Mount, the permanently subversive institution-using the word 'subversive' in a good sense-that always resists the reach of the state and government, and even of the churches. It is the nursery of individuality, the spirit of independence and social values. It is the only institution capable of generating upward mobility and is crucial to overcoming poverty. It will continue to resist the drive of governments to flush women out of untaxed work at home and into the public work force so that the state can tax them to advance the power of the state. Anything that weakens this wonderful subversive institution, as I believe the United Nations Convention tries to do, should be opposed. There may indeed be, as we are always being told, other forms of the family emerging in our time-the so- called single parent family and so on-but none can be a real substitute for the traditional family.

Having said that, I of course recognise the problems involved-for example, those of the talented house-bound mother of the traditional family who wants to earn an income of her own and develop her talents other than for mothering and running a home. I am thinking of a constituent of mine who wrote that she was sick of listening to the debate between liberated women who wanted to be PhDs and what she called hard-line full time mothers. She wrote that there ought to be a place for ordinary women who do not want to be PhDs and who want to stay at home with the children but also want to earn some income and develop other interests. She asked why the Government and the political parties did not give more attention to the possibilities of earning income in the home, in the so- called electronic or computerised cottage. There is of course a good deal of controversy in America about these possible developments and a Bill before the United States Congress, the Family Opportunity Act, would use tax measures to encourage families that want to purchase home computers for the purpose of establishing a business, using them in the home. I think that it is an interesting piece of legislation and an interesting development. Be that as it may, in pointing to the crucial role of the traditional family in a free and independent society, I am not wanting to reject anyone's freedom of choice. I am simply stating that we weaken the traditional family at our peril.

There are other articles of the Schedule or Convention which cause concern. Article 10 (b) gives the Commonwealth, under the Convention, control of the textbooks, school programs and teaching methods in government and non-government schools. One would have thought that people would have been more cautious about international treaties after the High Court's decision in the Gordon-below- Franklin Dam case which, relying on an international treaty, has destroyed self- government in Tasmania. Indeed, Tasmania is now Van Diemen's Land again but this time under a Colonial Office which is in Canberra, not London. The new Convention that is now under debate could have comparable consequences. One has only to consult the proclaimed ideas of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) to see that she would welcome this further weapon for use in the control of government and non-government schools. We have already seen in Tasmania the sort of conduct that ratifying this Convention has encouraged-the school in north-east Tasmania where they burnt hundreds of books, such as Snow White and Born Free, because they were regarded as sexist.

I also distrust Article 4-the special measures article-which is the call for affirmative action to accelerate de facto equality by appointing people to positions not on the basis of merit but on the basis that they are women. One might applaud the stated objective of helping women but the means chosen could cause injustice and widespread bitterness and be counter-productive. It is not mandatory in the Bill yet-it is only permitted-but it is in the Convention and one therefore assumes that it is only a matter of time before we get appropriate legislation.

I also find Article 17 objectionable in practice. This sets up a committee of 23 to monitor Australia's conformity with the Convention. Of course, Australia has nothing to fear from international monitoring but, as it happens, the monitoring committee is chaired by someone from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and is made up of representatives from such model liberal and enlightened democracies as Cuba, Bulgaria, East Germany, and so on, whose idea of eliminating discrimination is to treat women as well as men abominably. To have Australia submit its social arrangements to such a monitoring committee seems to me offensive and a retrograde step.

I repeat, there is much in the Schedule or Convention which is unobjectionable and which may even do some good, but there is also much to cause concern. What these sections do is raise further doubts about the moderate or reasonable interpretation of the Government's intentions with this Bill.

In summary, the Bill's stated objects should be supported, but the measure is an ill-advised way of achieving them. One could have a Bill based on conciliation, such as I proposed in my notice of motion, or one modelled on the New South Wales privacy committee legislation, or one which gives a statutory basis to the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation and broadens its jurisdiction. Instead, we have a cumbersome, legalistic measure which may well be counter-productive, one based on the idea of offences and enforcements in an area of human relations that is unsuitable for that treatment . I cannot welcome, without these basic qualifications, a Bill with this kind of approach. I will vote for it but I can only look forward to a future Liberal Government's removing its objectionable features.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important debate. I would like to begin by making a comment about the people who have spoken in it. I think it appropriate that on this side we have heard from the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer), the honourable member for Canning (Ms Fatin) and the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). That is very important because it says something about what is happening in Australian society and what is happening in the Australian Labor Party. Obviously our Party does not have a monopoly of good ideas. The Opposition, including you, Mr Deputy Speaker, has made major contributions. I was particularly impressed by the remarks of the honourable member for Balaclava, Mr Ian Macphee, and the honourable member for Darling Downs, Mr Tom McVeigh. The general spirit of the debate has been most worthy.

SPEECH.PARA: One or two points need to be picked up at the outset. The last speaker, the honourable member for Wentworth, (Mr Coleman), spoke about the traditional family. We need to clarify that the traditional family was only one of the outgrowths of economic life in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries; that the more narrowly defined role that women have played has been determined by factory and industrial life. If we look at the more extended family and the circumstances that preceded industrialisation, it is true to say that women played a rather broad role in economic life. The more narrowly defined economic life that many women have experienced in the last 200 years has been an outgrowth of industrialisation. It is important to emphasise that because when one speaks in a rather nostalgic sense about the traditional family one can refer back to the really traditional role of women as substantial economic providers during earlier times. It is important to understand that because in the community there is somehow a perception that what preceded was always better . I am not so sure about that. If we look at the role of women we see the more narrowly defined role of recent times and the fact that certainly a long time ago they enjoyed a much more extended role. That is not to say that there should be only one role but it is important to clarify that the traditional family of which the honourable member has been speaking has been of only recent growth and has been related to industrialisation. We know about that development.

In a sense it is important to cut through the whole debate and say that what we are talking about is establishing as a Federal Government a set of benchmark propositions concerning the role of women. It is not a case of saying that there are not other areas of jurisdiction that operate. We recognise that there are but as a Federal Government we have a responsibility to establish a framework, a structure, within which people can operate most effectively and fully. It is in that light that the Sex Discrimination Bill represents an important part of our overall approach to the management of the economy and of the society. It is also of course a Bill about rights, and a Bill that is about rights is also one about duties. I will say more about that shortly. I wanted to clarify those matters, but the general spirit of the debate is such that the listening community must feel very pleased about it. People on both sides of the chamber are trying to make a positive contribution on this significant issue, which is dealt with in a Bill that was introduced in the Senate in June of last year. On 20 October last Senator Gareth Evans modified the Bill. Some 53 amendments were incorporated. I need to make a point about that. That was significant. A substantial process of consultation with and involvement of the community had occurred. The amendments incorporated are not those of a government that is wishy-washy about its intentions but of one that has been willing to put forward a series of propositions about a social process and react to the community in an intelligent and responsible way. That was the genesis of the Bill.

There are other matters to which I want to refer shortly. However, when we do have legislation of this nature that is important-it is benchmark legislation and it tends to establish a series of important propositions that we as a government and, hopefully, we as a community would want to pursue-it is very important to follow a process in which we are involving people and in which we are listening to people. So the sort of process we are going through now in respect of 53 amendments that have been brought in is not one in respect of which we on this side would want to claim that the system is all cast in concrete and that truth has been laid down at some form of internal wisdom. It is not like that at all.

I want to talk about three aspects of the Bill. I would like to talk about the process of education institutions and their involvement. I would like also to talk about the role of women in the work place. Finally, I would like to talk about the issue of social change and what this Bill means in terms of social change. I suppose the fundamental principle we are addressing ourselves to in this debate is in fact the elimination of discrimination based on sex, marital status and pregnancy and discrimination involving sexual harassment, and I will say more about that shortly. We are saying as a government that that kind of sexual harassment in the work place cannot be tolerated in an intelligent and sensible community. That is why we would want to identify it as part of our process of legislation and our process of saying to members of the community that this is one of the ways we believe they should conduct themselves. So this matter is very much about establishing a series of propositions which are important.

Let me turn now to educational institutions. This is probably the area that has provoked the most controversial responses. It was felt by many in the community that in fact this Bill would invade the rights of non-government schools in particular, and somehow try to transform them as part of a total process of enforced social change. In fact, that is not the case. Clause 38 (1) of the Bill provides an exemption for institutions in relation to discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy for the hiring or dismissal of staff , for employment at an educational institution conducted in accordance-and this is the important part-with the doctrines, tenets, beliefs or teachings of a religion or creed where the discrimination is done in good faith in order to avoid injury to the religious susceptibilities of adherents of that religion or creed. Clause 38 (3) provides a similar exemption in relation to discrimination on the grounds of marital status or pregnancy for educational institutions with regard to their educational practices. These clauses were amongst the most controversial of this Bill. Originally the intention had been for the Human Rights Commission to look at this exemption area for two years. I have indicated what we have now done. In fact those educational institutions will be exempted from this Bill with respect to that area.

Might I say that the kinds of comments that I have just made and the sort of position we have come to are the result of consultation with the community. In my own electorate of Stirling I had very satisfactory consultation with educational institutions. I found that there was a very sensible level of debate in two schools in particular; namely, Servite College and Newman College. I was very impressed with the intelligent contribution and questioning from parents and staff at those institutions. As a result we were able to deal with what really were their fears. In circumstances in which people sense that something is going to be imposed in some way from outside it is legitimate for those people to feel concerned. I felt particularly that the contributions of Father Nestor and Mr Michael Beech of the Catholic Education Commission and Brother Valerian of Newman College and Mr Grenville Murray of Servite College were very intelligent. I would like to thank them for what they did because they provided the capacity to proceed in an educational debate in an intelligent and reasonable way. That is the position we have reached tonight. We are proceeding on the basis of consultation and involvement and not saying that this is a system which is cast in concrete.

Might I say, before leaving the area of educational institutions, that it is very important to say that these institutions are foundational in establishing what I would call the issue of consciousness of women about their role. Not only are educational institutions important in terms of their practices; they are also important in terms of their curriculum. One of the important contributions that educational institutions make is the intelligent development of both young men and women in their educational life. It is important, if we are to proceed in a sensible way in this legislation, that we begin by dealing with the administrators of those institutions in the way that we would like those administrators to deal with their pupils, and that is openly, intelligently and without compulsion. So I believe the process we are talking about in this debate of involvement and discussion with administrators is one that proceeds down to the level of the children in the institutions. I would hope that the sorts of issues we are dealing with here are dealt with openly and fairly in the curriculum. I want to make that point because I believe that one of the major issues we have to confront in this society is that both young women and young men must look to developing their potentials to the fullest. It is very unfortunate that in recent times young women have not seen that as their right, that in fact they define their life more narrowly. That is unfortunate. It will add something more about that in a moment.

I turn to the question of the work place. I suppose that when one is talking about a Bill of this kind ultimately one comes down to talking about the work place. In fact, people's economic lives tend to be foundational in the way that so much of the rest of their lives is conducted. However, I should begin by saying that it would be quite wrong to cast this Bill in the role of being a piece of legislation designed to get women to go out of the home into work. That is not intended. However, it is about ensuring that if women choose to do that they would have equal opportunities to men to pursue those involvements in the work place. That is what this legislation is all about. It is not saying that we have a sterotype ideal of what the woman should be. I must say that in the debate in the wider community some people have presented it as that. But this Bill is about saying that we believe women, if they choose to go into the work place, should have rights and those rights should be the same rights as those held by men. They should be able to pursue those rights and those rights also bring with them duties. That is really what the legislation is about. It is about establishing those rights. We believe that, as a national government, we have a responsibility to do that.

Let us look at another issue that arose today. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) released in this place some figures concerning apprenticeship. It is rather damaging to talk about apprenticeship generally because in fact the figures show a very low level of involvement of young women in the apprenticeship area. In fact, outside the hairdressing trades only 2 per cent of apprentices are female. Again, that is because there has been a very narrow definition of their role and their work life.

Let me talk for a moment about what might be called one of the modern diseases resulting from that narrow definition. That modern disease is repetitive strain injury. Tenosynovitis is another term by which it is known. We have received some figures from Ministers showing what has happened between 1978 and 1983. The figures indicate that there has been a substantial growth in repetitive strain injury or tenosynovitis. What is very revealing in terms of this discussion and in terms of the debate we are having in the wider community is that this disease affects women four times more than it does men. Why is that? It is because women are more narrowly confined to certain occupational categories. There is something wrong if that is the case. But that is the case-look at the figures. To give some approximate totals between 1978 and 1983, 1,695 women and 477 men in the Federal Public Service had compensation claims for this new industrial disease of tenosynovitis. I use the word 'new' because it is in a sense an old disease which has affected people in the clothing industry and the food processing industry for quite some time. But right at the moment it is one that is certainly affecting keyboard operators in the Federal Public Service. Of course, it does not require too much imagination to recognise that most of the keyboard operators are women. So this strikes right at the heart of what we are talking about in this debate and that is a sense in which opportunities can be seen in a broader way by women. That is foundational in this debate.

I would like to say something else about the work place. Prior to coming to this place I performed the role of a consultant in business as well as working in an academic environment. One of the things about working in a business environment was that I had the opportunity to visit many different work places and certainly factories. I spent a lot of time in one large corporation. One of the most dramatic experiences was that by and large, despite the good intentions of management, industrial life was very boring, dangerous, dirty, repetitive, monotonous, tedious and uncertain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about politics?

—Yes, it is almost like politics. However, when one came down to it, if one looked at the very serious situation one found that on all counts of work being boring, repetitive, tedious and dangerous women were always in more danger in terms of their work place in a more repetitive, boring and tedious environment in all of those semi-skilled and unskilled areas.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is not just about women in senior positions. It is about women in lowly positions. The sad thing about this research is that it showed that women in those very lowly positions had very low esteem. They did not really believe that they deserved to do anything more than be part of the industrial cannon fodder. What a sad circumstance that is. They were very angry because at the same time they felt that they were trapped in that circumstance. They were indeed, because economic necessity kept them trapped in that circumstance.

The other interesting aspect which I think is important for us and the wider community to recognise is that they also tended to be less unionised and less concerned about their rights. In almost every work place there was substantial evidence of sexual harassment that was never taken up with management and never taken up in the context of unions. At first thought one may not have understood why they were not more unionised. The reality was that they tended to look upon their job as being only temporary. By temporary, I mean it tended to last for about 10 years whereas their male counterparts looked upon their jobs as being long term jobs. Therefore, one of the first things they did was to get organised in the work place and demand their rights. So the capacity for that sort of harassment and intimidation was not there. For his female counterpart for whom the income was just as necessary, the capacity for harassment and the capacity for oppression was there. We could see the very sad part of it when we looked at who got to work overtime, what they had to do to work overtime and the sort of indulgences that foremen might have engaged in. The tragic part about it was that there were women who were willing to be exploited out of economic necessity and that was completely ignored in the whole work place.

This Bill deals with that circumstance. This Bill says that, if that were to occur, we as an intelligent 1980 society cannot tolerate it. It is as fundamental as that. I believe that honourable members sitting opposite equally share our concern with respect to that issue. It is a substantial issue. It is not something one can brush away. When we are talking about the work place we talk about something very substantial.

In terms of looking at social change which I think is foundational, in terms of the whole process that we are engaged in here-I would like to make some concluding remarks about that-this legislation is not about stereotypes. This legislation is about choices. I believe that honourable members opposite who, from time to time, are very concerned about choices should recognise that what we are saying as a government is that we are about establishing choices for women as well as men in the way they might choose to lead their lives. This legislation is not saying that there is only one way that a woman should lead her life. It recognises that women should lead lives as complex as men in this society. It says that if women choose to be at home they have a right to be at home. That is a very productive activity and one that the latest research shows is worth probably about $16,000 a year. If they choose to enter the work place they have rights in the work place; if they choose to have other sorts of careers that are interspersed between the work place and home that is their right. It is not about setting a stereotype; it is about creating rights. It is also about creating duties and those duties are very important. The sad part for women is that they have tended always to be burdened with duties and have had very few of the rights. This Bill establishes some of those rights. I believe that honourable members opposite recognise that.

In conclusion, I think that when we look at the whole passage of this legislation and we look at the debate which is going on-this debate does not confine itself to this chamber; it includes the wider community-what we ought to be saying to the people outside is: Let us proceed in an intelligent way. I heard the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) refer to those other societies which are somewhat in the dark ages by comparison with our society. Certainly in our society this debate is equally about having the discussion and having the sense in which the fresh air of debate proceeds. We all have a collective responsibility in this place to make sure that the debate proceeds in an intelligent and sensible way. I am confident, from the contributions that I have heard from honourable members opposite and from honourable members on this side of the chamber, that that debate can proceed.

What we need to do in this legislation, in this place and in this community is to say, at a certain point of time, that we, as intelligent people, recognise that we have to ensure that half of our society has the rights that the other half has enjoyed for a long time. It is not misinformation; it is not about compulsion. It is about creating choices and making people recognise that they have a right to those choices. An intelligent society such as ours should establish that in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a new member of this Parliament I have been, in my innocence, amazed. I have been amazed, principally, at the arrogance of the Parliament and amazed at the immodest assessment that we, as parliamentarians, have of our role as a Federal Parliament. It seems that we see that every obstacle and every difficulty that exists in Australian society exists for us and us alone to rub out. It seems that we think we have a great palliative that we can use by legislative action to relieve all pain. The Sex Discrimination Bill, which we are considering tonight, has been hailed by honourable members on both sides of the House as a healing and constructive step in relieving discrimination in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: In reality I am concerned because I see it as an unnecessary interference in human affairs. The dilemma that exists from my point of view as a member of this chamber is that while no one, least of all myself, has denied that discrimination exists and while all of us have said that we abhor discrimination in any form and while I am prepared to support justice for all regardless of colour, race, creed or sex, if I choose to oppose this legislation I will be labelled, not only in this House, but also outside it as a discriminator. The injustice of it is that this is black and white legislation. Opposition to it means simply that I am labelled as a discriminator and sexist and running with it means that what I am doing will be approved. There has been no room for middle ground or consensus in this debate. Indeed, when I spoke to the Women's Electoral Lobby about what my attitude to this legislation ought to be they said : 'Mr Andrew, there will be two columns. You will be in one or the other'. I said: 'But I am opposed to discrimination'. They said: 'We are sorry, there is no grey ground.'

I reiterate that there should be equal pay for equal work, equal opportunity in education and for promotion and free choice in employment. I reiterate that I am opposed to discrimination and that blatant acts of discrimination appal me. But I must say that I cannot support this Bill in its present form.

Principally I cannot support the Bill because it is unnecessary. The advantages that this legislation purports to give to the Commonwealth of Australia already exist in South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria. If citizens in Western Australia, Queensland, Tasmania or even the Northern Territory for that matter, wish to have this sort of legislation, they will elect the State governments that will give it to them. It is as simple as that. How can I stand in this House and support further erosion of States rights. The profile--

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you are elected as a Federal member of parliament, not a State member of parliament. What do you think you were elected for?

—I was elected because I have a task as a Federal member of Parliament . The whole problem that we face in this Parliament is that we had the audacity, in the last session, to agree that this Parliament ought to be larger and so further deprive individual States of the rights they have as State parliaments. We have given a greater profile to the Federal parliament than is healthy in the Federal system. When we ought to be returning responsibility for legislative action to the States, including the responsibility in this sphere, we are choosing instead to take it unto ourselves. The honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) and the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) have pointed out the dependence that this legislation has on external conventions for its head of power.

SPEECH.PARA: I have further difficulty with that because that means that, in order for the Commonwealth to exercise its power, it must take these external conventions into every State, into every family and, if honourable members wish, into every bedroom. The far more satisfactory result would be for the States to introduce legislation that is modelled on the South Australian legislation. I say that proudly as a South Australian. That is not the statement of one who would give responsibility for this action where it belongs, with the State parliaments.

The honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) said that in this House we have an illustration of just what is wrong with discrimination in Australia, because all of the female members are located on one side. She then went on to give an illustration that included the phrase 'them and us'-probably the most discriminatory statement one can make. I suggest to honourable members opposite that before they come into this House preening themselves about the number of female members they have, they should look at the Australian Council of Trade Unions and see what sort of representation it has on its governing bodies.

To date in this House we have had a purely statistical view of equality-the sort of dilemma we face when we consider one vote one value legislation. Nobody disagrees with it, but the reality is that the electors in my electorate are discriminated against much more in terms of voting legislation than are those in an inner suburban electorate. Their access to me, or to any country member, is much more difficult than would be their access to a member who can walk around his electorate before breakfast. That is another case of statistical equality being confused with real equality. True equality has nothing to do with legislation but a great deal to do with the regard we have for each other regardless of sex. True equality is not a matter of having equal regard for each other-all I have heard in this debate to date-it is about being prepared to concede that everyone other than myself is of a higher status than I am. True equality has a great deal to do with having a higher regard for other people rather than an equal regard.

It is totally unfair to suggest that women raise families and men raise incomes , but it is just as unfair to measure one's contribution to the community in purely employment terms. Having half the work force made up of women is no guide to the contribution women, or anyone else, make to society. It is a purely statistical analysis of equality and has nothing to do with reality. The problem with Senator Ryan's foreshadowed affirmative action is that it refers to statistical equality and has nothing to say about real contribution. It is a futile attempt to correct by numbers discrimination which is fostered by attitudes. No thinking person can tolerate withholding employment, all things being equal, from a woman who is just as well qualified as a man; no thinking person can tolerate denying girls access to the same educational opportunities as boys; and no thinking person can tolerate blatant discrimination on the grounds of sex, marriage or pregnancy. This Bill does not give equality. It is likely that employers will be reluctant to advertise permanent jobs lest they be obliged to employ women. This will not aid equality.

The Bill serves only to muddy the waters. It does nothing to relieve real inequalities. It is true, as was said earlier, that inequalities will persist in some families no matter what we do. There will still be single income families for whom the non-taxable wage level will be $4,000, while in two-income families the non-taxable wage level will be $8,000. This Bill does nothing to relieve that situation. The Bill supposes that we can legislate against discrimination, but does it make it possible for me, as a male chauvinist Liberal, to get a job with Senator Ryan? Does it address the individual indefensible inequality we perpetuate by ensuring that prostitutes are prosecuted while customers escape? Does it address the problem we all face as members of parliament? If I might digress, my wife was never as discriminated against as she was the day I became a member of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about my husband?

—That is absolutely right, and this Bill does nothing to relieve that situation. Why not? Because now the responsibility for raising the family is no longer shared, as once it was able to be. The geographic reality of being here makes it more difficult for our spouses to be as free as once they were. A further simple dilemma we face when looking at this Bill is that women are the only members of the human race capable of bearing children. Pregnancy happens to be a state exclusive to women, and much of this legislation is designed to ensure that the pregnant state does not disadvantage women. It is implied in what has been said by honourable members opposite that pregnancy is a burden. As a male, I would not challenge that statement.
—You don't want to get pregnant, either.

—No, precisely. The honourable member for Chisholm said she did not want to hear, to use her words, 'the simplistic dichotomy that suggested that mothering was right and a career was wrong'. She will not hear that from me because it is not what I believe. However, I do want to reinforce what was said by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman). The role of raising a family is a unique role in society. The parenting role will not be relieved for either males or females by the establishment of the child-minding centres that have been espoused by those opposite. The simple truth is that every child has a fundamental right to be parented, preferably by both parents and definitely by one or the other.

SPEECH.PARA: In leading for the Opposition in this debate the honourable member for Balaclava acknowledged that the barriers that existed and much of what had promoted discrimination in the past had largely broken down. I am pleased that in 15 years we have seen a tremendous change in the attitude of society to women and in the attitudes of men and women to each other. I want to say not that legislation is wrong but that it is unnecessary. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) said that the legislation is not about getting more women out of the home. I remind the honourable member that the Bill is seen as encouraging women out of the home. The opportunity the honourable member for Stirling referred to was the opportunity for women to play a broader role in society. I have no problem with that, but it must not be at the expense of the essential role of parenting that we all have.

I say again that I stand here as a member opposed to discrimination. I am equally opposed to the insinuation that the work force is more productive than the family. I am opposing this Bill simply because it is unnecessary. I am opposing it because South Australians, New South Welshmen and Victorians already have this protection and all other States can avail themselves of it by electing State governments that give it to them. I am opposing the Bill because, quite frankly, it takes from States what is a reasonable States' right and hands it to the Commonwealth. I suggest to the House that time has done a great deal to relieve the discrimination that once existed. Time has meant that through the process of evolution discrimination is being perpetually reduced. Some States already have this legislation, and I suspect we would be much wiser if we left it to the other States to implement it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, the world is full of people who will not face facts, people who, like my friend the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), bang their heads against brick walls. In 1955, before people were able to get far enough away from the earth to take photos of it, some people preached that the earth was flat. Their spiritual descendants are today preaching that a woman's place is in the home. The obvious inference from that is that a man's place is out of the home, except, I suppose, before and after hours of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: The only conclusion that can be reached about these people, the people who want women to stay in the home, is that they, like the flat earth proponents, have failed to see that release of people from stereotyped roles is part of a human response to their conditions. I suppose one could say that it is evolutionary. They have failed to see that a complex web of inextricably woven events has led to the need for women and men to review their roles. True, it is happening to some extent without legislation. Until I became a member of this House most of the previous 13 years had been spent job sharing with my spouse. Two men acquaintances of mine have decided to stay at home full time-they have done so for a few years-while their spouses have taken a job. This sort of thing is happening to some extent. But at the same time, with other changes occurring in the community, for some women and men pressures are creating areas of discrimination which are far more a problem than they once were.

The opponents of the Sex Discrimination Bill cannot see that it is part of what is already happening. Nor can they see the need for a Bill to release people from discrimination which has been occurring for a long time. Sexual harassment, discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy and jobs which are unreasonably reserved for one sex, such as air pilot, search and rescue worker or builder's labourer, are examples. In the 1950s a woman gained a job in Australia's great Snowy Mountains scheme as an engineer. She had graduated in another country. She rightly says that she would never have got the job if Australia had not been so desperately short of people at that time. She spoke about the difficulties which she had at that time. Men too are often the victims of discrimination. Some men would like to stay at home. This strange mob called Women Who Want to be Women, which really means 'women who want other women to be full time housewives', is trying to stop men from staying at home. I observed many years ago that women live longer, on average, than men. What the four Ws want to do is deny men the right to choose to stay at home and live longer.

In the long struggle which Roslyn Snow and I have had-she was a candidate for parliament a good six years before I thought of nominating-we had a turn each at being home all the time and then an agreement to job share. We have been lucky enough, in having a common profession, to do what other couples are not lucky enough to do. Single parents and most two-parent families cannot do that. For women, the poorest section of the community, the range of choice of jobs is not nearly as large as that for men. This Bill goes a long way to rectifying that.

Many of the letters which have come to me have dwelt on biblical precepts. These letters are, theologically, absolute rubbish. I hestitated about saying this, but so many people have contacted me about what they say is God's law; they quote Paul-or St Paul, for the conformists-ad lib, but they neglect his remarks that some of what he said were his words, not God's. They talk of woman as a helper, omitting the fact that the term was used in the same words as God is helper, if anything, showing superiority. Above all this, they use Christianity to back their beliefs, forgetting that this faith, like many others , puts love and justice well and truly ahead of the law.

The church has not been able to stop the march of women to power in its own institutions. May I say that that is a rather refreshing event. The church has not been able to stop some of the things that honourable members who have opposed this legislation have been talking about, that is, the breakdown of the rather short lived nuclear family-short-lived compared with the extended family. Yet these people are asking the Government to do what the church has not been able to do. This is more human enhancement Bill than a sex discrimination Bill. Neither women nor men should have to continue in roles just because they were developed in the Victorian era. The Bill is necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the Sex Discrimination Bill. I do so because I believe it is an ineffective attempt to impose upon society values, standards and principles which are not acceptable to the community at large. It is precisely because those standards, values and principles are not acceptable that the Government has been forced to water down the legislation and include in it a range of qualifications, exemptions and exceptions which render it a valueless and meaningless exercise in tokenism. All that will be achieved is more red tape to bamboozle and confuse the community; more rules and regulations, more tribunals and, as a result, less freedom. Opponents of the Bill have been attacked and ridiculed for their opposition. They have been called bigots and fools. Yet already the Government has acknowledged the merits of many of the objections by supporting amendments to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The feelings against this Bill are very widespread. Thousands upon thousands of ordinary, decent, good living Australians have voiced their deep concern. Despite the many amendments, people are still worried that the Bill undermines fundamental community standards, especially family life. There is a grave danger in ignoring the common sense of ordinary people and preferring the advice of articulate pressure groups. The legislation is wrong in principle and its form is totally confusing.

I wish to make some fundamental points. The responsibility of a democratic parliament is to respond to the wishes, desires and aspirations of the people it represents. The general body of Australian electors is not clamouring for this legislation. It was born out of the international feminist movement and seeks to satisfy its fancies. I say with confidence that those women have very little, if anything, in common with the vast majority of the women in my electorate to whom I owe a duty as their elected representative.

The legislation seeks to eliminate some forms of discrimination. It is interesting to consider for a moment the word 'discrimination'. According to the Oxford Dictionary it means inter alia 'to distinguish between' or 'give due weight to differences'. Should we not give due recognition to differences which exist? The philosophy from which this Bill springs does not recognise any innate differences between male and female. New feminism displays a frustration because it believes women have not achieved the success and the power allegedly enjoyed by men.

Dr Anne Summers, the senior Government adviser on women's affairs, in her book entitled Damned Whores and God's Police speaks of the oppression of Australian women and the need for their liberation. She speaks with feeling and understanding, of the 'setting up of all-women communes or embryonic rural communities which are intended to provide a haven where women can live and do as they like unhampered by the interference of men'. Dr Summers displays in her book an elitist radicalism and an attitude to men which surely must be now dissipating since she has achieved a position of power. Like other radical feminists, but unlike most women, Dr Summers fails to see that the sexes are not in competition but, according to the rules of nature, complement each other. She fails to recognise that in their complementary role men sometimes suffer, and why not? Is life not about giving as much as about taking?

A total of 94,471 Australian men and 127 women have died in action defending this country. The life expectancy of men in Australia is now 71.2 years. The life expectancy of females is 78.1 years. The important but tough jobs in our mines are worked by men, as well as the dirty jobs at the sewerage works and in garbage collection. Is this discrimination against men? No, it is merely the complementary role they play in society. But the radical feminists want women to share equally in those jobs.

The shadow Minister concerned with women's affairs referred in his speech to the policy statement of the coalition parties produced in 1974 in a booklet entitled 'The Way Ahead'. It is interesting to see that in that policy statement the term 'arbitrary discrimination' was used. The word 'arbitrary' is very relevant. It is inevitable that people will discriminate. It is wrong for anyone to decide in an arbitrary fashion, without any other reason, that he will not employ someone because of that person's sex or colour. That is sexism or racism in its purest form. But surely, beyond that point one should be free to choose. A black man or a white may have quite different abilities, as may a man or a woman. It is inverted racism or sexism to force a choice upon people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who does that?

—Do not get excited; listen to this. These are fundamental points and I hope the honourable member will read my speech tomorrow. This point was succinctly expressed by Dame Leonie Kramer, Professor of Australian Literature at the Sydney University and, of course, the former Chairman of the then Australian Broadcasting Commission.
—Before she was sacked.
—That is right, before she was sacked by this Government. A magazine called Mulberry Leaves interviewed her and I quote the question:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I wonder if we could hear your views on affirmative action. There is a lot of talk today about positive discrimination in favor of women, yet, you seem to have been very successful without the need for such a structure change. For women to succeed do you think that affirmative action policies are necessary?
Dame Leonie Kramer answered:

Not only do I think they are unnecessary, I think they can be positively harmful. And that has been clearly indicated in the U.S. where they have had some really bad experiences as the result of affirmative action policies.

You should never appoint anyone to any position, except on merit. To say that somebody ought to have a job because he or she is male, female, black or whatever seems to me to be really no different from saying that they shouldn't have a job because they're a Jew or a Catholic or whatever.
She continued:

The other aspect of this is in a way more personal. If I were now starting on an academic career, I would be absolutely appalled if I thought that I were appointed to a position, not because I deserved to have it, but because I was a woman.
I repeat what she said:

. . . not because I deserved to have it but because I was a woman. And I would hope I had the courage and the ability to turn it down, until somebody appointed me for the right reason and not for the wrong one.
I now turn to some particular aspects of the Bill. Clause 3 (a) states that one of its objects is:
to give effect to certain provisions of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women;

There are a couple of points I want to make about that Convention. Firstly, we should be very wary about signing and ratifying these conventions. In the past there has not been an opportunity for the community to have a debate about conventions of this kind. I think it is important in the future that we have machinery whereby the community at large can have a debate on important conventions such as this one before they are signed. It should not simply be an act of the Executive.

The other point-I do not know whether honourable members in the corner opposite will understand this-is that the Convention has a sexist title. This Bill is to give effect to certain provisions on the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. What could be more sexist than the title of that Convention? Is there not discrimination against men? Why should that not be mentioned as well? I will not go into the details of the Convention but I do want to refer to a couple of the Articles in it. The Convention is attached as a Schedule to the Bill. Article 10 of the Convention states:
States Parties shall take all appropriate measures . . .
I will leave out some words-
to ensure, on basis of equality of men and women: . . .

(c) The elimination of any stereotyped concept of the roles of men and women at all levels and in forms of education by encouraging coeducation and other types of education which will help to achieve this aim . . .

It will help to eliminate the stereotype concept of men and women, in particular , by the revision of text books and school programs and the adaption of teaching methods. Over the page, Article 11 provides:
States Parties shall take all appropriate measures. . .
I will go down to paragraph 2 (c) which states:

To encourage the provision of the necessary supporting social services to enable parents to combine family obligations with work responsibilities and participation in public life, in particular through promoting the establishment and development of a network of child-care facilities;

So the Convention is suggesting that we should have throughout Australia a network of child care facilities.
