The problem with that Convention is that it does not try to achieve equality between men and women; it tries to achieve sameness between men and women. It plays down the traditional role of women at home and plainly seeks to encourage elimination of the differences between men and women.

The Bill is full of the most incredible inconsistencies. It states that one cannot discriminate against a person of a particular sex by refusing employment on account of that person's sex, yet later we are told of numerous situations where one can do just that. It states that one cannot discriminate against a person of a particular sex by not admitting him or her to a school on account of sex yet the Bill approves all-male schools and all-female schools. It states that one cannot discriminate against a person in employment on the basis of strength and stamina of their sex, but one can do so in sport. It states that a person cannot be refused admission to membership of a club on account of sex, but it is all right to have all-male and all-female clubs.

I want to mention one point that was raised in the Senate which I think has a great deal of merit, and that is the possibility of including in the Bill a conscientious objection clause. Senator Harradine, in the Senate, raised the question of the conscientious belief of a pharmacist who may wish not to sell contraceptives to a single person. I prefer the example of the person who does not wish to rent a house to a de facto couple. If I had a house to rent that would not particularly worry me. But there are people in the community, I have no doubt, who do hold very strong religious beliefs and, as a matter of conscience, may not wish to rent a house to a de facto couple. As I understand the Bill, it requires a person to decide between what his conscience tells him and what the law tells him. I think this is placing very unfair pressure upon individuals in the community.

The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) said on a number of occasions that there is discrimination. It has also been mentioned by the honourable member for Canning (Ms Fatin) in the House this evening. If honourable members look at the membership of this chamber they will see few female members, and this is evidence of discrimination. There were very few females at the National Economic Summit Conference, and that is evidence of discrimination. But those examples in themselves are not evidence of discrimination because one relevant factor is that many women in the community, as a matter of choice, exercise their own free wills and decide that they do not want to enter business or the profession of politics. They prefer to remain at home.

This is where we get down to the nitty-gritty of it all. What Government supporters are not doing is giving enough encouragement and support to the woman who wants to remain at home and who chooses to remain at home and look after her family and children. All sorts of things are being done to encourage a woman to leave home. If we look at the Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women, we see that almost every provision attempts to encourage women to leave home and go into the work force. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, can shake his head all he wants. He is a decent chap. If he looks at the legislation and at that Convention he will see what I am talking about.

I do not mind which government I blame. I am not making a political point. I will blame the previous Government or this Government. It is high time that we did more to give proper support to the woman who chooses to remain at home to look after her family. We should do something about it and stop carrying on with all this nonsense. This Bill means nothing at all. Let us take the case of an ordinary employee and look at what we do for that employee in the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about you?

—The honourable member can make those smart remarks. I am trying to make a serious point. For such employees we provide long service leave, annual holiday pay, workers compensation, boots to work in, safety gear of all sorts, warm clothing, good coats and things like that. Let us think about this seriously. What do we do for the woman who wants to remain at home and take on the fundamentally important responsibility of nurturing young children and bringing them up? Maybe she does not want to send her children off to a child centre. Maybe she would prefer to have the children in her own home and to remain home. Good points have been made every now and again but 90 per cent of the points that Government supporters have made ask: 'Why should we not give women every opportunity to get out and leave the home?' The Convention speaks of women entering public life. How many women want to enter public life? I think that is an elitist comment and an elitist clause. It is about time we gave proper recognition to those people.

SPEECH.PARA: Arbitrary discrimination certainly does exist. I emphasise the word 'arbitrary' . We must encourage the community to eliminate that discrimination. We all have a sense of fairness. We must admit there is discrimination in the community. But do Government supporters think that the answer is to bring down this kind of draconian legislation? They say: 'This bit of paper with all these provisions in it is the great answer. It is all in black and white. Let us use the whip on people and get stuck into them and apply the penalties that are provided in this Bill. It is the answer'. The fact is that it is never the answer. One cannot legislate to impose community values unless the community at large will support that. This is where it comes back to basic politics.

What does the community want? I am just a humble back bench member from the electorate of Braddon in north-west Tasmania and I am very proud to be the member. Perhaps other members represent different kinds of areas and their views should be expressed in this chamber, together with the views of the people that they represent. But I assure honourable members that the people whom I represent , men and women, decent people in the main-there are some exceptions-do not support this legislation. People in the electorate of Braddon are not rushing around and saying: 'We are concerned about sex discrimination'. They are more concerned about the bread and butter issues. They are more concerned about their jobs. We have not had a debate on unemployment since this Government came to office. I have given notice of a motion-it is about time the motion came on for debate-about jobs for young people. Here we are wasting time on this great load of nonsense. This legislation is the greatest load of nonsense of all time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell the women of Australia that.

—I will tell the women. I will be proud to tell the women that this is the greatest waste of time. We are not doing our job if we spend hours debating this kind of nonsense. It will do nothing for society and nothing for the community. It is about time we worked on the issues of real concern to the community.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an act to follow! The closing statement of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) was about what the Government should be doing about the economy and whether we should be talking about it. If he read the daily newspapers he would know what the economy has been doing. It has not looked back since we were elected. He has not even asked a question on it at Question Time.
—We can't get one up.

—I ask the honourable member: Whose fault is that? In supporting the Sex Discrimination Bill, I am mindful that this is a significant step towards social equality by a government that cares about people. It is appropriate that I, as the member for Tangney, should be supporting this Bill because the seat was named after Dame Dorothy Tangney, the first woman to be elected to the Senate. She was a great woman of Australian politics and of the Australian Labor Party. Currently there are 13 women senators and six women members in the House of Representatives. In the latter case, they are all members of the Labor Party. On this side of the House we are all convinced that the effectiveness of Parliament will be enhanced as their numbers grow. Whenever we have legislation before the Parliament that deals with social issues, the fundamental differences between the conservative parties and the Labor Party are highlighted. The conservatives are generally happy to maintain the status quo even though there are inequalities such as those that this Bill addresses. The Labor Party has acted to correct discrimination, where it exists, in its first year of government.

SPEECH.PARA: In my contribution tonight I wish to talk about the positive aspects of the Bill, using two examples where shortcomings are present, and to comment briefly on the hysterical campaign aimed at aborting the Bill. All of us here are the product of a society with discrimination between the sexes deeply entrenched. From the pink and blue baby rugs to manual arts and home economics, society has tended to predetermine the future direction of a person's life based on that person's sex. The deeply entrenched attitudes that gave rise to that situation will not be changed overnight, but a start has to be made somewhere and it is pleasing to see the Hawke Government taking the lead.

Let us look at the objectives of the legislation. They are: To give effect to certain provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women; to eliminate, so far as is possible discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status and pregnancy in certain areas; to eliminate, so far as is possible, discrimination involving sexual harassment in the work place and in educational institutions; to promote recognition and acceptance of the principle of the equality of men and women. I put it to the House that they are very noble objectives indeed. What we are talking about is the equality of opportunity, above all else-the right of a person to equal access to education, to jobs for which he or she is qualified, to promotional opportunities within those jobs and to access to loans for housing, to name a few. These are fundamental rights and a person's sex should not be a contributing factor.

As I indicated before, change will be gradual but it is important not only to consider the personal disadvantage that women are suffering because they are women. I put it to the House that the economy of Australia is suffering as a result of not fully utilising half of the human talent of this nation. To illustrate this, I point out that those economies that are doing very much better than ours rely predominantly on products with a high intellectual input. Of all the arguments and propaganda generated by this Bill, I have not read anywhere that a woman's brain is inferior to a man's.

To illustrate the economic benefits to this country of developing the intellectual level of 100 per cent of the people rather than 50 per cent, I present some statistics given to me by my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). Countries such as Sweden, Switzerland, Norway, the Netherlands, Denmark and France derive about 60 per cent of their export earnings from products that are intellectual in nature. Examples are inventions, patents, research and development, product adaptation and copyright. By comparison, Australia earns less than 5 per cent from this source.

A graphic illustration is that of the Netherlands, which is second in the world only to the United States of America in agricultural earnings, excluding forestry and fishing, Australia, with its millions of tonnes of exports of agricultural products, cannot earn as much as the tiny Netherlands in agricultural exports because the Netherlands exports such things as vaccines, sera, seeds, bulbs and horticultural products. All of these require intellectual input and, as I have said before, women possess half of this talent.

I turn now to an area where lack of empathy has resulted in an illness known as premenstrual syndrome being largely ignored as an area of medical research. The only reason I know of its existence is because my attention was drawn to it by a constituent. The reason for this neglect is simple. It is an illness that is confined to women and though its symptoms differ widely its frequency is linked to the menstrual cycle. The reason for the lack of knowledge is that most medical research is done by men. These two illustrations are important in themselves, but it is important to remember that the needs of the individual are the most important thrust of the Bill.

Earlier today the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Drummond) said that we could not legislate to change community attitudes. That was reflected just a minute ago in the remarks made by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom). He said effectively that we could not legislate to change community attitudes to current sexual discrimination. I just say on that point that legislation has been used to end slavery, to allow women to vote and to give the Aboriginal people of Australia equal rights. In each case there was strong community opposition at the time. Today not even those opposite would challenge any one of these principles. In each case legislation recognised a right that was being ignored and was an important step in correcting community attitudes. Today we are going down a similar path.

I turn now to the hysterical campaign to stop this Bill going through the Parliament by a group called Women who Want to be Women. Every member in this House received copious amounts of roneoed material from that organisation. One did not have to look far to see how conservative this group was when it started to use the old fear tactics of communist influence. I refer to its claims of control of children by the state as one example. That shows the group's lack of credibility or imagination. To rely on tactics used in the 1950s to attempt to discredit legislation in the 1980s not only reflects the advanced age of those behind the campaign, but also indicates their tunnel vision in the views they hold on women related social issues. The group also claimed that international courts, under selected hostile figures-they were very selective about their selection; it included Colonel Gaddafi and a few others-would have jurisdiction over Australians. This was an outright lie and events will show this to be so. The kindest thing one can say about this campaign was that it was propaganda. By that I mean that it appealed to emotion and not to reason. Conservative parties always rely on these tactics and we have come to a stage of political history in this country where they cannot decipher the truth. When the division on this Bill comes, we will see a large number of National Party and Liberal Party members opposing it. In reality, they will have been influenced by the propaganda of the Women who Want to be Women. I put it to the House that some of the comments we have heard tonight reflect many of the things that group said.

The passage of this Bill through the Senate has taken into account many of the community's concerns. These have been expressed by the Opposition, the Democrats and the Independent senator. Not only has this process had an input into the final form of the Bill; it has also led to consultation with many groups which have a concern and which will be influenced by the legislation. The Government will issue a Green Paper on affirmative action with a view to generating public discussion and an understanding of the concept. Many speakers tonight have given statistics showing the inequalities that exist. It is my hope that over time this legislation will be an important contribution towards the remedying of that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to imagine any piece of legislation before this House more likely to call into question so many fundamental tenets of our parliamentary democracy as the Sex Discrimination Bill . There are problems of jurisdiction in this legislation and the balance of rights between employers and individuals. There are drafting problems with the Bill and its effectiveness can be questioned. How effective can a piece of legislation of this type drawn in this form be? I have listened in the chamber or in my room to every speech made on the Bill this evening. A great many questions were raised of a moral and even a philosophical nature. Honourable members opposite have made criticisms of a great many good and decent religious people who hold very firm and sincere beliefs about this legislation. I do not believe it serves this Parliament well to denigrate associations or individuals who believe just as strongly as they do in matters concerning this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As with all honourable members, the literature I have received amounts to a fair bundle. It is interesting that most of it expresses the frustrations and disappointments of women who remain at home and raise children. It seems that they are extremely disappointed and frustrated with the treatment that they get from government. Instead of abusing these women, this Government ought be to directing more attention to their problems and circumstances, particularly by changes to the taxation laws. Of course, women who choose to remain at home are no less intelligent, have no less dignity and work no less hard than women who choose to work in a professional field or in the work place. The Government ought to address itself to the problems of those women.

This legislation seems to be mostly about the balancing of rights-the right of an individual compared with those of an employer or with those of an educational authority or a club. It disturbs me to some extent that this Parliament has gone so far down the path that it is, in a sense, playing a superior-being role in that it is choosing what is more right than something else. By that I mean that the legislation before us deems an individual right to be supreme in almost all circumstances, with some exceptions, over that of an employer. That concerns me to a large extent. I am not at all convinced that that ought to be the case.

Perhaps it would assist the chamber if I stated clearly and unambiguously my position in regard to this legislation. I acknowledge and have often encountered , particularly in practising law before entering the House, discrimination in a number of different fields, particularly accommodation and the provision of services. The matter of loans, which has already been referred to, is of particular concern. But I will not under any circumstances vote for the Bill at its third reading.

I acknowledge that discrimination exists, but I do not believe that this legislation will rectify or assist the position of those discriminated against. Instead, I believe that the cure put before the Parliament is worse than the cause. It is worse than the cause for a number of reasons. First and foremost is the matter of jurisdiction. The legislation to some extent incorporates and relies on the foreign affairs power of the Constitution as decided by the High Court recently in the Tasmanian dams case. It does that by way of incorporation of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women which has already been referred to.

I do not accept that under our Federal system the Commonwealth has the right to impose legislation of a domestic nature by way of the foreign affairs power. To put it in the vernacular, I will not buy that at any price. To accept that proposition is to weaken if not set in motion the destruction of the Federal system and of States rights. My political philosophy sees the dissolution of power as the best means of providing checks and balances and of protecting and even strengthening our democracy.

Another matter which concerns me about the legislation introduced by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) is the matter of common law rights. A whole range of common law problems in this legislation will be addressed in the Committee stage. They refer to the rules of evidence, the admissibility of certain types of evidence, the matter of legal representation, the matter of admissibility of evidence obtained from proceedings other than those before the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, the matters of self- incrimination, onus of proof, and damages. On careful study of the legislation one finds that to an unexpected degree it infringes our common law right, the right of every citizen to be heard, to be represented and to be acquitted without loss or damage if it is so decided.

As most honourable members would know, in October I introduced two sex discrimination Bills as a private member. One related to Commonwealth employees, the other to the Australian Capital Territory. I did that to demonstrate two points, the first being that as a private member I acknowledge that discrimination exists but that jurisdictional problems outweigh the wrong we would be trying to right. It is very interesting to note that speakers on the Government side have had this legislation handed to them on a golden platter. I suggest that if they had embarked on the exercise of drafting legislation they would come quickly to the realisation, as I did, that one is playing God in some way. One has all the time to balance, to choose between the rights of individuals. It concerns me that this Parliament is embarking on such an exercise. I realise, of course, that the Parliament often passes laws on a whole range of philosophical or moral topics which affect the behaviour of society. That is our inescapable duty, but there is a limit to it.

There are many aspects of this legislation which concern me. I am particularly concerned that the Bill refers to and incorporates the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. I reject the basis of that Convention as well as its practical aspects. The legislation I introduced into the Parliament seeks to eliminate discrimination so far as that is possible without trying to impose an ideology. The ideology of the United Nations Convention is one which I reject but which the Government has embraced with open arms. The legislation I introduced would protect to a far greater extent than does the Minister's legislation the rights of non-government schools , small businesses, and all religious orders and organisations. Furthermore, it clearly sets out an individual's rights and obligations and avoids ambiguities and unworkable complexities. Do members of the Government pretend that the document before us is not ambiguous in many aspects? Do they pretend that ambiguous law is not bad law? Quite simply, ambiguous law is dangerous law. For that reason I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee) and I urge all members of the House to support it. The amendment states in part:
(1) the Bill should not rely on the external affairs power as a head of power;
(2) Australia's signature to the United Nations Convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women should not be used to extend the powers of the Commonwealth;

Looking more closely at the Minister's legislation, it pretends to eliminate discrimination on the grounds of sex, marital status or pregnancy in the areas of employment, education, accommodation, clubs and organisations. Regrettably, looking at the finer details, I regard many of the provisions as being not only complex, ambiguous and ultimately unworkable but also as being heavy handed and disregarding the traditional rights accepted by most members of our community. I certainly do not pretend that an employer can willy-nilly discriminate against women on the grounds of sex or marital status, but numerous circumstances have been referred to in another place, particularly by Senator Harradine, where the rights of the individual could be abused or where allowing an individual's right to supersede that of the employer would be wrong. That also applies to the area of education and especially to the area of accommodation. A great many moral questions are involved in this piece of legislation, particularly in regard to marital status. I suggest to members of the Government that many Australians would insist strongly on the right of the provider or seller of accommodation to make moral judgments about those who wish to rent or purchase accommodation from him. I certainly do not wish, nor does any honourable member on this side of the House, to embark on a moral crusade. That is certainly not the role of the Parliament. Nonetheless, I suggest that a person providing accommodation has an inalienable right to provide it on the terms and conditions he chooses. For that reason, discrimination against persons on the grounds of marital status causes me particular concern.

Another area which causes me real concern is that of discrimination on the grounds of pregnancy. It must be obvious that at an advanced stage of pregnancy a woman is physically unable to comply with the requirements of some jobs. In the two Bills I presented to the House, which interestingly enough were never debated by the Government, there was no provision for discrimination on the ground of pregnancy. I consider that to be quite unenforceable, quite unworkable . The complexity and ambiguity of the Minister's legislation is of real concern to all honourable members. That is evidenced by the fact that some 70 amendments have been introduced since the first draft, and I believe that another 70 amendments could easily be made.

One of the things that have disappointed me about this evening's debate has been the abuse heaped on those, whether in this chamber or outside, who wish to express strongly held views. Very fine people have been ridiculed and termed arch conservatives and narrow minded bigots. That is simply not the case. It is time that this Government recognised that at least half the population of Australia-soon there will be more-take a view different from its views on a whole range of issues. It is sheer arrogance, like the Mick Young method of using numbers, for the Government to disregard the strongly felt views of honourable members on this side of the chamber and of the people whom we represent, who believe in traditional values, not in legislation which is unworkable, which is dangerous in its content and which is quite unenforceable.

I have, further, been disappointed not just by the abuse heaped by many speakers, not all, from the Government side of those who take a different view, but also the number of pious platitudes that so many of them heap on women. I am sick and tired, as are a great many women who have approached me on the matter, of women being treated like little paper puppets, being put up on show for the Australian Labor Party. They are sick and tired of being patted on the head and being told that they are good little representatives, good little women; that they have attained preselection and can sit in this House. I consider those pious platitudes the most extreme form of sexism and discrimination. It is quite phoney for many members of the Opposition to pretend that they are enlightened. It is disturbing that women should be treated by so many of the men of the Labor Party in such a patronising, toying sort of way.

The final matter to which I wish to address myself is the fact that I concede that discrimination exists in our society. I concede that much of the criticism of the Bill has been uninformed and misleading. Statements that the Bill will interfere with religious practices, will dictate the size of families or will force people into the work force are patently wrong. No one on this side of the House has suggested that those criticisms are valid. What I am saying is that the legislation will not move us towards remedying the wrongs.

I referred in my opening remarks to the many problems that a piece of legislation such as this creates. First and foremost must be the question whether or not the Bill will be effective in changing community attitudes. Suffice to say that the Victorian Parliament seven years ago introduced sex discrimination legislation. I have questioned in private a number of members of the Victorian Government as well as other members of the Victorian Parliament concerning whether the legislation has been successful. I have yet to find a member of the Government who will say that it has been remotely successful in eliminating discrimination. There are other forms, other tools, available to the Government, to the Parliament especially, to eliminate discrimination. They include moral example and leadership. For that reason I oppose this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The aim of the Sex Discrimination Bill is to ensure equality of opportunity for women and men through the elimination of unjust discrimination. The Bill interferes in no way at all with religious or family values and will not encourage or force women or men into roles that they do not wish to undertake. I hope that the arguments for this legislation are both understood and well accepted by most Australians. Throughout our country women and men experience discrimination on the basis of their sex and marital status.

SPEECH.PARA: Having made those few brief introductory remarks, I believe it important to respond to comments by certain members of the Opposition that I have heard while sitting here during the debate. I have enjoyed the fairly forthright manner in which this debate had been conducted but I find certain of the assumptions on which contributions have been made by members of the Opposition to be somewhat lacking and in some ways quite offensive. In particular I would like to comment on certain points made by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), who referred to the traditional family and suggested that the legislation would in some way weaken its role. Of course he was talking strictly of the family in which there is a male breadwinner, a dependent spouse and children. I would point out to him that the traditional family as he defines it now accounts for well under 25 per cent of all family households in Australia. I would add that I and I am sure my parliamentary colleagues on this side of the House have considerably more faith and confidence in the family structure, be it the traditional family or any other type, to know that it will remain a strong and basic unit within our society. There is certainly nothing in this legislation that is about to destroy or break up any type of family in our society.

The honourable member for Wentworth also made the point that perhaps this legislation would push women into jobs that either they did not want or were unable to perform. I wish to make a few points concerning the type of concept that the honourable member for Wentworth represents concerning the jobs available in our community. It reflects a very narrow vision. Victorians know well that the State's transport system has many women who drive trams. It was only a matter of years ago that all trams were driven by men and all of the conductors were women. If one examines that proposition in terms of the traditional values that might be ascribed to those roles, as they were by the honourable member for Wentworth, one is reminded that it requires a great deal more physical strength to be a conductor than to be a tram driver. That situation had existed purely because of certain industrial relations over a period. It just was not seen that women ought to be performing the job of tram driver. There is clearly and absolutely no reason why women cannot or should not be able to perform a job of that type, yet it took until the 1980s, only a few years ago, before we actually saw women being allowed to participate in the job of driving a tram. Of course, they do an excellent job.

Another comment that I would like to make about the notion of pushing women into jobs that perhaps they do not want is that very sterotyped notions exist in our society about types of jobs and responsibilities. Another example is provided by police work. We need not go back very many years to the time when the vast majority of police were male and the major requisites for employment were physical attributes. That is why certain dimensions and certain sizes were necessary. If again we take a traditional view of the attributes of men and women, as did the honourable member for Wentworth, the simple fact is that the job of being a policeman or policewoman does not rely solely on the attribute of physical strength. Most of the work that police do involves clerical duties, the driving of cars and the solving of domestic disputes. Even on the traditional view taken by the honourable member for Wentworth one would have to argue that police work might be ideally suited to women. It is indeed in my view a very positive change in our society that women are now filling more and more positions as either tram drivers or police.

The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) suggested that as a result of this legislation there would be less freedom in our society. He was perhaps suggesting that because the legislation might be seen to be expanding the freedom available to women in our society it would necessarily be thought to be taking freedom away from another group. Of course that is not true. The sum total of freedom in our society is not fixed at all. That is an old, virtually economic mercantilist notion-that the total value of an economy is fixed. There is no limit on freedom in our society. To give more to women does not necessarily mean that any other group will have less.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the official rules of his Department for the use of Government vehicles by departmental officers for personal purposes.

(2) Is the expression of personal beliefs and political attitudes by way of stickers or slogans displayed by departmental employees on Government vehicles condoned or approved; if not, will he take steps to have a political slogan removed immediately from a Telecom Australia vehicle, licence No. ZGM 319.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The guidelines for use of Commonwealth vehicles issued by the Department of Administrative Services have been adopted as the official instructions for the use of such vehicles within the Department.
(2) The instructions require written approval before any modifications, including the affixing of stickers of any type, can be made to vehicles.
It is also Telecom policy that no stickers or slogans may be affixed to Telecom vehicles other than those for corporate identification and safety purposes.

Exceptions to this policy must be approved by the Chief General Manager of Telecom Australia who, to date, has provided no such approval. Instructions to this effect are widely circulated and strictly enforced.

The specific instance involving Telecom vehicle ZGM 319 has been investigated and it was established that a person unknown scrawled in crayon the words ' Manyana Republic' across the rear of the vehicle. The vehicle in question has been cleaned and the words removed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Assistance to Private Business by Department of Industry and Commerce

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) financial (b) technical and (c) other forms of assistance, are available from the Minister's Department to private business.
(2) What (a) is the contact point and (b) requirements have to be met to qualify, for each form of assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Industry and Commerce provides assistance to industry principally though the administration of the customs tariff. The Department, through the Australian Industry Development Corporation, also provides direct financial assistance to industry and, under the small business program, counselling and information services to small business.
Details of the types of assistance provided to industry, together with industry contact points and qualifying requirements, are outlined below.

AIDC provides specialised development finance (loans, equity, leasing) and project financing services to viable Australian companies, large and small. Proposals for such finance are assessed on a commercial basis.
Qualifying Requirements The AIDC is required to act in accordance with sound financial principles.

The AIDC Act has been amended to enable AIDC to invest in any industry but to require it to give priority to financing the manufacturing and service industries, industry reconstruction and the development of new or improved technology industries. AIDC makes its own individual lending decisions within these guidelines.
Contact Point Applications for financial assistance should be made direct to the Corporation at 212 Northbourne Avenue, Canberra City, A.C.T. 2601, Tel: (062) 479411
In certain circumstances the Department of Industry and Commerce provides technical advice on questions of tariff classification and valuation.
Contact Assistant Secretary, Import Administration, Department of Industry and Commerce, Canberra, A.C.T. 2601

The Department of Industry and Commerce examines requests from industry within its portfolio responsibilities, for changes in assistance and advises the Minister for Industry and Commerce on whether a reference should be forwarded to the Industries Assistance Commission-(IAC)-or Temporary Assistance Authority-( TAA).

Qualifying Requirements There must be an industry-wide prima facie case for a change in the level of assistance before a reference will be sent to the IAC or evidence of damage or threat or damage in respect to a reference to the TAA.
The Secretary, Department of Industry and Commerce, Canberra, A.C.T. 2601

Industry can obtain relief from duties normally payable on goods imported where it can be shown that goods serving similar functions are not produced in Australia or are not capable of being produced in Australia in the normal course of business.

When this criterion has been met, a concession in terms of the commercial tariff concession system may be granted which reduces the rate of duty normally payable on the imported goods to two per cent.

Qualifying Requirements and Contact Requirements to obtain a concession are set out in detail in a booklet which is available from the Assistant Secretary, Tariff Concession Branch, Department of Industry and Commerce, Canberra.

The Department may be able to provide protection to Australian industries that believe they are suffering unfair competition from dumped imports. Relief is offered through provisional securities, dumping duties and, in some cases, the acceptance of undertakings from exporters to raise prices to non-injurious levels.

Qualifying Requirements To initiate an investigation, the Department requires Australian industries first, to present evidence that export prices for goods are lower than the normal values in the country of export and, secondly, to show that imports at such prices are causing or threatening material injury to local manufacturers.
For information on dumping procedures contact in the first instance should be made with the Assistant Secretary, Dumping Branch, Department of Industry and Commerce, Canberra.

A bounty is a payment of money by the Government to a manufacturer in respect to the production of certain goods. The Government provides assistance by way of bounty where it considers it to be preferable to protective duties on imports (e .g. where a good constitutes a major input to another industry).
Qualifying Requirements Bounties are paid under the authority of an Act of Parliament. Payments may be made to manufacturers of the following goods:
Contact Claims for a bounty should be addressed to the Bounties Section of the Australian Customs Service in each capital city.
This scheme provides for an excise rebate of 7.155c per litre on diesel fuel used in off-road applications.

Qualifying Requirements Available for use in primary production, mining operations, domestic use and nursing homes, hospitals and aged persons homes- expenditure in 1983-84 is expected to be about $140m.
Contact Claims for a rebate of excise should be addressed to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Section of the Australian Customs Service in each capital city.
The petroleum products freight subsidy scheme subsidies the costs of tranporting motor spirit, automotive distillate, aviation fuels and power kerosene to non-metropolitan locations.
For the 1983-84 financial year it is estimated that the subsidy for the States is $89.15m and for the Northern Territory it is $11.45m.

Qualifying Requirements Distributors of certain petroleum can apply to the address below for registration. Registration is conditional upon the benefits being passed on to non-metropolitan users of these products.
Contact Completed applications should be lodged with the Inland Services Section of the Collector of Customs in each capital city.

Petroleum Retail Marketing Legislation The Petroleum retail Marketing Franchise Act 1980 and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980 together form a package of assistance measures for service station businesses which operate as lessees of oil companies.

The Franchise Act provides rights for lessee dealers (franchisees) against their oil companies (franchisors), mainly in regard to security of tenure, disclosure of information and price discrimination amongst franchisees
The Sites Act complements the Franchise Act by providing a limit on the number of service stations able to be operated directly by the major oil companies.

Qualifying Requirements The Franchise Act is available for franchisees, with the advice of their trade associations, to seek private remedies through the court system. The Government has responsibility for ensuring that the major oil companies comply with the Sites Act.
Contact Director, Petroleum Marketing Section, Department of Industry and Commerce, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Assistance to Private Business by Department of Resources and Energy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What (a) financial, (b) technical and (c) other forms of assistance, are available from the Minister's Department, to private business.
(2) What (a) is the contact point and (b) requirements have to be met to qualify, for each form of assistance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. (a) The Department provides financial assistance through the national industrial energy management scheme-NIEMS-to encourage energy conservation and grants for energy research, development and demonstration projects.
Under NIEMS, the energy audit scheme offers a subsidy up to $300 or 50 per cent of the fee-whichever is less-for a first time energy audit conducted by an independent registered energy consultant.
Also under NIEMS the energy management seminar and workshop program offers a reimbursement of up to $1,500 of net costs, to organisations conducting energy management seminars and workshops.
Grants for energy research development and demonstration projects may be approved by the Minister on the advice of the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council-NERDDC.
1. (b) Under NIEMS various publications and audio-visual material are available .

Under the national energy conservation program-NECP-a series of advisory booklets on energy management, designed particularly for the needs of small to medium sized commercial and industrial enterprises, is available.
Information on historical energy demand and supply statistics and forecasts of Australian energy demand is available in regular publications and upon special request.

The Department also provides technical reports relating to energy research projects under the national energy research development and demonstration program-(NERD&D). Technical branches of the Energy Research and Development Division also provide assistance in the form of replies to queries from the public on energy technologies.
Geoscientific publications, data and information are available from the Bureau of Mineral Resources.

The Division of National Mapping makes available copies of newly developed computer programs for technical survey applications and technical advice to users of reproduction material for maps and other products of the Division.

1. (c) Under the NIEMS scheme the national energy management awards are presented annually giving national recognition for outstanding achievement in energy management. Nominations, in June-July each year are invited from organisations in all areas of private and public enterprise, in up to six categories-buildings, energy management services, industry, public institutions, small business and transport. Nominations must be submitted on the official nomination form, usually by mid-September.

2. (a) The contact point for information on the national industrial energy management scheme, the national energy conservation program, energy statistics and forecasts and information on grants for energy research and development is:
For geoscientific publications from the Bureau of Mineral Resources the contact point is:
For information and advice on the services provided by the Division of National Mapping contact:

2. (b) To be eligible for the subsidy under the energy audit scheme, clients must have the audit conducted by a consultant who has been registered with the scheme. Clients must submit a completed subsidy application form accompanied by proof of payment of the consultant's fee and a copy of the energy audit report.
The organising body must first get the Department's agreement to the seminar or workshop.

Reimbursement of costs (net of any income from registration fees) is made on presentation of an itemised claim for payment which must be accompanied by receipts or other acceptable proof of expenditure.

There is no qualification on who may apply for grants for energy research, development and demonstration projects provided they relate to energy technologies or social, economic or environmental matters relating to energy supply or demand. Recommendations are based on the merit of the proposal and published priorities for energy research.
There are no other requirements that have to be met to qualify for other forms of assistance provided by the Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 1 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: Is he contemplating changes to the Australian Broadcasting and Television Act which would ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal consults not only with the television industry, as it is currently required to do, but also with other groups involved in the production and development of television programs in Australia; if not, is he prepared to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal-ABT-may consult with groups involved in the production and development of television programs when it considers it appropriate. I do not propose to consider, at this stage, placing a statutory obligation on the ABT to consult with these groups.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Employment Program in Electoral Division of Murray: Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 7 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's Department, or statutory authorities for which he is responsible, (a) made or (b) plans to make, an application for community employment program grants for employment creation in the electoral division of Murray; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The applications for grants submitted to date by the Department of Social Security under the community employment program-CEP-have been of an overall national character and therefore are not specifically related to any particular electorate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Security Intelligence Organisation: 'Four Corners' Program

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 December 1983 .

QUESTION.PARA: Has he or the management of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, received any complaints about the screening of a segment on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation in a Four Corners program on 19 November 1983; if so, (a) did those criticisms indicate viewers' beliefs that the program was not a balanced presentation and (b) what action did he take, or is prepared to take, to ensure the program was an accurate, unbiased account.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is:

ANSWER.PARA: One letter of complaint was received by the ABC.
(a) The viewer felt that the program under-estimated the danger posed by the Communist Party in Australia.

(b) The ABC legislation establishes the duty of the Board to ensure the accuracy and impartiality of the Corporation's news and information. I am advised that the ABC Board was satisfied that all appropriate checks were made in respect of this program.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Shire of Wanneroo: Department of Social Security Office

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, although three new offices of his Department have recently been opened in the Perth metropolitan area, the shire of Wanneroo, Western Australia, whose population of 108,000 residents is growing rapidly, does not have a Department of Social Security office; if so, why has an office not been established in the shire.
(2) Has planning commenced for the establishment of an office; if so, when will it be opened.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. Three new offices of the Department of Social Security have recently been opened in the Perth metropolitan area. An office in the shire of Wanneroo has not been established because of the need to devote resources to areas of greater need. Planning for an office in the shire is in the early stages of development and attention is being given to the pattern of population growth and the transport routes within the shire. While firm decisions have not been taken it is unlikely that an office will open prior to 1985-86.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that scanning receivers are (a) able to be used to listen to private conversations on Telecom Australia radio networks such as radio telephones and police radios and (b) not required to be licensed under the radiocommunications legislation recently passed by the House.
(2) Will he consider changes to the legislation to licence these receivers in light of their potential illegal use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) The Radiocommunications Act 1983 does provide for the licensing of prescribed receivers. However, I made a firm commitment during my second reading speech on the Radiocommunications Bill that the Government has no intention of licensing scanning receivers, or any other similar consumer devices commonly available to the public.

(2) Interception of the Telecom radiocommunication system is an offence under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. The Government is examining whether general radiocommunications privacy legislation could provide an effective solution to the problem based on engineering principles. However, it should be realised that, in today's technological society, the radio frequency spectrum is very much an area of public activity where conversations are liable to be overheard.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: Are public broadcast licences still available in Australia; if so, (a) in what categories and (b) in which cities or areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, although it is not intended to proceed with further metropolitan wide services until additional FM frequencies become available through the clearance of some television services from Band II of the VHF frequency spectrum.
(a) and (b) Low coverage Category C (community) licences in metropolitan areas;
Category C (community), in presently unserved non-metropolitan areas;
Category S (Special), in larger non-metropolitan centres currently served by a Category C station.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Accommodation of Radio and Television Signals

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress is being made to overcome the problem of accommodating both radio and television signals on the one Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service dish, which casts doubt on the promise of a cheap receiving dish costing $1,000 or less for people in remote areas.
(2) Have departmental officers solved the problem after consulting with the Hughes Aircraft Company in the United States of America.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service-(HACBSS)-to be provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation via the AUSSAT domestic satellite system, will provide one television service and at least two radio services to people in remote and underserved areas. Domestic reception of both the television and radio services has always been planned to be via a single receive-only earth station at each location.

(2) Development of transponders for AUSSAT has reached the point at which officers of the Department of Communications and the ABC have been able to use the Hughes Aircraft Company's spacecraft assembly and test facility in Los Angeles to test the performance of the HACBSS systems and equipment. Prior to this, the Department's testing has had to be based on simulated satellite equipment. On-ground tests at Hughes have further confirmed that at least two radio services can be included without significant adverse effects on the television signal.
My media release of 7 February 1984, titled 'Government Stays with PAL System for ABC Television', provides more details on HACBSS and the transmission technologies to be used.
